generalQuestions.title: Overview of Social Media Content Production (General Questions)

items.q: What exactly is social media content production?
items.a: Social media content production; It is the process of producing and publishing planned, format-appropriate and consistent content with the brand tone for the brand's target audience on channels such as Instagram, Facebook, TikTok and YouTube. The aim here is not just to share images; Telling stories is about building trust and demand.

items.q: What is the difference between content production and “social media management”?
items.a:
• Content Production: Visual/video + text + creative idea production part,
• Social Media Management: Strategy, planning, sharing, community management, comment/DM responses, reporting.

In the ideal scenario, the two feed each other: strategy → content production → publishing & community → reporting & optimization.

items.q: Why is there a need for a planned content calendar?
items.a:
Because "posting when you get the chance":
• confusion in brand tone,
• content repetition,
• missing campaign and season opportunities,
• chaos within the team

It leads. The content calendar makes the process predictable and manageable by clarifying the questions of when, what, in what format and to whom in advance.

items.q: Is content production just a "creative team" job?
items.a:
No. Best content:
• from the field (hotel, business, customer experience),
• from marketing strategy,
• From the creative team

It emerges from the fed hybrid structure. If data and content do not come from the field, the created world remains disconnected from reality.

items.q: Why is social media content production critical for hotels?
items.a:
User on the hotel and tourism side:
• see the hotel,
• to feel the atmosphere,
• Wants to review food, room, pool, beach and event images.

Therefore, social media becomes the "real showcase" of the hotel. Strong content creation allows you to go beyond classic photos on OTA pages and sell the experience.

items.q: How does social media content contribute to bookings?
items.a:
With the correct format and messages:
• creates trust and appreciation,
• carries traffic to the website and booking channels,
• Produces the “first touch” for remarketing and campaign audiences.

A significant portion of users check the hotel on social media before booking; The contents reinforce this decision.

items.q: What is social media content production and what does it involve?
items.a: It is the process of producing regular and consistent social media content for your brand with visual/video + text + format selection + calendar plan in accordance with the strategy.

items.q: Where should I start with a monthly content calendar for my hotel?
items.a: First, write down your season goals, campaigns and priority markets; then create a calendar that breaks them down into weekly content topics and formats.

items.q: How do I balance reels, posts and stories?
items.a: Generally, Reels are used for discovery and outreach, posts for showcase and fixed content, and stories for daily communication and campaigns; The rate is adjusted by segment and target.

items.q: How do I keep the brand tone consistent on social media?
items.a: First, you should determine the tone (formal, warm, entertaining, etc.) and vocabulary, and stick to this framework in all texts and answers; Prepare a “se tone” document if necessary.

items.q: Which makes more sense, an agency or an inside team?
items.a: The in-house team knows the field well; The agency brings expertise on strategy, creative and performance. The most efficient model is often hybrid: content from the field + agency production and orchestration.

items.q: Who is social media content production suitable for?
items.a: It is suitable for all brands that have a visual story such as hotel & tourism, lifestyle, F&B, fashion, health, education and want to generate demand and trust from social media.

section3.title: Content Production Service Scope

items.q: What does your social media content production service include?
items.a:
• Brand and target audience analysis,
• creating content strategy and calendar,
• format planning (post, carousel, reels, story, highlight),
• creative idea and concept development,
• visual/video production or editing of incoming images,
• copy writing and brand tone management,
• Preparing delivery and guideline for the broadcast plan.

items.q: What content formats do you work with?
items.a:
• Classic post (single image / carousel),
• Reels / short video,
• Story (announcement, question-answer, survey, slider),
• highlight covers,
• YouTube short / vertical video adaptation when necessary.

items.q: What kind of document does the content calendar look like?
items.a:
Generally monthly table:
• date,
• platform (Instagram, Facebook, TikTok, etc.),
• format,
• subject/title,
• visual/video description,
• text/CTA,
• notes & tags/mentions.

In this way, the team asked “what will we share in the morning of the day?” does not ask the question.

items.q: What content categories do you use for hotel and lifestyle brands?
items.a:
• room & facility promotion,
• destination and environment,
• gastronomy (food & bar),
• guest experiences and comments,
• campaigns and packages,
• team & behind the scenes,
• events and activities,
• guide and “how-to” contents.

items.q: How is brand tone management achieved in content production?
items.a: First, the tone and your word world are extracted (formal/casual, humorous/serious, youthful/corporate, etc.). Then all content texts are written within this framework; emoji, form of address, use of “you/you”, foreign words, etc. A clear line is determined for .

items.q: Does the agency take photos/videos or does the hotel provide it?
items.a:
Two models are also possible:
• Full service: photo/video production is also by us.
• Hybrid: the hotel/brand provides raw content from the field, we edit, edit, complete with editing and text.

items.q: Where do influencer and UGC content fall within this scope?
items.a: According to content strategy; Influencer or guest content (UGC) is placed on the calendar in certain categories. Fiction; It includes the editing and selection process to match your brand tone and quality.

items.q: Are content production and advertising creative production the same?
items.a: Similar but not exactly the same. Advertising creatives aim for harder targets and ROI; Organic content builds community and brand connection. However, organic content that works well can also be used as advertising creative.

items.q: What do you analyze before starting the content production process?
items.a:
• existing accounts (feed view, story usage, reels status),
• existing content categories and their deficiencies,
• target market and segments of the brand,
• rival and benchmark brands,
• past performance (which content did/did not work).

items.q: How is the monthly content calendar prepared?
items.a:
1. Main themes of the month (season, campaign, events),
2. distribution of content categories (room, destination, F&B, etc.),
3. weekly frequency and format determination,
4th draft topic headings and text skeletons,
5. Creating a visual/video requirement list.

items.q: How does the content approval process work?
items.a:
• Calendar + draft text + visual/video suggestions are prepared,
• Revision & approval is received by the hotel/brand,
• final contents are delivered or loaded directly into the planning tool.

An extra layer of approval can be added for critical announcements/campaigns.

items.q: Why is the IT/reservation side important in content production?
items.a:
• Campaign codes,
• link structures (booking link, UTM),
• reservation line/WhatsApp integrations,

When not set up correctly, “too good content” generates unmeasurable traffic on the campaign side. That's why integration with the booking and analytics side is important.

items.q: How should the in-house team and the agency work together?
items.a:
• Hotel team: provides photos/videos, information, campaign and event details from the field.
• Agency: undertakes content idea, editing, design/montage, text, layout and calendar management.

In this way, both authentic and professional content can be produced.

items.q: What tools are used in the content production process?
items.a:
• for project and calendar: Notion/Sheets/Asana/Trello,
• for visual/video: Photoshop, Premiere, CapCut etc.,
• for planning: Meta Creator Studio, Business Suite, 3rd party tools.

items.q: Is the process considered finished once the content goes live?
items.a:
No. Post-publication:
• performance tracking,
• analysis by content types and topics,
• optimization and rebalancing of categories in the coming months

must. Content production is not one-way; It is a continuous test-learn-improve cycle.

items.q: By what metrics should I measure the success of content production?
items.a:
• access and display,
• interaction rate (like, comment, save, share),
• profile visits and link clicks,
• DM/WhatsApp/phone directions,
• indirect contribution to bookings or sales (via analytics).

items.q: Are reels or classic post more effective?
items.a:
Generally:
• Reels → discovery, new audience, reach,
• post/carousel → showcase, information and “collection” content,
• story → daily communication, announcement and community.

Three formats together give the best results; Being locked into a single format is risky.

items.q: Where should I start with content experiencing low engagement?
items.a:
• visual/video quality,
• topic selection and message clarity,
• caption and CTA,
• sharing time and frequency,
• target audience choices (on the advertising side).

It is necessary to address the most obvious “image + message” issues first.

items.q: How can I measure the contribution of content to bookings?
items.a:
• profile link clicks,
• story link clicks,
• “social media interaction” segments in remarketing campaigns,
• UTM reservation links,
• organic social → booking funnel reports (GA4).

items.q: How to interpret ROI (return on investment) in content production?
items.a:
Although it is difficult to give credit to direct booking and sales alone; social media content:
• branded search volume,
• direct site logins,
• remarketing pool size,
• dissemination of campaign announcements

and these are evaluated together with reservation & income reports.

items.q: How often should a social media content report be prepared?
items.a:
• Weekly: short performance summary based on content category and format,
• Monthly: decision report on which content axes will continue / change at the strategy level.

section6.title: Productive Search & Industry-Focused Content Questions

items.q: How should content production differ for tourism regions (Antalya, Belek, Kemer, Bodrum, etc.)?
items.a:
• destination and environment focused content,
• season and event announcements,
• Content explaining the differences between family vs adults-only concept,
• language/tone adaptations for country-based markets (DE, UK, RU etc.).

items.q: How does content creation for lifestyle brands differ from hotels?
items.a:
Hotel content focuses more on accommodation and destinations, while lifestyle brands focus on:
• style,
• feeling,
• community,
• trend and inspiration

is focused. Storytelling and visual language are more prominent.

items.q: How should content production for local businesses (restaurants, cafes, clinics, etc.) be structured?
items.a:
• daily menu or campaigns,
• venue atmosphere and team,
• customer experience and reviews,
• local events and announcements,
• Content that frequently reminds you of map/link and time information.

items.q: What should be considered in social media content for hotels that appeal to the foreign market?
items.a:
• language compatibility and cultural sensitivity,
• holiday periods in the target market,
• features that these markets consider important (food, security, children's facilities, etc.).

items.q: How does content creation for city hotels differ from resorts?
items.a:
• location, transportation, business and MICE opportunities,
• short stay and weekday/weekend packages,
• meeting rooms and business services.

Story; It revolves around “comfortable & practical accommodation” rather than “holiday”.

items.q: Do I have to share content every day?
items.a: No; What is important is a regular and sustainable frequency. Quality content 3 times a week can be more valuable than random content every day.

items.q: Is it right to share the same content on all platforms?
items.a: It is possible to use the same raw content on different platforms, but the format, ratio and text must be adapted according to the platform.

items.q: Is just sharing Reels enough?
items.a: Reels are powerful for access but post/carousel for showcase and static information; Stories are necessary for daily communication. The combination is the healthiest.

items.q: Is photo or video more important?
items.a: Algorithm and user behavior currently favor video; But the “everything is video” approach is not correct either. The strong photo + video balance is ideal.

items.q: Is it okay to only use stock images?
items.a: Stock alone makes the brand ordinary. Real photo/video is a must, especially on the hotel and lifestyle side; stock may be most supportive.

items.q: How long should the text be in content production?
items.a: Enough to give the message clearly. Both short, striking texts and, when necessary, long "save" captions can be used depending on the content category.

items.q: Does the use of emoticons and emojis damage brand perception?
items.a: On the contrary, when used in the right tone and dosage, it can make the brand seem more friendly; The important thing is that it fits the brand tone.

items.q: Is it necessary to produce TikTok-specific content for hotels & tourism?
items.a: It is not mandatory, but it is a serious opportunity especially if you are targeting the young and new generation audience. Instead of carrying the same content verbatim, it is necessary to adapt it to the dynamics of TikTok.

items.q: Is it enough to move forward with only organic content?
items.a: Yes, up to a certain point; but the combination of organic + advertising is more powerful to quickly increase reach and visibility in target markets.

items.q: Can I also take content production as a short-term “audit + calendar + guideline” method?
items.a: Yes; Instead of a full service, it is possible to create a project that includes only strategy, calendar, category set and sample content templates, and have your internal team carry out the implementation.

to build it according to the healthiest model for you; It means clarifying what can be taken from the field and what can be produced on the agency side.

aiCapsule.text: Social media planning & strategy; Instead of "sharing whenever we want", it is to establish a measurable system based on clear KPIs, with the right content categories and campaign setups on the right channels. On the hotel and tourism side, wrong channel selection, scattered messages and unmeasurable targets lead to waste of both time and budget. A healthy strategy; It combines channel roles (IG core, FB support, TikTok discovery, YouTube deep narrative), content columns (room/facility, destination, gastronomy, guest experience, campaign, behind the scenes), 30-day planning logic and content-advertising-campaign integration in a single calendar. Aim; “What will we share and when?” It is to end the chaos and create a living strategy document that makes regular optimization with a repeatable calendar + KPI set.

intro.p1: Being successful on social media; It is not about "posting whenever you have the opportunity", but about establishing a system based on clear KPIs, in the right channels, with the right content categories and the right campaign setups. Especially on the hotel and tourism side, wrong channel selection, disorganized strategy and unmeasurable targets; It causes waste of both time and budget.
intro.p2:
This FAQ page; It brings together the most frequently asked questions about Social Media Planning & Strategy:
• Which channels should I be present on?
• How should I prepare a monthly plan?
• How do content, advertising and campaign plan connect?
• How should I define and track my KPIs?
intro.p3: The goal is “what will we share and when?” To end the chaos and create a measurable, repeatable social media strategy framework for hotels and brands.

items.q: What exactly is social media strategy?
items.a:
Social media strategy; It is the framework that defines who the brand is, which markets and segments it appeals to, what content and campaign language it will use in which channels, and which KPIs will measure these. So:

“To whom, where, what do we tell, how often and why?”

It is a plan that answers your questions clearly.

items.q: Why is social media planning necessary? Isn't "spontaneous sharing" enough?
items.a:
Just "sharing what comes to our mind at that moment" may be fun in the short term, but:
• Brand tone and message are dispersed,
• Season/campaign periods are missed,
• Content repetitions increase,
• Coordination within the team is lost.

Planning; It allows us to keep the content spontaneous and the content system controlled.

items.q: What do brands lose without a social media strategy?
items.a:
• Appears with a different “character” on each platform,
• Budget and time flow into the wrong channels,
• The cost of content production increases and the return remains uncertain,
• The true impact of social media on the booking/sales side is immeasurable.

In the long run, social media turns into a crowded activity that is done just to "exist", rather than a managed channel.

items.q: Why is social media strategy extra important for hotels and tourism brands?
items.a:
Because potential guests:
• Sees you on OTA,
• Searches on Google,
• then he goes on social media and wants to see the “real” hotel.

In accounts without a strategy; Since the concept, room, destination, service and comment language are not well-established, the guest either remains indecisive or turns to the competitor's better managed social media account.

items.q: Should the social media strategy be a one-off or a living document?
items.a:
The strategy provides a 12–18 month horizon; but:
• season,
• platform algorithm,
• target markets

As it changes, it should be reviewed and updated every 3–6 months. In other words, it is not a static document, but a constantly living document.

items.q: Which channels should be included in the strategy?
items.a:
This varies by brand, but the typical structure for hotel & tourism is:
• Instagram (core channel)
• Facebook (especially for the domestic market and some countries)
• TikTok (young and discovery-oriented audience)
• YouTube (longer format promotional videos)

LinkedIn can be added in hotels with strong B2B and collaboration sides. “Every channel” is not necessary for every brand.

items.q: What exactly is social media strategy?
items.a: It is the framework that defines on which channels, with which content categories, in what tone and frequency it will be shared, and with which KPIs it will be measured.

items.q: On which channels should I be present for my hotel?
items.a: Usually Instagram + Facebook is the core; Depending on the target market, a structure supported by TikTok and YouTube is the healthiest combination for hotels.

items.q: How to prepare a 30-day social media plan?
items.a: It starts with a simple but clear calendar that first writes down the themes of the month (campaign, season, events) and distributes them into weekly content categories and formats.

items.q: How should I determine my KPIs?
items.a: You must first define the business goal (brand awareness, booking, community, etc.) and select 3–5 core metrics (reach, interaction, link clicks, DM, booking, etc.) that serve this goal.

items.q: How do I link campaign, content and advertising plan?
items.a: Campaign goal → content categories and messages → advertising targeting and budget distribution should be designed in order; All must appear on the same calendar.

items.q: Who is social media planning & strategy suitable for?
items.a: Mainly hotel & tourism; It is suitable for all brands that want to generate brand awareness, demand and trust from social media.

section3.title: Service Scope: Channel Selection, Content Strategy, Campaign Setups

items.q: What does your social media planning & strategy service include?
items.a:
• Channel selection (which channel, which role),
• target audience and market segmentation,
• content categories and content architecture,
• monthly content and campaign plan,
• KPI set and reporting framework,
• advertising and content integration,
• Guideline for tone and visual language.

items.q: What criteria do you look at when choosing a channel?
items.a:
• target markets (country, age, income),
• sector and product/service type,
• status of existing accounts,
• content fit (which format is better explained where?),
• team capacity (how many channels can be managed?).

Then the “role” and “priority” are defined for each channel.

items.q: Why is the concept of "category" important in content strategy?
items.a:
The category is for “not redeciding every day.” For example for hotel:
• room & facility,
• destination,
• gastronomy,
• guest experience,
• campaign,
• team & behind the scenes,

Fixed columns are determined such as; The monthly plan is filled in these columns.

items.q: How do campaign setups connect to social media strategy?
items.a:
The campaign is not a stand-alone poster;
• teaser contents,
• announcement post/reels/story,
• reminder contents,
• closing and conclusion contents

It is planned with. This structure connects to the same strategy on both the organic and advertising sides.

items.q: What should be in the annual social media strategy for the hotel?
items.a:
• season plan (early booking, high season, low season),
• market targets (domestic market, foreign market, new markets),
• concept emphasis (family, adults-only, luxury etc.),
• main campaigns and promotional periods,
• content and advertising integration calendar.

items.q: How is the strategy different for lifestyle brands?
items.a:
It is not focused on “location & service” like a hotel;
• style,
• story,
• community,
• trend compliance

is in the foreground. This changes the content categories and tone design.

items.q: How should social media strategy and brand strategy be aligned?
items.a: Brand values, positioning, target segments and long-term goals; It should be included directly in the introduction part of the social media strategy. Content produced on the platforms should not behave "as if it were another brand".

items.q: Where do “se tone” and “visual language” fit into social media strategy?
items.a:
Both are the basic building blocks of strategy:
• se tone → text, caption, DM, crisis management,
• Visual language → layout, color, font, photo/video style.

Unless these two are clearly defined, content production and planning will seem disorganized.

items.q: What do you analyze before starting a social media strategy project?
items.a:
• existing accounts and performance (reach, engagement, community),
• content types and frequency,
• rival and benchmark brands,
• target market and segments (country, age, area of interest),
• current campaign and budget structure,
• Integration with web & reservation infrastructure.

items.q: How to prepare a 30-day social media plan?
items.a:
1. Month's goals (brand, campaign, sales),
2. proportions of content categories (e.g. 30% concept, 30% destination, 20% gastronomy, 20% campaign),
3. format distribution (post, reels, story),
4th day – topic matching,
5. Listing draft text and visual/video needs.

items.q: What does the annual social media strategy document contain?
items.a:
• goals and KPIs,
• channels and their roles,
• market/segment priorities,
• content categories and sample post types,
• campaign calendar,
• reporting and optimization mechanism.

items.q: Who should approve the social media strategy?
items.a:
• brand owner / GM,
• marketing manager,
• sales and revenue management if necessary,
• SMM lead on agency side.

Strategy; It is a document that not only the social media specialist but also all relevant units should own.

items.q: How should strategy be shared between content production and advertising teams?
items.a:
• Strategy: sets goals and framework,
• Content: produces creative within this framework,
• Advertising: carries these contents to the right audiences with the right budget.

They should all be aligned with the same calendar and set of KPIs.

items.q: Should SEO and the web side be taken into consideration when preparing a social media strategy?
items.a: Yes. Many contents to be produced on social media are linked to the web and blog side (guides, campaign pages, etc.). SEO and web priorities should also be reflected in the content & campaign plan.

items.q: Should the strategy document be long or short?
items.a:
To be applicable, it should be short but clear:
• 10–20 pages,
• not unnecessary theory; involving brand-specific decisions,
• a format that anyone can read and understand.

Very long, theoretical documents often remain on the shelf.

items.q: How should strategy changes be managed?
items.a:
• major pivots (new market, new channel, rebranding): revision of the document,
• minor optimizations (KPI tweak, small campaign addition): monthly/quarterly revision notes.

The important thing is; changes are noted and can be associated with future reports.

items.q: How to measure the success of a social media strategy?
items.a:
According to the goals you set in the strategy:
• brand goals → reach, follower quality, brand search volume,
• engagement targets → engagement rate, save/share, DM,
• sales/booking targets → link clicks, site sessions, remarketing performance, direct sales contribution.

items.q: How should SMM KPIs be determined?
items.a:
3–5 main KPIs should be selected first:
• 1–2 brand/target audience KPIs,
• 1–2 interaction KPIs,
• 1–2 business KPIs (clicks, leads, bookings, etc.).

The target, time period and responsible person should be defined for each KPI.

items.q: What should be in the strategy-focused SMM report?
items.a:
• summary KPIs of the month (target vs actual),
• channel based performance,
• content category/format based performance,
• campaign & advertising results,
• proposed changes for the next month.

items.q: How does social media strategy tie into media budget?
items.a:
• brand/target audience growth activities → higher funnel focused budget,
• sales/reservation focused activities → performance campaigns.

The organic vs. advertising role should be defined for each channel and content category in the strategy document.

items.q: When to pivot on an underperforming strategy?
items.a:
• KPIs remain significantly below target for 3–6 months,
• emergence of new market or channel needs,
• radical changes in competition and user behavior

In this case, it may be necessary to review the strategy more radically.

section6.title: Productive Search & Industry-Focused Strategy Questions

items.q: How should the social media strategy be designed for hotels in Turkey?
items.a:
• distinction between domestic market (TR) and foreign market (DE, UK, RU etc.),
• destination based content and campaigns,
• Messages compatible with OTA-web-call center balance,
• Content themes that change according to season (early booking, season, low season).

items.q: Is a special SMM plan required for tourism regions (Antalya, Belek, Kemer, Side, Bodrum, Alanya)?
items.a:
Yes. In these regions:
• busy season and short decision time,
• multinational guest profile,
• destination competition

Therefore, intra-destination differentiation and market-based content & advertising strategies are essential.

items.q: What is the main difference in social media strategy for lifestyle brands?
items.a: It is not focused on “product & location” like a hotel; It focuses on emotion, style and community. KPIs are accordingly; It is positioned on the side of community, interaction and brand collaborations.

items.q: How should social media strategy be positioned for e-commerce brands?
items.a:
• product focused content + UGC,
• campaign and discount periods,
• influencer & affiliate integration,
• social channel → site → sales funnel.

SMM KPIs should be reported through sales and basket.

items.q: What should the social media strategy be like for B2B / corporate brands?
items.a:
• LinkedIn and thought leadership content,
• case study, webinar, whitepaper, event contents,
• lead-focused campaigns.

Here, qualified leads and relationships are prioritized rather than interaction.

section7.title: Mini Social Media Planning & Strategy FAQ

items.q: Do I have to be present on all channels?
items.a: No; It is better to deepen in 2-3 channels chosen according to your target market and resources, than to disperse in 6-7 channels.

items.q: Is it right to change strategy every month?
items.a: No; The strategy should be tested for 3–6 months and supported with small optimizations; It should be radically revised only in case of major changes.

items.q: Is it right to determine SMM KPIs only based on the number of followers?
items.a: Number of followers alone is not an indicator of success; It should be supported by metrics such as interaction, clicks, leads/reservations.

items.q: Only organic, no advertising; Is this strategically sufficient?
items.a: Yes, up to a point; But advertising and strategic campaigns are inevitable for rapid growth and new markets.

items.q: Just advertising, no organic content; does this work too?
items.a: In the short term, yes; But if the user sees a poor feed when they enter your profile, trust and premium perception will be damaged.

items.q: Do I have to share the strategy document with the team?
items.a: Absolutely yes; All teams should know the same road map so that content, advertising and community management all go in the same direction.

items.q: How detailed should I detail the content calendar in the strategy?
items.a: Instead of micromanaging every day; It is sufficient to provide clarity on the basis of category, format and theme. Details can become clear in daily planning.

items.q: Is social media strategy and brand identity kit (brandbook) related?
items.a: Yes; Visual language, colors, logo usage, typography and tone are the basic inputs of social media strategy.

items.q: Does it make sense to take on content production without a strategy?
items.a: Content can be produced in the short term, but the question "what does it serve" in the medium-long term remains unanswered; There must be a frame on top.

items.q: Can I get social media planning & strategy service once?
items.a: Yes; It is possible to prepare a strategy + calendar + guideline once and have the implementation carried out by internal teams. For regular revision, periodic consultancy may be preferred.

This meeting;

aiCapsule.text: Reels and short videos; It is not just “the format the algorithm loves”, it is the type of content that conveys the brand story fastest and is closest to creating demand. Aim; To produce content that is not only watched, but also recorded, shared and creates reservations/demands.

generalQuestions.title: General Questions About Reels & Short Videos

items.q: What exactly is reel and short video production?
items.a: Reels & short video production; It is the process of producing short but effective videos for your brand by correctly using the hook-story-call-to-action trio on vertical video-oriented platforms such as Instagram, TikTok, YouTube Shorts. The goal here is to capture both the signals that the algorithm likes (full views, rewatches, saves, sharing) and the brand's goals (awareness, reservations, sales) at the same time.

items.q: Why do I need a vertical video strategy?
items.a: Because users consume content largely in mobile and vertical formats. Algorithms (especially Instagram & TikTok) also prioritize vertical, full-screen and fast-consuming content. Without a vertical video strategy; It is shown less in the stream, it remains in the background in discover/recommended content, and your visual/video investments do not give full performance.

items.q: Is Reels & short video production just for social media?
items.a: No. Edited short videos; It can also be used in advertising campaigns, on the website (hero/video areas), e-mail and landing pages, and even on offline screens. Properly planned video production is for multi-channel use, not for a single platform.

items.q: Why is Reels so powerful for the hotel and tourism industry?
items.a: Because the hotel experience is visual and emotional: the room, the pool & beach, the food & bar, the entertainment & activities, the destination and the environment. All of this can be conveyed very quickly in a short video. Guest “what is it like to be there?” searches for an answer to the question; Reels give this feeling directly.

items.q: Do short videos only work for younger audiences?
items.a: No. Reels and vertical video consumption is extremely high in the 25-45 age group. A significant portion of decision-making audiences, especially in sectors such as hotel, lifestyle, F&B, fashion and health, consume Reels/Shorts on a daily basis.

items.q: Should reels & short videos completely replace classic feed posts?
items.a: Not completely. Reels are strong on discovery and outreach; Classic post and carousel content is still critical in terms of creating permanent value on the showcase, information and profile. The healthiest structure is to use these two formats together.

items.q: What is Reels & short video production and what is its use?
items.a: It serves to present the brand to the target audience with a focus on discovery, interaction and demand creation with vertical, short and quickly consumed video formats.

items.q: Where should I start with Reels content for my hotel?
items.a: Reviewing existing images; It is best to start with simple but clear Reels describing the room, facility, destination, food and guest experience.

items.q: How do I make the first 3 seconds stronger?
items.a: Using an intriguing image, short text or question at the beginning of the video; with an introduction that will capture the audience in the first second.

items.q: What music and effects work best?
items.a: Trendy sounds and popular music recommended by the platform generally perform better; However, brand tone and harmony with the concept are always a priority.

items.q: Can I also use Reels in advertisements?
items.a: Yes. Reels that perform well can be creatively reused or optimized in advertising campaigns.

items.q: Who is Reels & short video production suitable for?
items.a: It is especially suitable for all sectors focused on hotel & tourism, lifestyle, fashion, F&B, sports, health and experience.

section3.title: Scope of Service: Vertical Video Strategy, Format and Algorithm

items.q: What does your reels & short video production service include?
items.a: It includes determining the vertical video strategy, content categories and theme planning, writing hook-content-call-to-action scenarios, shooting plan (hotel/brand site + production), editing, music, effects and subtitle editing, platform-based optimization (IG Reels, TikTok, Shorts) and performance analysis and optimization suggestions.

items.q: For which platforms do you produce short videos?
items.a: Instagram Reels, TikTok, YouTube Shorts; Production is made for Facebook Reels and other vertical video areas when necessary. Adaptation is made according to the ideal length and format constraints for each platform.

items.q: What exactly does hook–content–call to action fiction mean?
items.a: Hook (first 1–3 seconds): image, question, or text that attracts attention. Content (middle section): main message, story and details. call to action (last part): clear guidance such as “book now”, “click the link in the profile”. Successful short videos implement these three blocks without wasting time.

items.q: What themes and scenes are used for hotel promotional Reels?
items.a: Room and balcony images, pool and beach, lobby and common areas, restaurant & bar, guest experiences (entrance, breakfast, entertainment) and destination images. The aim is to quickly ask "what can happen here in a day?" is to give the feeling.

items.q: How is music selection made in short videos?
items.a: Trending or recommended sounds, songs compatible with the concept and season, and licensed/permitted music that will not cause copyright problems are preferred on the platform. Songs that do not fit the brand tone are avoided.

items.q: Is the creative / production team doing the shooting, or are ready-made videos being edited?
items.a: Both models are possible. In professional shooting, the team goes to the field and produces a new video; In the hybrid model, the brand provides raw videos from the field and we edit them in accordance with the Reels/TikTok format.

items.q: Are reels & short video production and creative video production the same thing?
items.a: It's not exactly the same. In short video production, speed, vertical format and hook-to-action clarity come to the fore. Creative productions can be longer and cinematic. Short videos are platform and algorithm driven.

items.q: What do you analyze before starting a Reels strategy project?
items.a: Current Reels/TikTok performance, music and formats used, content themes (room, destination, food, etc.), competitor and benchmark brands, and target market and age groups are analyzed.

items.q: How is the shooting plan prepared?
items.a: It is determined which locations (room, pool, lobby, restaurant), which hours (light & occupancy), which scenarios (check-in, breakfast, pool day, evening entertainment) will be used. Accordingly, the shooting day in the field is planned.

items.q: Can you convert existing videos to Reels format?
items.a: Yes. Videos shot horizontally or in a different format can be adapted to the Reels/TikTok format by cropping, re-framing, speeding up, adding text and music; but it may not be as flexible as new footage.

items.q: What techniques do you use to strengthen the first 3 seconds?
items.a: Starting with the strongest scene, using questions or assertive sentences on the screen, fast zoom/movement, and visuals that arouse curiosity in the audience.

items.q: Why are subtitles important?
items.a: Many users watch the video without sound. Subtitles and short texts on the screen support message understanding, increase viewing time and accessibility.

items.q: What does the brand guideline for reels & short videos include?
items.a: It includes do/don't lists for logo and watermark usage, color palette and font preferences, tone (premium, fun, etc.), music and effect preferences.

items.q: Should the production of reels be one-time or continuous?
items.a: Best results are achieved when Reels and short videos are part of an ongoing content plan. Staying silent for a long time after a single campaign is not sustainable.

items.q: By what metrics is real performance measured?
items.a: Viewing and completion rate, viewing time, saving and sharing, comments and likes, profile visits and link clicks; On the advertising side, ROAS is measured by click-through and conversion metrics.

items.q: “It is watched but not interacted with.” What could be the problem with Reels?
items.a: It may be the lack of a call to action, the message not being clear, the motivation to save/share being weak, the caption being insufficient, or the video looking too much like an advertisement.

items.q: “It's not even being watched” Where should we start in Reels?
items.a: Hook's weakness, music/rhythm incompatibility, lack of interest in the content, or general category incompatibility of the account should be examined; The first 3 seconds and theme should be reconsidered.

items.q: What should I pay attention to when using reels in advertisements?
items.a: Care should be taken to ensure that it looks platform native, that it does not shout like an advertisement in the first second, that the CTA is clear, and that it is compatible with the target audience and country/language.

items.q: How can I see the contribution of Reels traffic to the reservation?
items.a: It is measured by examining UTM links, GA4 social segments, remarketing lists for video viewers, and Reels–site session–booking correlation during campaign periods.

section6.title: Questions Focusing on Core Issues

items.q: Videos are watched but not recorded; From where?
items.a: Saving is the user saying “I have to look at this again later.” If the video lacks practical information, inspiring scenes or rewatch value, the user will just watch and pass. It should contain an element of hint, guidance or inspiration for recordability.

items.q: What are the most common mistakes made in poorly interactive Reels?
items.a: Images without a message, relying only on music and images, not asking questions to the user, leaving the caption section blank, and sharing too often or too infrequently are the most common mistakes.

items.q: How does choosing the wrong music and format affect performance?
items.a: The wrong music can make the video seem off-kilter, fail to connect emotionally with the target audience, and limit reach in some markets. Additionally, if the rate, duration and resolution do not comply with the platform rules, there will be a disadvantage in the Reels exploration area.

items.q: What should I do if production costs are high and performance is low?
items.a: It is necessary to turn the production into lighter but smart fictions, produce modular content instead of a single large production, use organic UGC from the field more, and accelerate the test-learn cycle.

items.q: We are trying to shoot reels, but team motivation is low; From where?
items.a: Since there is usually no clear strategy, sample set and success criteria, the team asks “what should we shoot?” He is left alone with the question. Theme sets, storyboard examples and clear goals increase motivation.

items.q: What should the Reels strategy be like for regions such as Antalya, Belek, Kemer, Side, Bodrum?
items.a: Separate content plans should be designed for in-season and low season with destination-specific images, concept emphasis (family, adults-only, luxury), country-based language and subtitles.

items.q: How should Reels & short videos be edited for City hotels?
items.a: Location and transportation advantages, business areas, short stay concepts and short stories connecting the city experience with the hotel should be at the forefront.

items.q: What should Reels focus on for lifestyle brands?
items.a: Style and mood boards, combination and usage stories, scenes that create a sense of community, and content with trendy sounds should stand out.

items.q: How does Reels benefit local businesses?
items.a: Menu and service displays, venue atmosphere, short customer experiences and address/location-focused Reels support both local SEO and social discovery.

items.q: How does Reels strategy differ for hotels that appeal to the foreign market?
items.a: Language and subtitles, expectations and sensitivities, and campaign messages should be adapted according to the target countries; Market-based content should be produced instead of single messages.

section8.title: Mini Reels & Short Video FAQ

items.q: How long should Reels last?
items.a: In general, videos between 7–15 seconds perform best; In longer videos the hook and flow should be very strong.

items.q: Do I have to show my face on every Reels?
items.a: No; However, human scenes enable the video to establish a stronger bond. Just the appearance of the space is not always enough.

items.q: Are subtitles required in Reels?
items.a: Recommended; because a large number of users watch videos silently.

items.q: Can I use the same video for TikTok and Reels?
items.a: In most cases yes; However, it is useful to make text, music and duration adaptations according to platform dynamics.

items.q: Do I have to share Reels every day?
items.a: No; It is more important to find a sustainable frequency. For example 3 Reels + 2 posts per week.

items.q: Is a professional team necessary for reel shooting?
items.a: Not always. Well-planned phone shots can also give high performance; The important thing is the story and fiction.

items.q: Are hashtags still important on Reels?
items.a: It is a supportive signal; the main driving force is watch time, save, share and engagement.

items.q: Is it enough to just use trending sounds?
items.a: No; Trendy sound alone will not bring performance unless it is combined with the right visual and clear message.

items.q: Is it okay to reuse old videos as Reels?
items.a: If it is constructed and updated correctly, yes; Especially images with potential can be re-evaluated.

items.q: Can I purchase short video production as a one-time concept + sample set?
items.a: Yes; It is possible to start with packages containing strategy, storyboard and a few sample Reels, and produce the rest within the internal team.

generalQuestions.title: General Questions About Social Media Ads

items.q: What exactly are social media ads?
items.a: Social media ads; Meta (Facebook/Instagram), TikTok, LinkedIn, YouTube etc. These are campaign structures that provide paid exposure to specific target audiences on platforms. The goal isn't to expose your brand to random crowds; To generate brand awareness, interaction, leads, sales or reservations with the right targeting and the right creatives.

items.q: What do social media ads do, how is it different from SEO/organic?
items.a: While SEO and organic content help build long-term visibility and community; Social media ads offer rapid testing, rapid scaling, and the ability to target specific audiences and markets in a short time. Together, they create an “organic + paid” hybrid growth model.

items.q: Why are social media ads so critical for hotels?
items.a: On the hotel and tourism side, seasons are short, competition is high and the decision process requires intense information and visuals. Meta and TikTok ads; It creates demand both on the OTA and web side by quickly delivering the concept, price and experience message to the right markets and segments. Social media ads are indispensable, especially in remarketing and campaign announcements.

items.q: Is it enough to just press the “boost post” button?
items.a: No. The “Boost” button offers limited targeting and optimization options. For a real performance structure, correct campaign purpose, detailed targeting and remarketing and pixel / conversion API installation are required via Business Manager / Ads Manager.

items.q: Do social media ads only work for B2C?
items.a: No. Social media advertisements are extremely effective for lead collection, webinar/event announcements, whitepaper and case study distribution, and branded awareness campaigns in B2B and corporate brands. Only KPI and creative language differ.

items.q: Should social media ads be only sales-oriented?
items.a: Not. A healthy structure; It consists of awareness & video views in the upper funnel, traffic & interaction & lead in the middle stage, and sales/booking & remarketing layers in the lower stage. Only sales-oriented ads can reduce algorithm performance in the long run.

items.q: What are social media ads and what do they do?
items.a: It allows you to display your brand to certain audiences for a fee on platforms such as Meta/TikTok and generate awareness, interaction, leads, sales or reservations.

items.q: Where should I start with Meta and TikTok ads for my hotel?
items.a: First you need to clarify your Business Manager setup, pixel/conversion API integration and key campaign goals (awareness vs bookings).

items.q: Why does it occur to get a lot of impressions and few sales?
items.a: It is usually caused by incorrect targeting, poor landing page, incomplete conversion tracking or creative-target audience mismatch.

items.q: How do I accurately define my target audience in social media ads?
items.a: By using your real customer data (web, CRM, pixel data) together with in-platform interest, behavior and lookalike audiences.

items.q: How to improve ROAS on social media ads?
items.a: By establishing a test-learn-optimize cycle with the right campaign purpose, clear targeting, strong creative, good landing pages and proper conversion tracking.

items.q: Who are social media ads suitable for?
items.a: It is suitable for all businesses focused on hotel & tourism, e-commerce, B2B, corporate and brand communication.

section3.title: Scope of Service: Meta Ads, TikTok Ads and Campaign Setups

items.q: What does your Social Media Ads service include?
items.a: Meta Business Suite/Manager installation control, TikTok Ads Business installation control, pixel & conversion API & event settings, campaign architecture (funnel structure), audience sets (cold, warm, hot, lookalike), creative set (image, video, Reels, carousel), budget & bid strategy, reporting and optimization.

items.q: On which platforms do you manage advertising?
a: LinkedIn Ads (for B2B brands) when necessary,
YouTube video & bumper integration (as part of funnel).

items.q: Which campaign types are priority for hotels?
items.a: On the Meta Ads side, traffic & conversions (reservations / leads), remarketing (web visitors, video watchers, interactors) and lead form campaigns are prioritized. In TikTok Ads, awareness + traffic campaigns work strongly to support the Instagram funnel.

items.q: Which social media advertising setups are used for e-commerce?
Are back-end and analytics integrations (GA4, CRM, etc.) included in this service?
items.a: According to the project scope; GA4 and basic conversion tracking integration are handled together with the SMM advertising service. CRM and advanced integrations can be carried out with separate data/analytics projects.

items.q: Does creative (image/video) production fall within the scope of advertising?
items.a: Generally yes. Production of basic campaign creatives (static post, carousel, Reels/short video adaptations) is included in the project. Large productions can be combined with the creative/video production package.

items.q: What do you analyze before starting a social media advertising project?
How is the campaign architecture (funnel structure) set up?
items.a: Generally, a three-layer structure is established: awareness/video view in the upper funnel, traffic/interaction/lead in the middle funnel, and conversion and remarketing campaigns in the lower funnel. At each layer, the creative, message and call to action are differentiated.

items.q: How do you create target audience segments?
a: custom audience (site visitors, pixel data, CRM),
lookalike (lookalikes of your most valuable customers),
market based segments (DE, UK, RU, TR etc.).

items.q: How do you plan your budget?
items.a: Number of rooms/products, number of target markets, campaign duration, historical ROAS/CPA data, season and competition level are taken into account. The budget is increased gradually with a test-learn-scale approach.

items.q: How often are campaigns optimized?
items.a: Weekly or more frequently during busy campaign periods; During stable periods, weekly optimization and monthly comprehensive performance reviews are performed.

items.q: How does Meta Ads and TikTok Ads governance differ?
items.a: Meta Ads are more on the remarketing and conversion side; TikTok Ads, on the other hand, are positioned in discovery, brand lift and young audience outreach. The role of each platform is clearly defined in the strategy document.

items.q: With what basic KPIs is social media advertising performance reported?
What steps do you follow in a “too many impressions, few sales” situation?
items.a: Target audience width, creative-message-landing harmony, conversion tracking accuracy and remarketing setups are analyzed in detail.

items.q: How to determine social media advertising budget?
items.a: Budget is simulated with targeted number of sales/bookings, maximum CPA accepted, estimated CPC and conversion rates; It is then confirmed by small tests.

items.q: How to set up a remarketing campaign?
items.a: It is designed with creatives with reminder and urgency messages for warm audiences such as web visitors, those who abandoned the cart/reservation step, and video watchers.

items.q: How do TikTok and Instagram ads contribute to sales?
items.a: TikTok generally provides first touch and discovery; Instagram, on the other hand, is strong in remarketing and decision making. When used together, it creates a funnel that increases CTR and CVR.

section6.title: Questions Focusing on Core Issues

items.q: I get a lot of impressions and few sales; From where?
items.a:
• broad and irrelevant targeting,
  • weak landing page (slow, confusing, unreliable),
  • wrong campaign purpose (expecting conversion through reach/engagement),
  • incorrect or incomplete measurement (not seeing the real conversion).

items.q: How do you address the issue of high click cost (CPC)?
items.a:
• narrowing or redefining the target audience,
  • performing creative and message A/B tests,
  • optimizing the bidding strategy,
  • cleaning up irrelevant placements and audiences.
The right audience and good creative combination increases CTR and lowers CPC.

items.q: What should I look for if my ads are getting rejected frequently?
items.a:
• platform policy violations (banned words, health claims, rebate writing, etc.),
  • wrong category or industry selection,
  • misleading or unverifiable promises.
Policy compliance is as critical as technical performance.

items.q: There is a budget, no results; Where could I be making a mistake?
items.a:
• tracking (GTM, pixel, GA4) is missing or incorrect,
  • campaign purpose and optimization signal are incorrect,
  • creative-message-market mismatch,
  • funnel deficiency (only cold audience without remarketing).

items.q: I left everything to the agency, but I don't know what happened; How to solve this?
items.a:
• creating a clear KPI set,
  • providing access to monthly reports and dashboards with comments,
  • holding regular review meetings,
  • ensuring the active participation of the brand side in the campaign goals.
Advertising management is a joint agency-brand process.

items.q: What should be the social media advertising strategy for hotels across Türkiye?
items.a:
• Meta campaigns in TR language for the domestic market,
  • country-based (DE, UK, RU etc.) segments and localized creatives for foreign markets,
  • campaign setups that clearly explain the destination and concept.

items.q: What should be taken into consideration for target country markets (DE, UK, RU etc.)?
items.a:
• language and text localization,
  • country-specific holiday and campaign periods,
  • criteria that these markets care about (food, children's areas, security, etc.).

items.q: How should social media ads be positioned for e-commerce brands?
items.a:
• dynamic/collection campaigns for product discovery,
  • add to cart remarketing,
  • limited time creations during campaign and discount periods,
  • catalog feed integration.

items.q: How should brand communication and performance campaigns be separated?
items.a:
• brand communication: awareness, video views, community building,
  • performance: traffic, conversion, catalog sales and leads.
KPIs and reporting should clearly reflect this distinction.

items.q: How to use social media ads for local businesses?
items.a:
• location-targeted campaigns,
  • booking/search/WhatsApp CTAs,
  • map and local SEO integration,
  • short-term remarketing and promotional campaigns.

section8.title: Mini Social Media Advertising FAQ

items.q: Do I have to advertise every day?
items.a: No; The important thing is to achieve sustainable continuity in line with the campaign goals.

items.q: Does only page like advertising make sense?
items.a: It is considered low value in most cases; Models focused on interaction, traffic and conversion should be preferred.

items.q: Is it possible to advertise on social media with a small budget?
items.a: Yes; but the goal should be clear and not dispersed across too many channels or markets.

items.q: Can I advertise without Pixel?
items.a: Technically yes; However, conversion optimization cannot be done and healthy performance is difficult to achieve.

items.q: Is just remarketing enough?
items.a: It may work in the short term; However, cold campaigns are necessary to produce new audiences in the long term.

items.q: Is it incomplete to progress only with Meta without using TikTok?
items.a: It varies depending on the target audience; TikTok provides a serious advantage in young and discovery-oriented markets.

items.q: Is it okay to use the same creative for a long time?
items.a: Generally no; Creative fatigue occurs and performance decreases. Regular creative renewal required.

items.q: Is it right to keep ad texts only in Turkish?
items.a: It can only happen if the domestic market is targeted; In foreign markets, localization must be made in the relevant language.

items.q: Do social media ads contribute to SEO?
items.a: Indirectly yes; It supports SEO signals by increasing brand search volume and direct site traffic.

items.q: Can I get SMM advertising service only as audit + installation?
items.a: Yes; Account audit, campaign templates and basic setup can be done and management can be handed over to the internal team.

generalQuestions.title: General Questions About Social Media Analysis

items.q: What exactly is social media analysis?
items.a: Social media analysis; It is the process of collecting access, interaction, saving, click and conversion data of the content and advertisements you produce on platforms such as Instagram, Facebook, TikTok, YouTube and interpreting them on the basis of content category, format, channel and target audience. The goal is not "let's produce a lot of content"; “Which content works for us?” is to answer the question with data.

items.q: Why is a social media report necessary?
items.a:
Because without a report:
  • You cannot know which content categories are working,
  • which formats (Reels/post/story) give better performance,
  • which campaigns and ads really contribute to sales/bookings
. Social media analysis; It ensures that strategy, content and advertising decisions are based on data rather than guesswork.

items.q: Is analysis & reporting only required for large accounts?
items.a: No. Even in small hotels or local businesses; If 3-5 content is produced per week, and time/budget is spent for this, you have to measure what it does. The report is perhaps even more critical than big brands in order not to make the wrong decision with a small budget.

items.q: Can I say that I am successful in social media with “one metric”?
items.a:
No. Alone: ​​
  • number of followers,
  • reach,
  • number of likes
are not indicators of success. The important thing is; is how these metrics look together and relate to business goals (brand, lead, booking, sales).

items.q: Social media reporting; How does content fuel advertising and strategy?
items.a:
• on the content side → which topics and formats will continue/updated,
  • on the advertising side → which audiences and creatives will be scaled,
  • on the strategy side → which goals are realistic
it becomes clear through reports. So analysis & reporting is the R&D (R&D) layer of social media.

items.q: Why is social media analysis extra important for hotels?
items.a:
Social media on the hotel and tourism side:
  • part of the guest's decision process,
  • critical in campaign and seasonal occupancy management,
  • strategic in terms of OTA - web - call center balance.
Therefore, knowing which content and campaign works better in which market, in which season, with which audience; It is important not only for the “nice feed” but also for occupancy and revenue.

items.q: What is social media analysis and what does it do?
items.a: Social media analysis; It allows you to see which content and campaigns are producing real business results by looking at reach, engagement and conversion data.

items.q: What social media metrics should I look at for my hotel?
items.a: In particular, you should look at reach, engagement rate, save/share, profile and link clicks, DM/WhatsApp clicks, and organic/paid social booking or lead data.

items.q: What does it mean if there is access but no interaction?
items.a: Your content is showing but is not engaging or inviting enough for the user; It is necessary to rethink the subject, creative or CTA.

items.q: How do I interpret Reels performance?
items.a: Instead of just viewing; You should evaluate the completion rate, watch time, saving/sharing and subsequent movements created in the profile/external link together.

items.q: What should be in the monthly social media report?
items.a: Summary KPIs (reach, engagement, saves, clicks, conversions), content category/format based performance, ad-organic split and recommended actions for the next month.

items.q: Who is social media analysis & reporting suitable for?
items.a: It is suitable for anyone who wants to spend time and budget on social media and see results, including hotel & tourism, lifestyle, e-commerce and corporate brands.

section3.title: Service Scope: KPIs, Report Structure & Tools

items.q: What does your Social Media Analysis & Reporting service include?
items.a:
• Determining the KPI set (access, interaction, saving, click, conversion),

  • Integration of GA4 and link click data,

items.q: What tools do you use to analyze social media?
items.a:

  • GA4 (socially sourced traffic and conversions),

items.q: Which social media KPIs should be followed?
items.a:
• reach and impressions,
  • number and rate of interaction (like, comment, save, share),
  • profile and link clicks,
  • DM/WhatsApp clicks,
  • socially sourced traffic, lead, reservation, sales.

items.q: Why is it important to compare reel, post and story performance?
items.a:
The role of each format is different:
  • Reels → discovery and new audience,
  • Post/Carousel → showcase and information,
  • Story → daily communication and community.
Performance analysis helps determine in what proportion these formats will be used.

items.q: What additional KPIs do you look at for hotels?
items.a:
• number of reservations/leads from social media,
  • WhatsApp/phone clicks,
  • social-organic-paid contributions during campaign periods,
  • destination/market-based reach and interaction.

items.q: How do KPIs differ for e-commerce and brand communication accounts?
items.a: For e-commerce, product page clicks, cart additions, organic/paid social channel sales stand out; On the brand communication side, community metrics (save/share, DM, mention, UGC) become more important.

items.q: What do you examine before starting an analysis & reporting project?
items.a:
• existing accounts and content structure,
  • access & interaction trends for the last 3-6 months,
  • content categories and format distribution,
  • advertising-organic distinction,
  • business goals of the hotel/brand (brand, lead, reservation, sales).

items.q: What sections should the monthly social media report consist of?
items.a:
• summary KPI (total reach, engagement, clicks, conversion),
  • performance by content category and format,
  • best and weakest content examples,
  • advertising results (if any),
  • content & campaign recommendations for the next month.

items.q: How do you compare performance between content types (Reels/post/story)?
items.a:
• average reach,
  • average interaction rate,
  • save/share rate,
  • profile/link click contribution
are compared; so it becomes clear which format works better for which purpose.

items.q: What time periods do you use in the analysis & reporting process?
items.a:
• Weekly → quick signals and optimizations,
  • Monthly → strategy and category level decisions,
  • Quarterly → big picture based on season and market.

items.q: Who should read social media reports?
items.a:
• social media & content team,
  • marketing and sales team,
  • GM/revenue management in hotels (summary KPI section),
  • SMM lead on the agency side.

items.q: How is the content calendar fed with analysis & reporting?
items.a: High-performing categories and formats receive more coverage in the following month's content calendar; Weak content types are improved or replaced by new test topics.

items.q: How is social media performance measured?
items.a: Performance; It is measured not only by the number of followers, but also by looking at reach, interaction rate, saving/sharing, clicks, DM/WhatsApp and conversion metrics together. It is also important to compare the trend of these metrics over time and benchmarks.

items.q: What should be done if interaction decreases while access increases?
items.a:
• reaching a larger but less interested audience means
  • while the content is visible, it does not connect enough
. It is necessary to review target audience settings, topic/message selection and call-to-action use.

items.q: What are the 3 most critical metrics when interpreting reels performance?
items.a:
• watch time / completion rate,
  • saving and sharing,
  • following profile and link clicks.

items.q: How does a monthly social media report guide content & advertising strategy?
items.a:
• well-performing content & creatives → scale on the ad side,
  • well-performing audiences & markets → become new campaign focus,
  • weak-performing areas → flagged for optimization or discontinuation.

items.q: How to detect “budget/outcome imbalance” at the report level?
items.a: Advertising and production costs; The traffic brought in by relevant content and campaigns is juxtaposed with lead and sales/booking data. Content that is high-cost but produces low results becomes a candidate for new format and approach tests for the next period.

section6.title: Questions Focusing on Core Issues

items.q: Reports are prepared but no one reads them; From where?
items.a:
• Reports that are too long,
  • too technical,
  • unclear about what they tell anyone,
  • that do not suggest action
over time are not opened by anyone. Report; It should be in the format of short summary + clear KPI + comment + action.

items.q: What happens when the right KPI is not set?
items.a: When success is interpreted only in terms of the number of followers or only reach, metrics that have little relevance to the business goal come to the fore. This causes budget and team time to be wasted on the wrong work.

items.q: How to misinterpret across content types?
items.a: Since Reels is strong in reach, it is common mistakes to look only at reach and attribute the entire strategy to Reels, or to see stories as worthless because they naturally receive low likes/comments. Each format should be evaluated within its own role and KPIs.

items.q: How does a budget/outcome imbalance arise?
items.a:
• very high production but small or wrong target audience,
  • advertising budget being allocated only to the top funnel,
  • no remarketing,
  • reports not being included in the process.

items.q: What do social media studies without analysis turn into?
items.a: It becomes a “content graveyard” that is visually beautiful but produces no business value; Only content and budget are spent without knowing what works.

items.q: How should social media performance be interpreted in tourism regions (Antalya, Belek, Kemer, Side, Bodrum, etc.)?
items.a:
• pre/mid/post-season access and interaction trends,
  • country-based performance (DE, UK, RU, TR),
  • social contribution during campaign periods (organic + paid),
  • performance of destination content
should be examined separately.

items.q: For which content categories should separate KPIs be kept in hotels?
items.a:
• room & facility,
  • destination,
  • campaign,
  • guest experience,
  • gastronomy.
Access-interaction-click KPIs should be followed separately for each category.

items.q: What stands out in social media analysis for lifestyle brands?
items.a:
• community indicators (save, share, DM, mention),
  • Performance of UGC and influencer content,
  • social impact of collection/product launches.

items.q: How should social media analysis be structured in corporate/B2B accounts?
items.a:
• LinkedIn interactions,
  • web traffic and lead form filling,
  • brand awareness (impression, follower quality),
  • contribution to event/webinar participation.

items.q: What KPIs are critical for local businesses (restaurant, clinic, etc.)?
items.a:
• location targeted reach,
  • DM/WhatsApp/phone clicks,
  • Contribution to Google Maps & web clicks,
  • comment and check-in/connection with UGC content.

section8.title: Mini Social Media Analysis & Reporting FAQ

items.q: Why is it wrong to just look at the number of followers?
items.a: 5,000 active and engaged followers are much more valuable than 50,000 passive followers.

items.q: Do I need to look at reports every day?
items.a: No for detailed report; Daily short control and weekly-monthly deep analysis are healthier.

items.q: Is “average engagement rate” alone sufficient?
items.a: No; The average interaction rate without taking into account format and audience differences can be misleading.

items.q: Should I read Reels and TikTok performance with the same eye?
items.a: No; Although the infrastructure is similar, the platform and audience dynamics are different. The same video may yield different results on two platforms.

items.q: Should I keep the report in Excel or dashboard?
items.a: Dashboard should be used for routine monitoring and Excel should be used for special analysis and scenarios.

items.q: Should the social media report only go to the SMM expert?
items.a: No; A summary should be conveyed to the management, details should be conveyed to the SMM team, and content-based inferences should be conveyed to the creative team.

items.q: Is it right to change the KPI target every month?
items.a: No; KPIs should be tested for at least 3 months and then revised according to the data.

items.q: Should social media analysis be read together with SEO and advertising reports?
items.a: Yes; The social → site traffic → conversion chain makes sense when read together with SEO and advertising data.

items.q: Is it enough to update the report format once a year?
items.a: If there are platform and target changes, it is better to make slight revisions every 3–6 months.

items.q: Can I get the SMM Analysis & Reporting service once?
items.a: Yes; After an installation that includes account analysis, KPI set, dashboard design and sample report, the internal team can continue regular follow-up.
