intro.p1:
Website development; It is not just about making a “nice design”, it is the process of establishing a fast, secure, SEO-friendly and easily manageable infrastructure that carries the entire digital presence of your brand. Especially on the hotel and tourism side; Your website is both the first impression and the final decision point in the eyes of the guest. This FAQ page; It collects the most frequently asked questions on topics such as corporate site architecture, hotel web design, reservation infrastructure integration, performance (Core Web Vitals), security and manageability. Our aim is for both hotels and corporate brands to:
  • To give clear and applicable answers to questions such as “What should I pay attention to when building a new site?”
  • “How do I modernize the existing slow site?”
  • “What do modern infrastructures such as Next.

aiCapsule.title: Brief Summary (Overview)
aiCapsule.text: Website development; Beyond design, it is the process of establishing a fast, secure, SEO-friendly and easily manageable digital infrastructure for your brand. On the hotel and tourism side, the site; It creates the guest's first impression and directly affects the booking decision. This FAQ; It offers an applicable framework on critical topics such as correct site architecture, SEO/speed contribution of modern infrastructures such as Next.js, reservation/PMS integration, Core Web Vitals (Basic Web Performance Metrics) focused performance approach, and post-release maintenance-support.

voiceSummary.title: Brief Summary
voiceSummary.text: Website Development FAQ; It explains how to establish the right architecture on corporate and hotel sites, gain speed and SEO advantages with modern infrastructures, seamlessly design reservation/PMS integration, and post-publication maintenance and performance management.

voiceQueries.title: Sample Queries
voiceQueries.q1: “What are the 5 most important criteria when building a hotel website?”
voiceQueries.q2: “Is Next.js good for website SEO?”
voiceQueries.q3: “How to improve Core Web Vitals (LCP, CLS, INP)?”
voiceQueries.q4: “How can reservation engine / PMS integration be done in the best way?”
voiceQueries.q5: “How do I modernize my existing slow website without breaking it?”

items.q: What exactly is website development?
items.a: Website development; It is an end-to-end process that brings together design, frontend, backend, content management system (CMS), integrations (reservation, CRM, payment, etc.), speed and security layers and creates the brand's digital showcase. So it's not just "choosing a theme"; is to establish the right architecture and build infrastructure suitable for long-term growth.

items.q: How should the corporate website be?
items.a:
A healthy corporate website should be:
  • fast and mobile compatible,
  • with a clear information architecture,
  • reflecting the tone and visual identity of the brand,
  • SEO and analytics infrastructure properly established,
  • supported by an easily manageable CMS
. Within 3-5 seconds, the user asks "what do you do, who do you appeal to, how can I reach you?" should be able to find answers to their questions.

items.q: What should be taken into consideration in hotel website development?
items.a:
• Performance: pages that open quickly despite high-dimensional visuals,
  • Reservation: clear, step-by-step, reliable reservation flow,
  • Multilingual structure: language options suitable for main markets,
  • Mobile experience: trouble-free use on phones and tablets,
  • Content: room/concept, destination, reviews and Proper construction of campaigns.
The hotel website should not only be "informative" but also one of the strongest sales channels of the hotel.

items.q: Why should project-specific web development be preferred instead of ready-made templates?
items.a:
Although ready-made themes may seem like a quick solution in the short term:
  • they may be weak on the performance (CWV) side,
  • they become bloated with unnecessary code and plugins,
  • security and maintenance costs increase,
  • they do not offer flexibility in reservations/custom integrations.
Project-specific or modern framework + headless CMS solutions; It provides a faster, safer, more flexible structure in the long run.

items.q: How do modern infrastructures (Next.js, React, Headless CMS) affect SEO?
items.a:
When designed correctly, it provides:
  • fast and SEO-friendly pages with server-side rendering (SSR) or static generation,
  • improvement in Core Web Vitals (LCP, CLS, INP) metrics,
  • cleaner URL and meta management,
  • flexibility in multilingual and multi-site structures
. In other words, a correctly installed Next.js/React infrastructure can create a great advantage on the SEO side compared to classical “heavy WordPress” systems.

items.q: What is the relationship between website development and SEO and advertising results?
items.a:
Weak infrastructure = wasted SEO and advertising budget.
  • slow site → the user exits even if they come from the advertisement,
  • complex structure → the user cannot find what he is looking for,
  • bad CWV → SEO rankings decrease,
  • wrong tracking → it is not visible which campaign is running.
Healthy web development is the “ground” of all digital marketing activities.

items.q: What exactly is website development?
items.a: It is the process of establishing a modern, fast and manageable web infrastructure for your brand by bringing together design, code, CMS, speed, security and integration layers.

items.q: Where should I start with the new website for my hotel?
items.a: You should first clarify your target markets, concept, reservation infrastructure and content needs and start with the appropriate architectural & technology decision.

items.q: How do modern infrastructures like Next.js affect SEO?
items.a: When designed correctly, it produces fast-loading, SEO-friendly pages that are advantageous in Core Web Vitals (Basic Web Performance Metrics); This positively affects organic performance.

items.q: How do I integrate the reservation module into the site?
items.a: API / widget-based integration is planned with the reservation infrastructure or PMS you use; On the design and UX side, this module is placed on the site in a natural flow.

items.q: Why is mobile compatibility so critical?
items.a: Because most users access the site from mobile devices; Google also takes mobile experience into account in both SEO and ad quality scores.

items.q: Who is website development suitable for?
items.a: It is suitable for hotels, tourism brands, corporate companies and other growth-oriented brands that want to build a new site or make their existing site modern, fast and SEO compatible.

section3.title: Service Scope: Corporate Site Architecture, Hotel Web Design, Performance Oriented Development

items.q: What does your Website Development service include?
items.a:
• needs and target analysis,
  • information architecture and UX design,
  • UI design (brand-specific interface),
  • frontend & backend development,
  • CMS (e.g. headless or classic) installation,
  • reservation and third-party integrations,
  • speed and security optimization,
  • testing, go-live and basic training.

items.q: How do you design the corporate site architecture?
items.a:
We establish a structure that supports user flow (funnel) around
  • identity and story pages (about us, vision, team, etc.),
  • product/service pages,
  • references and case studies,
  • blog/FAQ and content areas,
  • communication and offer/application forms
.

items.q: What extra do you bring for hotel web design?
items.a:
• room & concept pages,
  • package & campaign areas,
  • destination and environment guides,
  • reservation flow and PMS/OTA integrations,
  • multilingual content and currency support,
  • galleries and video areas.
The aim is for the site to be a structure that both inspires and closes sales.

items.q: What does performance (speed & CWV) focused development mean?
items.a:
• light and clean frontend code,
  • correct image optimization (lazy load, WebP, etc.),
  • cache/CDN configuration,
  • Optimization according to Core Web Vitals (LCP, CLS, INP) metrics,
  • unnecessary script and plugin cleaning.
In short, not “beautiful but heavy”, but nice and fast. We are aiming for a site.

items.q: What do you take into consideration on the security side?
items.a:
• HTTPS/SSL obligation,
  • secure form and user data processing,
  • use of current framework and packages,
  • admin panel access restrictions,
  • regular backup and logging practices.

items.q: How is the decision made when choosing a CMS (WordPress, headless, custom development)?
items.a:
Depending on factors such as
  • needs of your content team,
  • multilingual structure requirement,
  • integration needs,
  • performance expectation
, a classic CMS or headless solution or a completely custom structure is recommended. There is no “single truth”; There is the right one to suit your needs.

items.q: What steps does your new website development process consist of?
items.a:
• Analysis & discovery meeting,
  • information architecture and UX wireframe study,
  • UI design (approval and revision),
  • frontend & backend development,
  • Installation of CMS and integrations,
  • content entries (customer + agency collaboration),
  • testing and improvement,
  • go-live and training,
  • maintenance & support. (optional).

items.q: How is the process of “refreshing” the current site progressing?
items.a:
• technical and UX audit of the current site,
  • identification of areas to be protected and improved,
  • transportation of URL and SEO architecture to the new structure,
  • design/development + redirect plans,
  • broken link and tracking checks during the go-live.
The aim is not to "reset", but to protect the strong sides and improve the weak sides.

items.q: How should a multilingual website be planned?
items.a:
• target markets and languages ​​are clarified,
  • URL structure (subfolder, subdomain, etc.) is determined,
  • language switcher UX is designed,
  • content production/translation process is planned,
  • hreflang and technical SEO settings are made.
Core language sets such as TR–EN–DE–RU are frequently used in hotels and tourism.

items.q: How do you integrate the reservation infrastructure into the site?
items.a:
An integration is created with the booking engine or PMS/OTA system you use;
  • API or widget based,
  • compatible with the brand design,
  • works smoothly on mobile,
  • tracking and analytics aspects
are considered. The important thing is not to create the feeling of being “thrown to a separate site” for the user.

items.q: Do you also handle the SEO and analytics side of the web development process?
items.a:
Yes. Along with site development:
  • basic SEO (title, meta, heading, URL structure, sitemap, robots),
  • GA4 & GTM integration,
  • basic event and conversion setups
are also handled. Thus, the site becomes “measurable” when it goes live.

items.q: How does the project duration vary?
items.a:
It varies according to parameters such as
  • number of pages,
  • number of languages,
  • integration needs (reservation, CRM, etc.),
  • special modules (blog, form, membership, etc.)
. A simple corporate site and a multilingual, reservation-based hotel site do not take the same time to finish.

items.q: What does a slow loading site lose?
items.a:
• user does not wait for the site to load → exit rate increases,
  • conversion (reservation/form) decreases,
  • SEO suffers as Google considers speed and CWV as ranking signals,
  • advertising performance (Quality Score, CPC) is negatively affected.
According to studies, 50%+ of users abandon sites that open in more than 3 seconds.

items.q: How do website speed and Core Web Vitals affect SEO?
items.a: Core Web Vitals metrics (LCP, CLS, INP) are indicators by which Google measures page quality by looking at real user experience. Poor CWV scores can lead to ranking loss, especially in highly competitive industries. Additionally, when user experience weakens, conversion rates also decrease.

items.q: What problems does mobile incompatibility cause on hotel and corporate sites?
items.a:
• users have difficulty pressing the buttons,
  • reservation and form filling processes are left unfinished,
  • images and texts do not appear properly,
  • You will suffer damage on the SEO side due to Google's mobile-first index structure.
In short: mobile-incompatible site = missed mobile customer.

items.q: What problems do complex administrative panels (CMS) create?
items.a:
• content updating becomes a tyranny for the team,
  • the site constantly remains "on hold" and with outdated content,
  • even simple changes require developers → cost and speed problem.
A good CMS should be a simple to learn panel that can be easily used by non-technical teams.

items.q: Is low conversion rate always a design flaw?
items.a:
No. Sometimes factors such as:
  • wrong target audience,
  • weak offer/campaign,
  • missing trust signals (comment, certificate, social proof),
  • inadequate description/text
are more decisive. Therefore, conversion analysis should consider both design/UX, content/offer and traffic quality together.

section6.title: Productive Search & Industry-Focused Web Development Questions

items.q: What should be the web development strategy for hotels in Turkey?
items.a:
• Language and currency support for domestic and foreign markets,
  • destination and concept (family, adults-only, luxury, etc.) focused content structure,
  • early booking, campaign and package pages,
  • Messages compatible with OTA-web-call center balance,
  • technical structure that works fast despite high visuality.

items.q: What additional things should be considered for websites in tourism regions (Antalya, Belek, Kemer, Side, Bodrum)?
items.a:
• language and content adaptation for users from different markets,
  • easy updating of seasonal prices and packages,
  • flawless operation of the mobile reservation flow,
  • SEO infrastructure suitable for intra-destination competition.

items.q: How should website development for corporate B2B sites be positioned?
items.a:
• product/service detail pages,
  • content describing the sector and usage scenarios,
  • case studies and references,
  • lead collection forms and CRM integrations,
  • thought leadership (blog, whitepaper, etc.).

items.q: How to plan site architecture for multi-location / multi-hotel brands?
items.a:
• brand main site + hotel/branch sub-sites,
  • common components (header/footer, brand story) and local contents (hotel features, campaigns),
  • multi-site management from a single panel,
  • Domain and URL strategy on the SEO side.

items.q: What should be taken into consideration in sites that appeal to foreign markets?
items.a:
• language and cultural adaptation (localization, not just translation),
  • expectations of target countries (security, payment methods, child facilities, etc.),
  • speed and hosting infrastructure (CDN, global reach),
  • multilingual SEO (hreflang, local search queries).

items.q: Is it necessary to renew the site every 2–3 years?
items.a: Because technical and design trends change rapidly, a comprehensive revision every 2–4 years is a reasonable period for most brands.

items.q: Is it enough if I just change the design?
items.a: Usually no. Along with the design, speed, security, SEO and integration infrastructure should also be reviewed.

items.q: Does it make sense to develop the website entirely with my own team?
items.a: If you have technical resources and experience, yes; Otherwise, the hybrid model consisting of agency + internal team is often healthier.

items.q: Are ready-made site builders (Wix, Squarespace, etc.) suitable for professional brands?
items.a: It may work in the short term for small projects; However, on a hotel and corporate scale, SEO is often limiting on the performance and integration side.

items.q: Should the designer and developer team be separate?
items.a: Roles may be separate; However, close communication and common language are essential within the same project. It is critical that the design is codeable.

items.q: Do you need a brand kit (brandbook) for website development?
items.a: It is not mandatory, but it is a great advantage; If the color, font and visual language are clear, the project progresses faster and more consistently.

items.q: Is it necessary to receive maintenance/support after the site is published?
items.a: Yes. A maintenance model is required for security updates, minor enhancements, and integration changes.

items.q: Is it right to think of website development cost as just design and code?
items.a: No. Content production, photo/video, SEO, analytics integration, and maintenance/support are also part of the total cost.

items.q: Is it right to launch the site without Analytics / GA4 installation?
items.a: It is technically possible but not recommended; It is difficult to optimize a site that you cannot measure.

items.q: Can I receive Website Development service only as analysis + architectural suggestion?
items.a: Yes. You can purchase a consultancy package that includes analysis, architectural recommendations and technology stack recommendations and implement the application with your own team.

intro.p1:
CMS (Content Management System) integration; It is a panel + infrastructure + integration combination designed to enable you to manage the content side of your website "without opening a ticket to IT". A poorly built CMS can render even a great design and strong infrastructure “unusable”; A well-designed CMS makes the content team fast, free and secure for both hotel and corporate brands.

This FAQ page; Answers the most frequently asked questions about WordPress, headless/custom CMS, multilingual content management, user authorization, PMS/booking integrations and security.

aiCapsule.title: Brief Summary (Overview)
aiCapsule.text: CMS integration; It is a combination of panel + content model + integration + authorization so that the marketing team can manage the content management of your website (content such as pages, blog, campaign, room/package) without being dependent on IT. Correct fiction; Ensures regular management of multilingual content, role/authority, approval flow and SEO fields; The wrong setup makes every change dependent on the developer and makes the site "untouchable". This page; WordPress focuses on practical topics such as headless/custom CMS options, multilingual structure, reservation/PMS and CRM integrations, and security-performance balance.

voiceSummary.title: Brief Summary
voiceSummary.text: CMS Integration FAQ; It explains how to make multilingual content, role/authority and approval flows, integrations (PMS/CRM) and SEO areas easily manageable by connecting panels such as WordPress or headless CMS to your website securely and efficiently.

voiceQueries.title: Sample Queries
voiceQueries.q1: “What is CMS integration and why is it needed?”
voiceQueries.q2: “WordPress or headless CMS, which should I choose?”
voiceQueries.q3: “How do I set up multilingual content management in CMS?”
voiceQueries.q4: “How should I set roles and authorities in the CMS panel?”
voiceQueries.q5: “How do I manage campaign/room/package content on my hotel site with CMS?”

items.q: What exactly is CMS integration?
items.a: CMS integration; It is the job of building a solid, secure and user-friendly bridge between your site design and code and your content management panel (WordPress, headless CMS or custom panel). The aim is to help marketing and content teams without the need for technical knowledge; page, blog, campaign, room/product, menu, etc. It is easy to manage content.

items.q: What is CMS and what does it do?
items.a: CMS (Content Management System); It is a system that allows you to manage your content (text, visual, video, menu, news, campaign, etc.) through a panel. Without dealing with code; It allows you to perform operations such as opening a new page, updating an existing one, adding languages, changing images, etc. much faster and safer.

items.q: WordPress, custom CMS or headless CMS? How to decide?
items.a:
There is no “one truth”; The right CMS is chosen according to the need:
  • WordPress → fast installation, wide plug-in ecosystem, classic panel experience,
  • Custom CMS → completely designed according to the need, lighter and more controlled structures,
  • Headless CMS → talking via API with modern frontend (such as Next.js), very Ideal for multilingual/multi-site and performance-oriented projects.
Scale is decided according to team structure, integration and performance needs.

items.q: What is the difference between “Headless CMS” and “classic CMS”?
items.a:
• Classic CMS: panel + frontend in the same system (like WordPress),
  • Headless CMS: content panel is separate, frontend (site) is separate; In the meantime, they talk to the API.
Headless; It offers great flexibility and speed advantages, especially in multilingual, multi-site and performance-oriented structures.

items.q: Why does the site become unusable if CMS integration is not done correctly?
items.a:
Because a poorly designed panel causes:
  • not knowing what content has changed and from where,
  • fear of breaking wrong pages,
  • content team saying "it's hard, let's not touch it",
  • waiting for developers for every change
. This means that the project "freezes" shortly after it goes live.

items.q: Why is CMS integration critical for hotel and corporate sites?
items.a:
On the hotel and corporate side:
  • campaigns change frequently,
  • prices, rooms/products, packages and contents are updated,
  • multi-language and multi-market management.
Making all of these dependent on IT would be both slow and costly. A good CMS integration puts content and sales teams at ease.

items.q: What is CMS integration, what does it do?
items.a: It is a structure that combines the design and code sides of your website in a safe and high-performance way with a content management panel that non-technical teams can easily use.

items.q: What should I pay attention to when setting up a content panel for my hotel?
items.a: You should ensure that the number of languages, rooms/concepts, campaigns and reservation contents are easily manageable on the panel and that the panel can be used without being dependent on IT.

items.q: How does multilingual content management work in CMS?
items.a: It works with a simple structure where language variants for each content can be managed from a single panel and does not disrupt the language-URL-hreflang relationship.

items.q: Can I also manage reservation contents from the panel?
items.a: In correctly designed CMS integration; Campaigns, packages and "reservation-related text/images" can be managed from the panel and integrated with the reservation engine/PMS.

items.q: How to ensure the security of CMS?
items.a: With current versions, security patches, role/authority model, 2FA, IP/access restrictions and regular backups.

items.q: Who is CMS integration suitable for?
items.a: It's not just a "static promotion" site; It is especially suitable for hotel, tourism and corporate brands that need content, campaigns, multi-language and integration.

section3.title: CMS Integration Service Scope

items.q: What does your CMS Integration service include?
items.a:
• analysis of the current site and content structure,
  • CMS selection (WordPress, headless, custom CMS),
  • definition of content types (page, room, package, blog, faq, etc.),
  • multilingual panel setup,
  • user role/authority model design,
  • Integration with PMS/reservation and other systems,
  • training and documentation.

items.q: What do you standardize in WordPress integration?
items.a:
• custom post type and field setups,
  • light and secure solutions in theme and plugin selection,
  • multilingual structure (scenarios such as WPML/Polylang/Multisite etc.),
  • role and authority sets,
  • performance (cache, image optimization) and security settings.

items.q: How does the panel work in a headless CMS scenario?
items.a: Contents; It is stored on the panel via API, the site (Next.js/React etc.) pulls these contents via API. In the panel, content is managed in page, block and component logic; On the frontend side, these components are created dynamically. This provides great flexibility, especially in multilingual and multi-site structures.

items.q: How should content types (room, package, blog, etc.) be modeled in the panel?
items.a: It is necessary to define custom fields suitable for each content type. For example, for the room: room name, description, images, season/price information, features; for the package: date range, price, services included, etc. In this way, the content team manages content through a standard form without dealing with code or HTML.

items.q: How do you configure user roles and privileges in CMS?
items.a:
• full administrator (admin),
  • editor (able to approve content),
  • writer (able to create and offer content),
  • limited role (only seeing certain areas)
are defined as needed; At the hotel, we make the dashboard safe and organized with department-based access models (marketing, reservations, IT, etc.).

items.q: Can PMS/reservation systems be integrated into CMS?
items.a: Yes. Depending on the APIs offered by PMS and reservation systems; Room types, prices and occupancy information can be reflected on the CMS side, or campaign and package contents can be managed via CMS. The detail is planned according to the technical possibilities of the system used.

items.q: What do you analyze before starting a CMS integration project?
items.a:
• existing site and content types,
  • panel expectations of content and marketing teams,
  • multi-language/multi-site need,
  • integration requirements (PMS, CRM, e-mail, form, etc.),
  • current security and performance issues.

items.q: What should an ideal CMS panel look like for the content team?
items.a:
• it is clear which content has changed from where,
  • the page and block structure is understandable,
  • it does not contain too many technical terms,
  • the content can be updated without damaging the design,
  • it makes it difficult to make mistakes (e.g., it gives warnings in important areas).

items.q: How do you build a multilingual CMS structure?
items.a:
• we add language fields to each content type,
  • we simplify the language adding/updating flow on the panel,
  • we plan content management without breaking the language-URL-hreflang relationship.
For example: TR, EN, DE, RU versions of the same room content can be seen side by side on the panel.

items.q: How are content approval processes (workflow) designed in CMS?
items.a:
According to the need, flows are designed as:
  • author → editor → publication,
  • author → department approval (e.g. legal/quality) → publication,
. Thus, important pages (campaign, KVKK, contract, etc.) will not go live without being checked.

items.q: How is content migration (moving from the old site to the new CMS) managed?
items.a:
• existing content types are mapped,
  • old data (pages, blogs, rooms/products, etc.) are exported,
  • mappers suitable for the new CMS structure are written,
  • data is moved with automatic + manual controls.
Manual QA (especially for multilingual content) is definitely done for important pages.

items.q: What extra fields should be in the CMS panel for hotel and tourism sites?
items.a:
• room/concept management,
  • campaign and package management,
  • season texts and date parameters,
  • destination and environmental contents,
  • galleries and video embed areas,
  • multilingual menu and footer management.

items.q: How do hard-to-use panels disrupt workflow?
items.a:
• pages that are not updated,
  • incorrect content (pages in the wrong language/data),
  • the content team's constant dependence on IT,
  • doing nothing for fear of "not breaking the site."
Result: a good infrastructure loses its value because it is not used.

items.q: How to ensure the security of CMS?
items.a:
• use of current version and plugins,
  • avoiding unnecessary plugins,
  • strong password and 2FA,
  • correct setup of role/authority model,
  • IP or VPN based access for admin panel,
  • regular backup and logging.
Security best practices are critical, especially in common systems such as WordPress.

items.q: How does CMS performance affect site speed?
items.a: Excessive use of plugins, poorly written themes and queries, unnecessary database load and lack of cache disrupt both backend and frontend performance. This means damage to user experience, CWV and SEO. Lightweight theme, minimal plugins and the right cache strategy are the key elements in CMS performance.

items.q: What causes integration problems (PMS, CRM, etc.)?
items.a:
• incorrect price/occupancy display,
  • missing/incorrect recording of reservation and lead data,
  • Disconnection on the CRM and marketing automation side,
  • difficulty in reporting and optimization.
Therefore, integrations should not only be tested for “showing” but also for data accuracy and continuity.

items.q: Does incorrectly designed CMS structure affect SEO?
items.a: Yes. Inappropriate URL structures, wrong language/URL matches, canonical and hreflang errors, automatically generated garbage pages, and misconfigured sitemaps directly affect SEO. CMS integration should be considered together with SEO.

section6.title: Productive Search & Industry-Focused CMS Questions

items.q: What should the CMS structure be like for hotels in Turkey?
items.a:
• Multilingual content management for TR + EN + other market languages,
  • management of room/package/campaign contents from a single panel,
  • quick updating of seasonal and promotional texts,
  • structures ready for reservation and PMS integration.

items.q: How should CMS integration be designed for corporate B2B sites?
items.a:
Separate content types and flows should be defined for
  • product/service pages,
  • case study and references,
  • blog/whitepaper and content marketing areas,
  • lead form and CRM integrations
.

items.q: How to scale CMS for multi-branch/multi-hotel brands?
items.a:
• multi-site/hotel management from a single panel (multi-site/multi-tenant),
  • common components (header/footer, brand pages),
  • local content and language management of each hotel,
  • role-based authority (each hotel's own content editors, etc.).

items.q: How should destination and region contents be managed in CMS?
items.a:
• separate content types for the destination,
  • content areas that can be associated with the hotel/branch,
  • multilingual metadata and SEO areas,
  • internal link construction with relevant blog/guide content.

items.q: What are the critical points of CMS integration on sites aimed at foreign markets?
items.a:
• multilingual and multi-currency content management,
  • panel access and role management to local market teams,
  • management of different banner/campaign areas for different countries,
  • local SEO and content tagging (language/region) support.

items.q: Do I have to know technical knowledge to use CMS?
items.a: In a well-designed CMS, no; Someone who can use basic office and digital tools can easily add and update content.

items.q: Is it right to use WordPress in every project?
items.a: Not always; Depending on scale, performance and integration needs, headless or custom CMS solutions may be more appropriate.

items.q: Will I lose all content when switching CMS?
items.a: No, if a correct migration plan is made; Contents can be moved by mapping to the new CMS structure.

items.q: Is it good to see a lot of space on the panel?
items.a: Usually no. Unnecessary field crowding increases the risk of errors; The simple and purposeful panel structure is healthier.

items.q: Is it dangerous to skip CMS updates?
items.a: Yes. If security and performance patches are missed, the risk of attack and incompatibility increases.

items.q: Does it make sense to give admin rights to all team members?
items.a: No. Role-based authorization (admin, editor, writer, etc.) is essential for both security and order.

items.q: Is it good to be able to change everything from the panel?
items.a: Not always. Unrestricted freedom in design-critical areas increases the risk of breaking the site; It is better for some areas to be protected.

items.q: Does CMS's impact on performance only affect the backend?
items.a: No. Images, scripts, plug-ins and queries added from the panel directly affect frontend performance.

items.q: Do I have to finish the CMS integration project in one go?
items.a: No. It is generally safer and more economical to start with MVP (minimum usable panel) and add modules over time.

items.q: Can I get CMS Integration service only at the analysis + design level?
items.a: Yes. You can get consultancy including panel design, content types, role/authority model and integration scheme and implement the application with your own team.

KVKK compliance is not just about "publishing a single cookie text and information letter" on the site. Especially on the hotel and tourism side; As guest data flows between PMS, OTA, website, call center, e-mail and even social media messages, it becomes very critical where, by whom, for how long and for what purpose this data is processed. This FAQ page; It collects the most frequently asked questions about the KVKK Compliance Service from a technical and operational perspective:
  • What does KVKK compliant web & software infrastructure mean?
  • How should cookie management and permission screens be designed?
  • How should data flow be controlled between PMS, OTA, web, call center and CRM?
  • How should logging, storage periods and access controls be designed?

generalQuestions.title: Overview of KVKK Compliant Web & Software Infrastructure

items.q: What exactly is KVKK compliant web & software infrastructure?
items.a:
An infrastructure compliant with KVKK; It is a technical and organizational structure where personal data is
  • for legitimate and explicit purposes,
  • according to the data minimization principle (without collecting more than necessary),
  • stored securely,
  • recorded in terms of the process and responsible parties,
  • protected against unauthorized access,
  • deletion/anonymization and access rights can be managed
. This structure; It covers all data processing channels such as your website, PMS–OTA–CRM systems, call center and e-mail.

items.q: What does a KVKK compliant website mean?
items.a:
A KVKK compliant website
  • informs the user when using cookie and tracking technologies and obtains consent when necessary,
  • clearly states what data it collects and why in contact and reservation forms,
  • does not collect unnecessary personal data,
  • transfers data in an encrypted and secure manner (HTTPS/SSL),
  • defines logging and storage periods,
  • user rights (access, deletion, correction). It has processes that can meet the needs.

items.q: Is the KVKK compliance process just writing legal texts?
items.a:
No. Clarification texts and policies are the visible face; In the background, there is
  • data processing inventory,
  • access authorizations,
  • logging,
  • storage and destruction processes,
  • cookie and pixel configuration,
  • system architecture in accordance with KVKK
. Texts and technical infrastructure should be considered together.

items.q: Are KVKK and GDPR the same thing?
items.a: No. Although they have similar principles, KVKK is a regulation specific to Turkey. It differs from the GDPR in terms of definitions, processes and sanctions. Businesses operating in Turkey should take the KVKK as a basis, and if necessary, they should also take the GDPR into consideration for overseas activities.

items.q: Why is the hotel & tourism sector risky in terms of KVKK?
items.a:
Because hotels process intense and sensitive personal data such as
  • identity and passport information,
  • contact data,
  • payment information,
  • health and special request information,
  • camera records,
  • OTA and agency-sourced data
. This means high liability and audit risk within the scope of KVKK.

items.q: Is KVKK compliance the responsibility of the IT team or the legal team?
items.a: It is the responsibility of both. The legal side defines what needs to be done; IT and operations teams implement how this will be implemented. A healthy KVKK compliance process requires legal + IT + operations teams to work together.

items.q: What is KVKK compatible web & software infrastructure?
items.a: It is a set of recorded technical and organizational systems that ensure the collection, storage, sharing and deletion of personal data in accordance with KVKK.

items.q: How should I store guest data in my hotel in accordance with KVKK?
items.a: You should store data only in necessary systems, with authorized users, in an encrypted and access-logged format, in accordance with legal retention periods.

items.q: How should cookie management and permission screens be structured?
items.a: Mandatory cookies, measurement and marketing cookies separately; with a structure that allows the user to accept or reject these groups individually.

items.q: How should PMS, OTA and call center data be managed in terms of KVKK?
items.a: Which system processes which data, for what purpose and for how long should be defined in the data inventory; Secure connection and authorization checks must be ensured.

items.q: What should I be technically prepared for if a KVKK audit comes?
items.a: Data inventory, access logs, storage and destruction records, and cookie and user consent logs must be organized and auditable.

items.q: Who is KVKK Compliance Service suitable for?
items.a: It is suitable for all hotels that process guest or customer data, tourism businesses, call centers, corporate brands and all companies that want to update their web & software infrastructure.

section3.title: KVKK Compliance Service: Scope of Service

items.q: What does the KVKK Compliance Service technically cover?
items.a:
• technical support for the preparation of data processing inventory,
  • KVKK risk analyzes on web & software,
  • cookie management tool installation and configuration,
  • technical setups for logging and storage periods,
  • PMS-OTA-web-call center data flow mapping,
  • Creation of forms and permission setups compatible with KVKK,
  • technical documentation for audit (system scheme, log policies, etc.).
(Final approval of legal texts always belongs to the legal expert.)

items.q: How is the data processing inventory prepared on the technical side?
items.a:
• in which system (PMS, web, CRM, OTA, call center, etc.),
  • which data type (identity, communication, health, finance, etc.),
  • for which purpose,
  • by whom and for how long
it is processed is presented in a table. The IT side carries the actual operation of the systems and log/storage practices into this inventory.

items.q: Why is the harmony between lighting texts and technical flow important?
items.a:
The data processing purpose, systems and storage periods specified in the texts must match the actual application exactly. Otherwise,
  • keeping more data in the system than stated in the text,
  • longer retention periods,
  • uncertain data flows
poses a serious risk in terms of KVKK.

items.q: How to make cookie management compliant with KVKK?
items.a:
• cookie and pixel inventory is created (domain, purpose, duration),
  • categories such as mandatory/measurement/marketing are defined,
  • a cookie banner/panel that provides category-based permission to the user is established,
  • user choices are logged and stored in a verifiable manner.

items.q: How should hotel PMS and OTA data be protected within the scope of KVKK?
items.a:
• user access should be limited by the role & authority model,
  • access and transactions should be logged,
  • storage & destruction policies should be applied for data kept for longer than necessary,
  • The systems to which data from OTA is transferred should be recorded.

items.q: What are KVKK technical measures?
items.a:
• access control (authorization, password policies, 2FA),
  • network and application security (firewall, WAF, SSL),
  • logging,
  • backup,
  • data masking and anonymization,
  • secure deletion/destruction,
  • regular vulnerability scans.

items.q: What analysis is done before starting a KVKK compliant web & software project?
items.a:
• in which channels data is collected (web, PMS, OTA, call center, e-mail, social media),
  • where the data is stored,
  • who has access to which systems,
  • existing disclosure and contract texts,
  • storage and destruction practices
are analyzed. This analysis is the basis of both the legal and technical roadmap.

items.q: What steps does the KVKK Compliance Service include in the technical process?
items.a:
• current situation analysis (inventory + risk),
  • deduction of data flow diagrams,
  • cookie/pixel inventory and management setup,
  • logging & storage/destruction plan,
  • technical part of user permissions and application processes,
  • final control and documentation.

items.q: How is the cookie management tool integration progressing?
items.a:
• the tool to be used (custom or 3rd-party) is determined,
  • all cookies and scripts are scanned and categorized,
  • banner design and texts are structured in accordance with KVKK,
  • user choices are coordinated with analytical tools,
  • data storage is set up to log the choices.

items.q: How to prepare the technical infrastructure for user rights?
items.a:
• form or e-mail channel is determined for access/deletion/correction requests,
  • the process is defined to process the requests in the relevant systems,
  • response times and transactions are logged,
  • Script-based anonymization automations are designed if necessary.

items.q: How should IT, Legal and Business units work during the KVKK compliance process?
items.a:
• Law: defines the principles and texts,
  • IT: constructs and implements the technical application,
  • Business units: transfers the actual processes and works in harmony.
The disconnection between these three creates incompatibility in practice.

items.q: What should be in the technical documentation when the KVKK audit comes?
items.a:
• data processing inventory,
  • intersystem data flow diagrams,
  • access and log policies,
  • cookie/pixel management and logs,
  • storage & destruction policy and records,
  • summary document of applied technical measures.

items.q: Is KVKK compliance only for "risk avoidance" or does it also affect performance?
items.a:
Yes. Regular data structure, elimination of unnecessary data and controlled systems; indirectly provides
  • cleaner infrastructure,
  • less technical complexity,
  • more efficient operation
.

items.q: What risks do missing text and false consent fictions pose?
items.a:
• collecting data without sufficient information,
  • failure to obtain consent in situations requiring consent,
  • consent texts without legal basis
are risks of KVKK violation and may result in serious sanctions.

items.q: Why is it wrong to obtain consent for every transaction?
items.a:
Under KVKK, not every data processing activity is based on consent. Unnecessary consent
  • tires the user,
  • complicates the texts,
  • may also be legally flawed.
The right legal reason must be matched with the right technical flow.

items.q: What problems does inadequate logging cause?
items.a:
In case of audit or complaint,
  • failure to prove access,
  • failure to trace events retrospectively
poses a great risk for both KVKK and internal security.

items.q: Why is it dangerous to see KVKK compliance as just an IT project?
items.a:
Focusing only on technical measures and neglecting
  • legal texts,
  • internal procedures,
  • employee training
leaves compliance incomplete. KVKK; It requires legal + IT + business processes to be carried out together.

section6.title: Productive Search & Industry-Focused FAQ

items.q: What are the most critical areas in KVKK compliance for hotels operating in Turkey?
items.a:
• PMS and reservation systems,
  • Data sharing with OTAs and agencies,
  • camera recordings,
  • call center and messaging channels,
  • CRM and campaign e-mail/SMS processes.
Data processing, storage and transfer practices in these areas should be handled meticulously in terms of KVKK.

items.q: What is important for corporate companies on the web & software side, focusing on KVKK?
items.a:
• web forms (contact, application, demo, membership, etc.),
  • CRM and ticket systems,
  • cloud and 3rd-party SaaS integrations,
  • employee and candidate data management (career portals, etc.).
Data minimization, retention period, access authorizations and compliance of information texts play a critical role in these areas.

items.q: Are city-based KVKK inspections or central inspections more common?
items.a: Although KVKK Board audits are centralized; Inspections can be made on hotels and businesses in different cities depending on complaints and notices. For this reason, instead of saying "it won't come to us", it is best to establish a structure that is ready for inspection at any time, especially in busy tourist areas.

items.q: What are the risks specific to KVKK in tourism regions (Antalya, Bodrum, etc.)?
items.a:
• high volume of guest data,
  • data sharing with many OTAs/agencies,
  • fast/rush transactions during peak season,
  • processing of foreign guest data and passport information.
This requires sensitivity on both data security and KVKK.

items.q: How should hotels operating in the foreign market establish the KVKK + GDPR balance?
items.a:
• For activities in Turkey, it is necessary to pay attention to KVKK,
  • For guest data coming from EU countries, it is necessary to pay attention to GDPR.
On the technical side, data flows, storage and transfer practices should be designed according to the basic principles of both legislation (minimization, transparency, security); However, the final legal position must be determined together with lawyers.

items.q: Does this information replace legal advice?
items.a: No; What is described here is a technical and operational guide, not legal advice. You should always work with your lawyer regarding KVKK.

items.q: Is it against KVKK to use the site without a cookie banner?
items.a: If consent is not obtained for non-essential cookies (measurement, marketing), there is a risk; Your cookie structure should be reviewed with your lawyer.

items.q: Should I keep all data domestically for KVKK compliance?
items.a: Overseas servers and cloud services may be within the scope of "data transfer abroad" within the framework of KVKK; The legal framework must be evaluated together with your lawyer.

items.q: Is KVKK compliance a one-time or a continuous process?
items.a: It is a continuous process; New systems, integrations, campaigns and platform changes require re-evaluation.

items.q: Do I have to obtain consent for each cookie individually?
items.a: Generally, permission management is structured on the basis of categories; Legal opinion should be obtained for details and interpretation.

items.q: Can't I use Google Analytics due to KVKK?
items.a: Its use is not prohibited; However, IP anonymization, retention periods, cookies and international transfer issues must be handled with legal care.

items.q: If I comply with KVKK, will my risk of data breach be reset?
items.a: No; Risk is reduced, but no system is 100% risk-free. The important thing is to take reasonable technical and administrative measures and be prepared to manage the process in case of violation.

items.q: Is the KVKK compliance project too luxurious for small businesses?
items.a: No; Since smaller scale means less data and systems, KVKK compliance can be more manageable and at the same time critical to protecting business reputation.

items.q: How important is employee training in the KVKK compliance process?
items.a: No matter how strong the technical system is, if the personnel accessing the data are not knowledgeable and aware, the risk of breach remains high.

items.q: Can I receive KVKK Compliance Service only as "technical audit + road map"?
items.a: Yes; Audit + recommendation roadmap showing technical risks and needs can be obtained; You can carry out the implementation process together with your internal teams and your lawyer.

items.q: What exactly is server security?
items.a:
Server security; It is the process of designing and managing the infrastructure on which the website, application, database and related services operate in a way that protects it against:
  • unauthorized access,
  • data leaks,
  • service interruptions (DDoS, etc.),
  • malicious code and configuration vulnerabilities
.

items.q: Why is server security critical “especially” for hotel and corporate sites?
items.a:
Because in these structures, the servers contain sensitive information such as:
  • reservation data (guest name, contact, date),
  • payment and billing information,
  • CRM and PMS integrations,
  • employee and supplier data
. A violation poses a serious risk both on the KVKK/GDPR side and on the brand reputation side.

items.q: Are website security and server security the same thing?
items.a:
They partially overlap, but are not the same:
  • Website security → application layer (forms, login screen,

items.q: Can server security be ensured with shared hosting?
items.a:
In shared hosting, the service provider offers some basic security; However, it may not fully meet the security and performance needs at hotel and corporate scale due to:
  • resource sharing,
  • limited access,
  • customization restrictions
. Private server (dedicated) or secure cloud (cloud VM / managed) scenarios are generally healthier.

items.q: Next.js / how does modern web infrastructures affect server security?
items.a:
When used correctly, it can provide:
  • less dynamic surfaces with static generation (SSG),
  • better distributed architecture with edge and CDN layers,
  • more limited and controlled backend points with serverless functions
. However, incorrect configuration (public .env, incorrect public/private separation, faulty build pipeline, etc.) may also bring security risks.

items.q: Is it enough to leave server security only to the hosting company?
items.a:
Not quite. The hosting company:
  • takes some security measures at the infrastructure and network level,
but issues such as:
  • application security,
  • access management,
  • IAM (user and key management),
  • log and monitoring,
  • backup scenario
are often your responsibility.

items.q: What is server security and what does it do?
items.a: Server security; It protects your website, application and database against unauthorized access and attacks, allowing you to provide uninterrupted and secure service.

items.q: How can I make my hotel website more technically secure?
items.a: With an up-to-date infrastructure, SSL/HTTPS, strong password & 2FA, firewall, regular backup, up-to-date software and proper monitoring (logging & logging).

items.q: Is an SSL certificate really essential for SEO and trust?
items.a: Yes; HTTPS is now considered de facto mandatory for both browser security and Google ranking signals.

items.q: How do I protect against DDoS attacks?
items.a: You can become more resilient with CDN-based DDoS protection rate limiting, firewall rules and scalable infrastructure.

items.q: How should backup and logging be on the server side?
items.a: Backup: should be regular, automatic, in different locations and restoration tests should be performed. Logging: A structure should be established to store authorization and data access logs and security logs for reasonable periods of time.

items.q: Who is server security service suitable for?
items.a: Including hotel & tourism, corporate, e-commerce, SaaS products; It is important for every structure that works and processes data via the web and API.

items.q: What is an SSL/TLS certificate and what does it cover?
items.a:
SSL/TLS certificate; It helps ensure:

  • confidentiality,
  • authentication
by encrypting the traffic between the browser and the server. TLS 1.2+ is recommended in modern builds; Weak encryption algorithms and outdated protocols should be disabled.

items.q: How does firewall work?
items.a:
Firewall; It is a filtering layer that controls access from:
  • which IPs,
  • which ports,
  • with which protocol
according to the rules you set. It can be used both at the network level (network FW) and at the application level (WAF). The goal is to allow only necessary traffic.

items.q: Why is it important to use WAF (Web Application Firewall)?
items.a: WAF; Provides an additional layer of protection against common web attacks such as SQL Injection, XSS, brute-force. It does not completely eliminate vulnerabilities on the application side, but it can significantly reduce the risks caused by incorrect/unupdated code or 3rd party plugins.

items.q: How should the backup strategy be designed?
items.a:
• backup frequency (daily, weekly, hourly),
  • how many versions will be stored,
  • in which environment (same server, separate server, cloud) they will be kept,
  • restore tests
should be clearly defined. Saying "There is a backup" and not doing any restoration tests is a huge risk.

items.q: What does the Server Security service mean for Next.js/modern web projects?
items.a:
• Secure construction of hosting & deploy environment (Vercel, Netlify, your own server),
  • Management of environment variables (.env, secrets),
  • Protection of API routes,
  • correct cache/security settings in static/dynamic content distinction,
  • Secure integration with third party services (payment, auth, analytics).

items.q: What do you analyze before starting a server security audit?
items.a:
• which hosting/platform you are using,
  • operating system and versions,
  • which services (web server, db, redis, etc.) are open,
  • access methods (SSH, panel, RDP),
  • existing SSL certificates,
  • backup and logging practices,
  • application and integration structure (PMS, payment, APIs).

items.q: What are the “minimum security hardening” steps?
items.a:
For example:
  • up to date OS & packages,
  • root login disabled (for SSH),
  • key-based authentication / 2FA,
  • closing unnecessary ports and services,
  • simple rate limiting,
  • brute-force protection with fail2ban or similar tools,
  • basic WAF configuration.
Details vary for each system, but these types of steps vary. Increases the “base security” level.

items.q: How is the security approach of Cloud (AWS/Azure/GCP) vs classic hosting different?
items.a:
In cloud environments:
  • security groups,
  • IAM roles,
  • VPC,
  • managed WAF and DDoS services
come to the fore. In classic hosting, the focus is more on panel-based settings and server-level configurations. Cloud is more flexible, but can be riskier if constructed incorrectly (policies with everything left "on", etc.).

items.q: How should access & user management be configured on the server?
items.a:
• person-based accounts (instead of the common “admin”),
  • role-based authorization,
  • “least privilege” principle,
  • access on-off procedure during login/logout processes,
  • 2FA or similar extra verifications for critical accounts.

items.q: How are logging and monitoring positioned in the process?
items.a:
• access logs (web, SSH, panel),
  • error logs (application & server),
  • security event logs (WAF, firewall),
  • uptime and performance monitoring (CPU, RAM, disk, response time)
should be monitored regularly, and alarm/warning mechanisms should be established for critical thresholds.

items.q: What is the relationship between server security and KVKK/personal data security?
items.a: In systems where personal data is kept (PMS, web, CRM, DB); If server security is weak, the risk of data breach is high. KVKK technical measures are directly linked to server security (access control, logging, encryption, etc.). Lawyer for the legal framework; The security/IT team should work together for technical measures.

items.q: What are the most common risks when server security is weak?
items.a:
• hacking (deface) of the web page,
  • inserting malicious code/redirects,
  • database leak,
  • falling into spam e-mail and IP blacklists,
  • complete site crash or inaccessibility.
These create both technical and reputation risks.

items.q: How do DDoS attacks affect websites and how to prevent them?
items.a:
DDoS aims to consume the resources of your site or server by sending a large number of requests. As a result:
  • the site slows down or cannot respond,
  • real users cannot receive service.
To prevent/mitigate:
  • CDN and DDoS protection services,
  • rate limiting,
  • firewall rules,
  • scalable infrastructure
are used.

items.q: What consequences does insufficient backup lead to?
items.a:
In case of an attack, incorrect deployment or human error:
  • all site content,
  • database,
  • configurations
may be lost. Relying on backup and not performing any restoration tests is also a serious risk; It is necessary to make sure that the backups are working.

items.q: Is wrong firewall/WAF configuration also a risk?
items.a: Yes. Overly lax rules → open door for attacker; overly strict rules → problem for real users and integrations. For example, completely closing PMS integration ports may disrupt the connection; On the contrary, opening it to all IPs also creates risks.

items.q: Why is the “if I never update the server, it won't break” approach dangerous?
items.a:
Systems that are not updated:
  • remain with known security vulnerabilities,
  • become vulnerable to new attack sets,
  • some APIs and integrations begin to stop supporting over time.
Not controlling the update process is risky; It is riskier not to update at all.

section6.title: Productive Search & Industry-Focused Server Security

items.q: What are the most critical layers in server security for hotels in Turkey?
items.a:
• PMS and reservation servers,
  • website and booking engine hosting environment,
  • OTA integrated API endpoints,
  • CRM and e-mail marketing systems,
  • call center software and registration systems.
Access, encryption and logging levels must be sensitive in these areas.

items.q: Where should server security be important for corporate companies?
items.a:
• customer portals,
  • internal applications (intranet, ERP),
  • APIs and B2B integrations,
  • e-mail and file sharing systems.
WAF and IAM are critical, especially in externally open APIs and portals.

items.q: Is a server located in Türkiye or a global cloud more secure?
items.a: It's not just location; Configuration and management quality are decisive. Türkiye may be advantageous in terms of location, latency and some data regulations; Global cloud offers scalability and managed security services. In terms of KVKK/GDPR, you should evaluate the location preference with your lawyer.

items.q: Do security risks increase during peak season in tourism regions (Antalya, Bodrum, etc.)?
items.a:
During busy season, systems:
  • are used more,
  • the number of changes/deploys and campaigns increases,
  • operations team work more intensively.
This may increase the risk of human error and lack of attention. That's why it makes sense to conduct a pre-season safety audit.

items.q: What extra security points should be taken into consideration for sites operating in the foreign market?
items.a:
• DDoS and bot protection for traffic from different countries,
  • security of payment provider integrations,
  • tests of multi-language/currency supported forms and payment flows,
  • clarity in which country the data is kept in international hosting/cloud scenarios (related to KVKK/GDPR).

items.q: Is it OK to install everything on a single server?
items.a: It is possible in the short term for small projects; But as you scale, separating the application, database, cache and other services becomes more secure and manageable.

items.q: Does it make sense to run a critical system with shared hosting?
items.a: Usually no. For critical data and integrations, more isolated and controllable environments (VPS, dedicated, cloud) should be preferred.

items.q: Is it still safe to send files via FTP?
items.a: Classic FTP is not secure; You should use SFTP or FTPS and minimize manual file transfers with CI/CD pipelines if possible.

items.q: Does changing the SSH port from 22 alone work?
items.a: Port switching can help reduce brute-force attempts, but it alone is not enough; key-based auth, fail2ban, firewall etc. should be supported by measures.

items.q: Is it safe to keep all admin passwords in an Excel?
items.a: Not. It is much safer to use a secure password manager, manage access on a per-person basis, and not share passwords.

items.q: Why is it so risky to use the same password everywhere?
items.a: When there is a leak somewhere, all your systems become vulnerable to attack with the same password. The most basic good practice is to use different passwords for different services and activate 2FA.

items.q: Should server security and application security be on the same team?
items.a: Preferably, they should work in coordination; In some structures there may be the same team, in others there may be two separate teams, but constant communication and joint planning are essential.

items.q: Do I have to implement every security report as is?
items.a: Prioritization is a must. Some risks may be critical and urgent, some may be medium/low level. However, instead of “ignoring it completely”, it is important to make conscious risk management.

items.q: Do security layers necessarily reduce performance?
items.a: Some controls may introduce additional latency, but with the right configuration and scaling it can be kept at a level that the user will not notice. The security-performance balance must be established correctly.

items.q: Can I get the Server Security service only as “audit + report”?
items.a: Yes; You can examine your current structure, obtain a technical report containing your risks and improvement suggestions, and carry out the implementation part with your own IT team or another partner.

intro.p1:
A web project is not "done" the day it goes live; On the contrary, the life cycle begins from that day on. Framework versions change, security patches are released, content and integrations are updated, traffic/market grows. Without regular maintenance & support, even the best written site will after a while:
  • slow down,
  • produce errors,
  • give security vulnerabilities,
  • disrupt hotel/corporate operations.
intro.p2: This FAQ page; The most frequently asked questions about Maintenance & Support Services; Responses through version updates, bug tracking, performance improvement, uptime monitoring and content/deploy processes.

aiCapsule.title: Brief Summary (Overview)
aiCapsule.text: This Maintenance & Support Services FAQ page; It clarifies that maintenance for live websites and digital infrastructures is not “optional” but a mandatory process for business continuity. In critical topics such as version updates, security patches, uptime monitoring, error/log tracking, performance improvement and content/deploy flows; It focuses on preventing problems that may cause reservation/lead loss and reputation risk, especially in hotel & corporate projects. Aim; Instead of a reactive 'intervention when a fault occurs' approach, it is to establish a sustainable maintenance model that provides faster solutions, less interruption and higher performance with planned monitoring + SLA.

voiceSummary.title: Brief Summary
voiceSummary.text: Maintenance & Support FAQ; how to manage updates, security, uptime monitoring, error tracking and performance optimization to keep your website safe, fast and trouble-free when live; summarizes in a way that reduces the risk of interruption and loss of income in hotel and corporate projects.

voiceQueries.title: Sample Queries
voiceQueries.q1: “What is website maintenance and support?”
voiceQueries.q2: “Is a maintenance agreement required for the hotel website?”
voiceQueries.q3: “What is the difference between a maintenance agreement and a call when necessary?”
voiceQueries.q4: “The website has slowed down, why does it happen and how to solve it?”
voiceQueries.q5: “What does uptime monitoring and SLA mean?”

items.q: What exactly is website maintenance & support?
items.a:
Maintenance & support; It is all of the continuous technical work done to ensure that your live website and software infrastructure continue to work:
  • up-to-date,
  • fast,
  • secure and
  • error-free
. It is not a one-time “bug fix” but a regular process.

items.q: Why is maintenance & support critical “especially” for hotel and corporate sites?
items.a:
Because in these structures:
  • reservation/offer processes,
  • PMS and OTA integrations,
  • campaign pages,
  • multilingual content management
are constantly used in the live environment. An error or outage translates directly into loss of occupancy, revenue, leads and reputation. Maintenance is the “quiet but critical” part of the hotel operation.

items.q: “The site is working, is there a need to allocate extra budget for maintenance?”
items.a:
In the short term, yes, it seems to be working, but:
  • framework/OS updates are missed,
  • security patches are not applied,
  • database and logs swell,
  • risks of slowdowns and sudden crashes increase over time.
Maintenance budget is like insurance for bigger crises that may arise in the future.

items.q: What is the difference between a maintenance agreement and the “we call when necessary” model?
items.a:
• “We call when necessary” → intervention when problems arise; The duration of the failure is uncertain, loss/damage may be high.
  • Maintenance agreement → monitoring, warning and regular improvement before the problem occurs; Faster solution and less damage even if there is a problem.
The "reactive" model is very risky, especially for hotels experiencing busy seasons.

items.q: Is maintenance & support only required for large projects?
items.a:
No. Even in small hotel and corporate sites:
  • hosting and domain durations,
  • SSL renewals,
  • basic security patches,
  • GA4/GTM/tracking changes
should be followed. In small projects, the scope of maintenance is more limited, but “no maintenance” is a serious risk.

items.q: What is the relationship between maintenance & support and “SLA (Service Level Agreement)”?
items.a:
SLA; Within the scope of maintenance & support:
  • It is the written framework for which type of problems,
  • how long it will take,
  • through which channels (mail, ticket, telephone)
will be intervened. It is the “service contract” leg of the maintenance agreement.

items.q: What is website maintenance & support, in one sentence?
items.a: It is a process of regular technical monitoring and intervention to keep your live website and infrastructure up-to-date, secure, fast and error-free.

items.q: Why should I have regular maintenance for my hotel website?
items.a: Because your reservation, campaign and integration flows are used every day; interruption or error directly leads to loss of occupancy and revenue.

items.q: Who should monitor version updates and patches?
items.a: Framework, CMS, plugin and server updates; It should be monitored, tested and implemented by a technical team or agency that is familiar with these technologies.

items.q: Who should I contact when the site slows down or gives errors?
items.a: If you have a maintenance agreement; To the technical maintenance team with defined areas of responsibility. Otherwise, to the team that developed the project or to an expert agency that knows the infrastructure.

items.q: What kind of risks occur if there is no maintenance agreement?
items.a: Systems that are not updated; It increases the risk of security vulnerabilities, performance degradation, unexpected crashes and outages during critical periods (season, campaign).

items.q: Who is the maintenance & support service suitable for?
items.a: It is suitable for all hotels, tourism businesses, corporate sites, e-commerce projects and SaaS products whose website and digital infrastructure are at the center of their business.

section3.title: Maintenance & Support Service Scope

items.q: What does website maintenance service include?
items.a:
A typical maintenance package includes routines such as:
  • framework/theme/plugin updates,
  • security patches,
  • uptime and basic performance monitoring,
  • error log tracking,
  • minor fixes and improvements,
  • SSL and domain/critical certificate monitoring
. The scope can be expanded depending on the project.

items.q: How should version updates be managed?
items.a:
• It should first be tried in the testing/staging environment,
  • critical functions (reservation, form, payment, etc.) should be tested,
  • If there is no problem, it should be taken live.
Making a "direct update to live"; It poses a serious risk, especially in busy season and high traffic environments.

items.q: How are error tracking and logging included in maintenance & support?
items.a:
Server and application logs are regularly checked for:
  • critical errors (500, DB errors, time-out, etc.),
  • crashes and performance problems,
  • integration problems
. If necessary, alarm/warning systems (Slack, email, SMS) are installed.

items.q: Where is performance optimization in maintenance?
items.a:
• image optimization,
  • cache/purge settings,
  • detection of heavy queries and scripts,
  • CWV (Core Web Vitals) monitoring
are checked at regular intervals. Especially on hotel and campaign pages, speed is critical for conversion.

items.q: Is uptime monitoring included in the maintenance service?
items.a: In most professional care packages; site/server uptime (e.g. 24/7 monitoring + outage alerts). This way, your continuity metric will be clear.

items.q: Can content changes and minor UI fixes be part of maintenance?
items.a: According to the agreement, within a certain hour/person/day limit; Minor content edits (text/image), minor UI fixes and minor improvements may be covered under maintenance. Major revisions should be defined as separate projects.

items.q: What do you analyze before starting a maintenance & support project?
items.a:
• existing site and infrastructure (framework, CMS, hosting),
  • integrations (PMS, payment, CRM, OTA, etc.),
  • past error and outage records,
  • traffic and busy periods (season, campaign),
  • previous update and maintenance practices.
This analysis determines the scope and priorities of the maintenance agreement.

items.q: How does the ticket / support process work?
items.a:
• The customer opens a ticket through specified channels (e-mail, support panel, etc.),
  • the ticket is classified according to priority level (critical, high, medium, low),
  • The first callback and solution actions begin within the periods defined in the SLA,
  • closed tickets are seen in the reports.
The important thing is; It is clear who will look at what and for how long.

items.q: What frequency is reasonable for version updates?
items.a:
• security patches → as fast as possible (after testing),
  • framework/minor updates → monthly / quarterly,
  • major version transitions → separately planned, as a tested project.
This frequency for each project; adjusted according to risk and business continuity.

items.q: The site started to slow down; What does the maintenance team check?
items.a:
• last deployment/updates,
  • server resource usage (CPU/RAM/disk),
  • database queries,
  • cache status and CDN,
  • 3rd party scripts and tags (especially tracking/pixel crowd).
After these checks, it is seen whether a "one-time improvement" or a more radical revision is required.

items.q: How to set up uptime and health-check monitoring?
items.a:
• health-check services that send requests to the site at certain intervals (e.g. 1 minute),
  • HTTP response code, response time and content control,
  • Slack/e-mail/SMS alerts when threshold values ​​are exceeded,
  • uptime percentage in reports (e.g. 99.5%, 99.9%).
This is especially vital for reservation and sales-oriented sites.

items.q: What should be checked during pre-season maintenance?
items.a:
For hotel and tourism:
  • booking flow (all steps),
  • campaign and price contents,
  • text and link integrity on multilingual pages,
  • speed tests (especially mobile),
  • integrations (PMS, payment, OTA),
  • tracking and reporting setups (GA4, Tag Manager).
It is more difficult to collect these after the season enters.

items.q: What are the most common problems on sites that are not maintained?
items.a:
• security vulnerabilities caused by outdated plugins and frameworks,
  • slowdown and occasional access problems,
  • broken CSS/JS and faulty views,
  • broken form and reservation flows,
  • corruption of measurement infrastructure such as GA4/GTM.

items.q: Why do system crashes and unplanned outages occur?
items.a:
Most of the time:
  • due to resource limits,
  • wrong deployment,
  • lack of testing after the update,
  • excessive traffic/DDoS,
  • database problems
. Regular monitoring and maintenance reduces these risks.

items.q: What's missing from the "Everything went wrong one night, we couldn't reach anyone" scenario?
items.a:
• a clear maintenance & support agreement,
  • SLA,
  • 24/7 or wide-time support,
  • clear who can be called in critical situations.
These deficiencies can turn into very expensive mistakes during the season/busy period.

items.q: Isn't wrong maintenance/updating also a risk?
items.a: Yes. Random, unplanned updates and changes without testing; It can be as dangerous as a security vulnerability. That's why maintenance; It should be done “planned and recorded”.

items.q: What does not budgeting for maintenance & support cost in the long run?
items.a:
In the short term, it looks like savings; but risks such as:
  • security vulnerability → breach and loss of reputation,
  • crash → loss of reservations/sales,
  • incorrect data → reporting and decision errors
may produce losses in total that far exceed the maintenance cost.

section6.title: Productive Search & Industry-Focused Maintenance & Support Questions

items.q: What should we focus on in maintenance & support services for hotels in Turkey?
items.a:
• Continuity of PMS and reservation engine integrations,
  • problem operation of campaign and season pages,
  • robustness of the multilingual structure,
  • uptime and performance in high season,
  • Preservation of KVKK compliant data flows.

items.q: What are the priorities in maintenance & support for corporate B2B sites?
items.a:
• error-free form and lead flows,
  • case study, product/service pages remaining up-to-date,
  • integrations (CRM, ERP, ticket systems),
  • smooth processing of content and document uploads,
  • security and uptime.

items.q: Why is pre-season maintenance extra important in tourism regions (Antalya, Bodrum, etc.)?
items.a:
Because:
  • visitor traffic intensifies at the beginning of the season,
  • early bookings and campaigns come into play,
  • competition is high.
Having problems with the site or reservation flow in the middle of the season causes much greater costs in terms of occupancy and reputation.

items.q: How should maintenance be scaled in multi-location / multi-hotel brands?
items.a:
• common component (theme, component, infrastructure) updates should be made centrally,
  • hotel/branch based content and minor developments should be carried out at the local level,
  • a common monitoring and warning system should be established for all hotels.

items.q: What additional maintenance & support is required for sites operating in foreign markets?
items.a:
• synchronized update of different country/language versions,
  • global CDN and performance monitoring,
  • tracking of different payment providers and integrations,
  • reflection of local legal/security changes (especially on the cookie/pixel side).

items.q: I have a new website built, is maintenance required for the first year?
items.a: Yes; Especially in the first year, the need for technical support is high for both optimization and unexpected bugs.

items.q: Does maintenance have to require dozens of hours each month?
items.a: No; Depending on the scope and site size, an efficient maintenance plan can be made with a certain monthly hour/man-day limit.

items.q: Is it enough to just rely on the support of the hosting company?
items.a: The hosting company looks after the infrastructure; The site code, integrations and CMS side are mostly your/your agency's responsibility.

items.q: Do the things we postpone as "little mistakes" accumulate?
items.a: Yes; The accumulation of small bugs and warnings can turn into big problems and more expensive revisions in the long run.

items.q: Will SEO be affected if there is no maintenance & support?
items.a: Indirectly yes; Corrupted pages, slowdowns, broken links and incorrect tracking negatively impact SEO performance and measurement.

items.q: What does Uptime 99.9% mean?
items.a: It means not experiencing interruptions for more than certain periods of time on an annual basis (approximately 8–9 hours/year). Uptime percentage is one of the critical KPIs on reservation-oriented sites.

items.q: Can content production be included in the maintenance agreement?
items.a: The scope can be designed accordingly; For some brands, technical + certain amount of content support are managed under the same agreement.

items.q: Is it possible to resolve every maintenance request instantly?
items.a: Rapid action is targeted for critical errors; However, since some jobs require testing and planning, it is more realistic to solve them within the time periods within the SLA.

items.q: How should I plan the maintenance & support budget?
items.a: Generally, an annual/monthly maintenance budget is planned based on a certain percentage of the project cost and/or the expected volume of changes.

items.q: Can I get maintenance & support service only as audit + roadmap?
items.a: Yes; It is also possible to get a maintenance audit that includes current situation analysis, risk and improvement suggestions, and carry out the implementation phase with your own team.

items.a:

  • your hosting/cloud structure,

  • monthly expected content/development needs,
  • the main problems you have experienced in the past (crashing, slowdown, integration error, etc.).
When you share a brief brief about; A maintenance & support roadmap and proposal can be prepared including scope, SLA, duration and budget.

items.q: What does the “consult specialist” call clarify on the maintenance side?
items.a:
This meeting clarifies issues such as
  • what kind of work will or will not be included in the maintenance agreement,
  • which risks are prioritized,
  • how to structure SLA and communication channels,
  • how to manage priorities specific to season/campaign periods
and draws a framework for the maintenance model suitable for your brand.
