generalQuestions.title: What is Call Center Performance Analysis? (General Questions)

items.q: What exactly is call center performance analysis?
items.a:
Call center performance analysis; It is the analysis process that measures and reports inbound/outbound calls, with metrics such as waiting time, response rate, service level, solution rate, sales/reservation conversion and agent efficiency:
  • how much work you do,
  • how high quality you do this work,
  • what this brings to your hotel in terms of income and satisfaction
.

items.q: “Are the phones answered?” What does the transition from question to “performance analysis” mean?
items.a:
Just looking at “is anyone answering the phone?” is the level of operational survival. Performance analysis allows you to read efficiency, quality and revenue contribution through data such as:
  • incoming call volume,
  • answered,
  • lost,
  • waiting, bounced calls,
  • how much you converted into sales
.

items.q: Is call center performance only valid for inbound calls?
items.a:
No. Performance analyzes should be performed for both inbound (incoming call) and outbound (callbacks, campaign calls, no-show / offer follow-up calls). Especially on the outbound side, metrics such as:
  • reach rate,
  • conversation rate,
  • offer → booking conversion
are important.

items.q: Why should hotel call center performance be considered separately?
items.a:
Hotel call center; Unlike the classical call center:
  • directly linked to reservations and revenue,
  • Working with different stakeholders such as MICE, agency, OTA and direct,
  • a multi-lingual and multi-channel (phone, WhatsApp, OTA message, etc.) structure.
Therefore, the KPI set should be designed according to tourism & hotel realities.

items.q: What is the risk of managing a call center without performance analysis?
items.a:
• excessive staff → unnecessary costs,
  • insufficient staff → missed calls and revenue,
  • weak script and training → low conversion,
  • unmeasurable quality → guest complaints and score decrease.
So if there is no performance analysis; optimal management is inevitable.

items.q: How is call center performance tied to “revenue contribution”?
items.a:
With a well-constructed analysis, it is possible to see the monthly/periodic income contribution of the call center by establishing a funnel such as
  • how many calls → how many offers,
  • how many offers → how many reservations,
  • reservations → total revenue
.

items.q: What is call center performance analysis?
items.a: It is the process that measures and reports incoming and outgoing calls, waiting time, service level, solution and sales/reservation conversion with KPIs.

items.q: What KPIs should I look at for a hotel call center?
items.a: Key KPIs such as response rate, wait time, service level, sales/booking conversion per call, agent productivity and guest satisfaction.

items.q: How do I measure booking conversion rate?
items.a: By tracking the number of calls/requests, the number of offers and the number of reservations made; You must calculate the bid → booking rate.

items.q: What should the wait time and response rate be?
items.a: Although the targets vary depending on the size of your hotel; A specific service level target (e.g. “answering 80% of calls within 20 seconds”) should be defined.

items.q: How should I report agent performance?
items.a: You should track metrics such as number of calls answered, average call duration, conversion rate, quality scores, and complaint rates for each agent.

items.q: Who is call center performance analysis suitable for?
items.a: It is suitable for all hotels, tourism brands and businesses in the service sector with inbound/outbound call traffic; It is especially critical for buildings with reservation lines.

section3.title: Service Scope: Call Statistics, Quality, Team Productivity

items.q: What topics does call center performance analysis cover?
items.a:
• call statistics (number, channel, language, inbound/outbound),
  • service quality metrics (response rate, waiting time, service level, resolution rate),
  • sales/reservation conversion metrics,
  • team and agent efficiency (call handling, occupancy, attendance),
  • language/channel breakdowns,
  • report and dashboard design.

items.q: How is call center performance measured?
items.a:
The following KPIs can be considered as a core set:
  • total number of calls (incoming/outgoing),
  • number and rate of answered/unanswered calls,
  • average waiting time,
  • service level (e.g. 80% call answered within 20 seconds),
  • average call time (AHT),
  • resolution rate (first call resolution). etc.),
  • reservation/sales conversion rate,
  • agent-based performance metrics.

items.q: What are the most important KPIs for inbound and outbound?
items.a:
• Inbound: response rate, service level, wait time, AHT, resolution rate, inbound → booking conversion.
  • Outbound: reach rate, call rate, outbound → offer → booking conversion, callback efficiency.

items.q: What are the service quality metrics?
items.a:
• service level,
  • first call resolution,
  • waiting time,
  • guest satisfaction scores (CSAT, NPS),
  • complaint rate and complaint resolution time.

items.q: By what metrics is team productivity measured?
items.a:
• number of calls per agent,
  • number of reservations/sales per agent,
  • occupancy (ratio of conversation + after-call work time to total time),
  • adherence (shift compliance – in the right place at the right time),
  • quality scores and feedback.

section4.title: Process & Operation: KPIs, Dashboard, Continuous Improvement

items.q: How to start the call center performance analysis process?
items.a:
1. Reviewing existing reports and data,
  2. determining targets (income, satisfaction, capacity),
  3. clarifying the KPI set,
  4. establishing the reporting infrastructure (call center platform + BI/reporting tools),
  5. designing dashboard and periodic report formats,
  6. defining the analysis → action → follow-up cycle.

items.q: How should inbound/outbound call data be classified?
items.a:
• inbound/outbound distinction,
  • channel-based distinction (phone, WhatsApp calls, callback, etc.),
  • campaign/segment-based distinction (e.g. early booking, no-show callback),
  • language-based distinction (TR–EN–DE–RU etc.),
  • guest type-based distinction (individual, agency, MICE).

items.q: What is service level and how is it calculated?
items.a: Service level; It is the ratio of calls answered within a certain period of time (e.g. 20 seconds) to the total number of calls. For example: “80/20%” goal → 80% of calls answered within 20 seconds.

items.q: What metrics should I use to evaluate agent performance?
items.a:
• number of answered calls,
  • average call duration,
  • conversion rate (calls returned to reservation),
  • quality scores (compliance with script and standards),
  • complaint rate,
  • shift compliance/adherence.

items.q: What are the common mistakes made in performance analysis?
items.a:
• only looking at the number of calls,
  • completely ignoring quality,
  • breaking team spirit by listing all KPIs on an agent basis,
  • producing reports but not taking action,
  • ignoring inbound/outbound, language and channel breakdowns.

section5.title: Performance & Reporting: Reading and Interpreting KPIs

items.q: How is call center performance measured?
items.a:
It is necessary not to see the metrics just as a table; it is necessary to interpret them together with their
  • trends (increase/decrease),
  • benchmarks (comparison with the target),
  • correlations (for example, does the conversion decrease when the waiting time increases?)
. To measure = not to count; It means understanding the story.

items.q: How to track booking conversion rate?
items.a:
• You should calculate the offer → reservation ratio by separately tracking the total number of calls/requests for reservation,
  • the number of calls for which offers were made,
  • the number of calls that turned into reservations. Breaking this ratio based on language, channel and campaign is very valuable for sales-oriented improvements.

items.q: What are the most important KPIs for inbound and outbound?
items.a:
The above mentioned;
  • for inbound: response, service level, AHT, solution and conversion,
  • for outbound: reach, conversation and conversion rates
are the core KPI set for each call center.

items.q: How do KPIs affect team motivation?
items.a:
• well-constructed KPIs,
  • fair targets,
  • transparent reporting,
  • combined with a system that rewards success;
increases team motivation.
  • incorrectly constructed KPIs (only quantity pressure, stifling quality);
  • reduces both guest experience and internal motivation.

items.q: How do I tie call center performance to “revenue and guest satisfaction”?
items.a:
• reservations and revenue from the call center,
  • satisfaction/comment scores of these calls,
  • representative-based sales + satisfaction correlations
by tracking; It can move from “we are responding” to “we are growing revenue and NPS together.”

section6.title: Unmeasurable Performance, Wrong KPI, Low Service Level

items.q: What problems does unmeasured performance cause?
items.a:
• You can't really meet how many people you need,
  • You can't know who is good and who is open to improvement,
  • You can't see sales opportunities and losses,
  • The team and senior management make decisions based on "feelings".

items.q: What problems do wrong KPIs produce?
items.a:
• If you only say "the shortest talker is better": representatives try to close the customer quickly, quality decreases,
  • If you only aim for "numerical": the team may ignore the real need of the guest,
  • If you only look at "quality": productivity and capacity planning may deteriorate.

items.q: What does low service level mean?
items.a:
• guests wait for a long time,
  • some calls are never answered,
  • guests move to another hotel,
  • The budget you allocate for OTAs and campaigns is not met correctly in the call center.

items.q: How do motivational problems impair performance?
items.a:
• if there are no clear goals and fair KPIs,
  • if good performance is not rewarded,
  • if feedback is only “negative”;
team performance decreases over time; The call center turns into a "job done out of necessity".

items.q: What kind of decision errors does improper reporting cause?
items.a:
• unnecessary staff increase/decrease due to wrong KPI weights,
  • wrong capacity planning for wrong time/language,
  • only quantity-oriented actions when the real problem is conversion and quality.

section7.title: Productive Search & Industry-Focused Call Center Performance

items.q: Why is call center performance analysis important for hotels in Turkey?
items.a:
• peak season and multilingual calls in tourist areas,
  • OTA and direct channel mix,
  • revenue targets and satisfaction scores have to be managed simultaneously.
Therefore, a call center without performance analysis means a flight in the dark.

items.q: What performance metrics stand out for City hotels?
items.a:
• transformation of business/MICE focused inbound demands,
  • corporate and agency call performance,
  • service level in short stay and price questions requiring quick decisions.

items.q: How does performance analysis differ in multilingual call centers?
items.a:
• language-based call volume,
  • language-based response and conversion rates,
  • service level and satisfaction scores in each language should be monitored separately.
Especially in 4-lingual structures such as TR–EN–DE–RU, each language should be considered as a separate market.

items.q: Why is the inbound/outbound balance important in tourism regions?
items.a:
• inbound: not missing incoming demand,
  • outbound: no-show, offer tracking, early booking and campaign sales.
Both are critical for revenue; The balance of these two flows must be seen in performance analysis.

items.q: How does call center performance connect with hotel digital marketing results?
items.a:
• call volume during campaign periods,
  • conversion rate of calls coming from the campaign,
  • channel (Google Ads, Meta, OTA, etc.) based call-reservation impact
by reporting; It can be seen how digital marketing investments yield results when combined with call center performance.

section8.title: Mini Call Center Performance FAQ

items.q: Should the same set of KPIs be used for every call center?
items.a: No; Weights may vary depending on your hotel's goals (sales, support, NPS, etc.), but the core set of metrics remains similar.

items.q: Why is it wrong to just look at the number of calls?
items.a: Quantity indicates volume; but it alone does not provide information about quality, conversion and satisfaction.

items.q: Is the notion of “the shorter the better” correct?
items.a: Completely wrong. The aim should not be “the shortest meeting” but to offer the guest the best experience in a reasonable time.

items.q: Is inbound or outbound more important?
items.a: Instead of choosing one over the other, it is necessary to optimize both together; The ideal model is to not miss inbound demand and pursue outbound opportunities.

items.q: Need a giant BI system to start performance analysis?
items.a: No; Even the basic reports of your call center platform + simple dashboards can provide very valuable insights at the initial stage.

items.q: Is it healthy for the team to disclose all KPIs on an agent basis?
items.a: Transparency is important, but “just sorting and printing” can be demotivating; KPIs should also be used for coaching and development purposes.

items.q: How often should performance reports be reviewed?
items.a: Depending on the operational intensity, daily/weekly operational reports and monthly/quarterly strategic evaluations are a good balance.

items.q: Is it possible to just look at inbound KPIs and forget about outbound?
items.a: It is possible but unhealthy; The outbound side carries great potential for revenue and loyalty.

items.q: Should I use call center performance analysis just for “history”?
items.a: No; Historical data should provide decision support for future shift, capacity, training and campaign planning.

items.q: Can I get the Call Center Performance Analysis service only as "audit + dashboard design"?
items.a: Yes; A consultancy package that analyzes your current structure, creates a KPI set and dashboard design, and provides report reading training to your team is also possible.

If you share a short brief that summarizes; A Call Center Performance Analysis roadmap and proposal can be prepared, including KPI set, dashboard design, analysis processes and training steps.

items.q: What does the call to “consult with an expert” clarify on the performance analysis side?
items.a:
In this meeting, we clarify:
  • which KPIs are "must have" for you,
  • which data you already have,
  • which reports and dashboards you really need,
  • short-term (quick win) and medium-term (structural improvement) steps
together. Thus, call center performance analysis becomes not just an Excel table, but a management tool that grows your operation and revenue.

generalQuestions.title: General Questions About PMS and PMS Installation Service

items.q: What is PMS and what does it provide to hotels?
items.a:
PMS (Property Management System); It is hotel management software that allows you to carry out the hotel's:
  • room & reservation management,
  • check-in/check-out processes,
  • housekeeping (room status),
  • invoice & accounting integration,
  • report and income tracking
through a single system. Using PMS instead of Excel or notebook; It reduces the risk of errors, increases speed and makes the operation measurable.

items.q: What exactly is PMS Installation Service?
items.a: PMS Installation Service; It is a professional installation and transition process that includes steps such as selecting the appropriate PMS for your hotel, determining the license and module structure, configuring the system according to your hotel (room types, price plans, users, etc.), planning data migration from old systems, personnel training and preparation for OTA-channel manager integration.

items.q: Which PMS should I choose for my hotel?
items.a:
There is no single answer to this question; When deciding:
  • hotel type and number of rooms (resort, city, boutique, chain),
  • target market and channels to be used,
  • modules you need (housekeeping, POS, spa, MICE, etc.),
  • OTA/channel manager integration support,
  • cloud-based or local?
  • support & training quality,
  • budget and license. It is necessary to evaluate criteria such as model
together. During the PMS Installation Service process, this analysis is done professionally.

items.q: What stages does PMS installation consist of?
items.a:
In general:
  • Needs analysis & PMS selection
  • Contract & licensing
  • System configuration (room, price, user, department definitions)
  • Data migration plan from old systems
  • Training plan and in-hotel pilot use
  • Go-live
  • First period support and optimization

items.q: Will hotel operation stop during PMS installation?
items.a:
In a properly planned installation, there is no need to stop the operation completely. Generally:
  • in the low season or on calmer days,
  • in the test environment parallel to the old system,
  • the transition is made step by step.
The aim is not to “change everything overnight”; is to provide a controlled and safe passage.

items.q: Who is PMS Installation Service suitable for?
items.a:
• It is suitable for all hotel and tourism businesses that still use Excel/manual systems,
  • want to change their old PMS,
  • open new hotels,
  • are experiencing disorganization on the OTA and channel management side
.

items.q: What exactly is PMS Installation Service?
items.a: It is a professional service that selects the right PMS for your hotel and manages its installation and personnel training to digitalize your room-price-reservation and operation processes.

items.q: Which PMS should I choose for my hotel?
items.a: You should decide by evaluating the hotel type, number of rooms, your module needs, OTA/channel manager integrations and your budget together.

items.q: How long does the installation and training process take?
items.a: Although it varies depending on the number of rooms, module scope and complexity of data migration; We can talk about a process that generally takes a few weeks in small/boutique hotels and a few months in larger and chain buildings.

items.q: How to migrate data from old systems to PMS?
items.a: Room, guest, past reservation and price data in the old system; After it is cleaned and mapped, it is transferred to the new system using the methods offered by the PMS provider (import, API, etc.); Manual control is made for critical areas.

items.q: How to organize staff training?
items.a: Department-based (reception, reservation, accounting, housekeeping, etc.) trainings are planned; Practice is carried out on both theoretical and live systems and reinforced with short support sessions after go-live.

items.q: Who is PMS Installation Service suitable for?
items.a: It is suitable for all hotels that open a new hotel, change their old PMS, or want to move their Excel/manual structure to a professional PMS.

ensure that the staff can easily carry out their daily work within the new system.

items.q: How to prepare OTA and channel manager integration with PMS?
items.a:
During PMS installation:
  • room types,

  • packages
are named in accordance with the channel manager and OTA structure. After installation, PMS–OTA mapping is performed via the channel manager and verification is provided through test reservations.

items.q: How is the PMS Installation Service different from the installation provided by the PMS provider?
items.a: The PMS provider often offers product installation and its own documentation; PMS Installation Service is an end-to-end transition and consultancy process that also takes into account hotel-side operation, OTA/channel manager strategy and personnel adaptation.

section4.title: Process & Operation: Installation, Data Migration, Training

items.q: What main stages does PMS installation consist of?
items.a:
• Analysis: Existing processes, used systems, room structure, price policy, integrated systems (channel manager, POS, etc.) are examined.
  • Design: PMS module and configuration plan is created.
  • Configuration: Room, price, user, department, role and report definitions are made.
  • Data Migration: Necessary data from the old system/Excel is transferred to the new PMS.
  • Training: Department-based. training and test runs are carried out.
  • Go-Live: The system goes live, the first reservations and transactions are managed from the new system.
  • After Support: Early errors and improvement needs are tracked.

items.q: How to migrate data from old systems to PMS?
items.a:
• determine which data actually needs to be migrated (room cards, customer cards, active reservations, basic historical data, etc.),
  • old data is cleaned and mapped according to the PMS format,
  • Importation is made using the PMS provider's import tools or APIs,
  • manual checks are performed for critical data (e.g. active reservations and room matches).
The goal is not to "throw away whatever we find", It is to establish a sustainable and clean database.

items.q: How to organize staff training?
items.a:
• separate sessions are held for departments such as reception/front office, reservation, accounting, housekeeping,
  • each department is given training through scenarios suitable for daily workflows,
  • trial recordings and simulations are made in the test environment,
  • understanding level is measured with short quizzes or applied tests after training,
  • compressed support is provided in the first weeks after go-live.

items.q: How long does the installation and training process take?
items.a:
• in small/boutique hotels and simple module sets: usually 1–3 weeks,
  • in larger or multi-module, chain structures: a process ranging from a few weeks to a few months may be required.
Duration; It depends on the number of rooms, module scope, complexity of data migration and personnel density.

items.q: What are the common mistakes made during PMS installation?
items.a:
• failure to analyze module needs well,
  • failure to design the room & price plan structure in compliance with the OTA/channel manager,
  • direct import of "unprepared" and uncleaned data during data transfer,
  • inadequate planning of the training period,
  • scheduling the go-live date to coincide with the busiest period of the hotel.

section5.title: Performance & Reporting: What Does the Hotel Gain After PMS?

items.q: What reports can I get after PMS installation?
items.a:
• occupancy, ADR, RevPAR reports,

In other words, instead of pulling the "signboard" from Excel, in real time. reportingbecomes possible.

items.q: How does PMS performance impact OTA & channel management?
items.a:
Correct PMS–channel manager–OTA setup enables
  • synchronous updating of prices and inventory across all channels,
  • reducing the risk of overbooking,
  • easier management of price/campaign setups specific to different markets.
An efficient PMS–OTA setup can often improve channel efficiency in hotels by 20–30%.

items.q: How does switching to PMS affect call center and reservation processes?
items.a:
• the call center and reservation team access price-room-availability information in real time and from a single place,
  • offer and reservation records are standardized,
  • working with manual notes and notebooks is reduced to a minimum.
This reflects positively on both conversion and satisfaction.

items.q: How does PMS installation increase operational efficiency?
items.a:
• Efficiency increases through processes such as shortening check-in/out times,
  • automating communication between housekeeping and reception,
  • reducing incorrect records and conflicts,
  • fast receipt of reports that facilitate decision-making by the management team
.

items.q: How should PMS performance be monitored?
items.a:

  • error reports and user complaints,
  • accuracy of reports,
  • OTA/channel manager synchronization logs,

should be reviewed regularly.

section6.title: Wrong PMS, Incorrect Installation, Untrained Team, Data Loss

items.q: What problems does choosing the wrong PMS cause?
items.a:
• unnecessary fees for modules you don't need,
  • lack of modules and integrations you need,
  • non-user-friendly interface,
  • poor support and training,
  • inability to "port" the system as the hotel grows.
Result: need to change PMS again after a while and loss of time + money.

items.q: What triggers incorrect installation?
items.a:
• incorrect definition of rooms or price plans,
  • mapping errors on the channel manager and OTA side,
  • configuration problems that cause conflicting data in the reports,
  • state of "distrust in the system" in the team.
This creates a picture of dealing with PMS instead of using its advantages.

items.q: What kind of problems do untrained teams experience in PMS?
items.a:
• using even basic functions incorrectly or incompletely,
  • returning to old habits (Excel, notebook, notes),
  • over time, the perception that "PMS is not working",
  • extra difficulty for new staff.

items.q: How do data losses and incorrect data migration become problems?
items.a:
• incomplete reflection of active reservations,
  • loss of guest history and preference information,
  • discrepancy in debit-receivable and account movements,
  • undermining the reliability of reports.
Therefore, data migration; It should be done in the form of preparation + cleaning + controlled import.

items.q: What happens if support is not received after PMS installation?
items.a:
• Small mistakes that occur in the first months become bigger,
  • The team develops wrong habits,
  • New possibilities of the system are never discovered,
  • The hotel remains at the point of "We bought PMS, but we continue with the old style"

Factors such as

items.q: How should PMS installation in tourism regions be connected with OTA/channel manager strategy?

items.q: What extra considerations should be taken in PMS installation for chain hotels?

items.q: What does switching to PMS provide for small and boutique hotels across Türkiye?

section8.title: Mini PMS Installation Service FAQ

items.q: Is PMS required for every hotel?
items.a: In practice, yes for any hotel above a certain room and booking volume; Manual systems become both risky and inefficient after a point.

items.q: Is it right to choose PMS based only on price?
items.a: No; In the long run, support, integration and ease of use may be more critical than the license fee.

items.q: Do I have to completely migrate old data when changing PMS?
items.a: No; It is healthier to carry clean data that you will actually need, rather than unnecessary or old/unproductive data.

items.q: Do I have to train all staff at the same time on PMS installation?
items.a: Department-based and grouped trainings according to shifts do not stop the operation and provide more effective learning.

items.q: Is it enough to do PMS training only once?
items.a: Usually no; Post-go-live follow-up training and onboarding training for new personnel are required.

items.q: Is misusing PMS as big a risk as correct installation?
items.a: Yes; A perfectly configured PMS will still produce faulty data and processes if used incorrectly. Training and supervision are essential.

items.q: Does it make sense to do the PMS installation entirely with my own team?
items.a: It's technically possible, but if you're doing it for the first time; Getting professional support can prevent major errors and additional costs in the future.

items.q: Is it necessary to put the processes in writing after PMS installation?
items.a: Yes; Written SOPs (standard operating procedures) are very useful, especially for new personnel and audit processes.

items.q: Can I get PMS Installation Service only as “analysis + selection recommendation”?
items.a: Yes; It is also possible to receive consultancy for PMS selection, module recommendations and installation roadmap, and carry out the implementation with your own team and PMS provider.

items.q: What exactly is OTA integration?
items.a:
OTA integration; It is a set of technical connections that ensure secure, fast and two-way (if possible) flow of:
  • room & price,
  • availability & closing,
  • reservation and change
data between your PMS, channel manager and OTAs (Booking.com, Expedia, Agoda, etc.). Aim; It is to manage price/inventory in each channel from a single panel, instead of manually entering them one by one.

items.q: What does it mean to work without OTA integration?
items.a:
• you enter prices and availability into each OTA panel separately,
  • as the number of channels increases, the risk of error and workload increases,
  • the risk of overbooking and wrong prices increases,
  • combining reports becomes difficult.
In short: as your number of channels increases, manual management becomes unscalable.

items.q: Which systems does OTA integration include?
items.a:
In typical architecture:
  • PMS (hotel management system) – rooms, rates, reservations,
  • Channel Manager – bridge between PMS and OTAs,
  • OTAs – Booking.com, Expedia, Agoda, Hotels.com, etc.,
  • Hotel website booking engine – often integrated with the channel manager.

items.q: Does OTA integration work the same for all OTAs?
items.a:
Although the principle is the same;
  • each OTA's integration protocol,
  • data fields,
  • some special rules and restrictions
may be different. That's why the correct mapping and testing process is important for every OTA.

items.q: Is OTA integration only for big hotels?
items.a: No. As the number of channels + booking volume grows, the value of integration increases, even if you are a boutique hotel. It is unrealistic to work without integration even for small and medium-sized hotels, especially if the OTA volume is high in destinations such as Antalya, Belek, Kemer, Side, Bodrum and Alanya.

items.q: Who is the OTA Integration service suitable for?
items.a:
• hotels that currently work with OTAs and experience errors and overbooking,
  • hotels that will add a new OTA/channel manager,
  • Hotels that renew their PMS and want to establish an integrated channel structure,
  • All facilities that make multi-channel sales in destinations such as Antalya–Belek–Kemer–Side–Bodrum–Alanya.

items.q: What is OTA integration and how does it work?
items.a: It is the connection structure that enables automatic and synchronous flow of room, price, availability and reservation data between PMS-channel manager-OTA.

items.q: How to integrate Booking and Expedia into PMS?
items.a: Usually PMS → channel manager → OTA; The channel manager receives the room/price from PMS, forwards it to OTAs such as Booking/Expedia, and writes the reservations from OTA back to PMS.

items.q: Why is rate parity important and how is it protected?
items.a: Rate parity; It means offering the same or controlled price for the same room on different channels. With integration and the right price plan setup, you can maintain price balance across all OTAs and your website.

items.q: How to prevent overbooking?
items.a: All channels use synchronous inventory via the same PMS & channel manager, keep manual intervention to a minimum and manage closed dates/stop-sell through the integrated system.

items.q: How to make room/price matching between channel manager and OTAs?
items.a: You must map each PMS/OTA room and price type exactly to its counterpart in the channel manager; If the room-plan-market based mapping is not done correctly, the wrong price/structure will be published.

items.q: Who is the OTA Integration FAQ suitable for?
items.a: It is suitable for all hotels that want to stabilize the PMS + channel manager + OTA trio and manage price/inventory from a single panel.

section3.title: OTA Integration Architecture & Service Scope

items.q: How is the OTA integration architecture constructed?
items.a:
In standard architecture:
  1. PMS is the source of room types and price plans.
  2. Channel manager distributes the room & price data received from PMS to OTAs.
  3. Reservations from OTAs are written back to PMS through the channel manager.
  4. Hotel website booking engine often works in connection with PMS through the channel manager.
This structure means prices and inventory managed from a single source (PMS).

items.q: How does PMS–channel manager–OTA data flow work?
items.a:
• PMS → Channel Manager:
    room/inventory, price, minimum night, closing information.
  • Channel Manager → OTA:
    price & inventory update in a format suitable for each OTA.
  • OTA → Channel Manager → PMS:
    new reservation, change, cancellation and no-show information.
This flow; It can be periodic (pull/push), event-based or real-time (depending on the system).

items.q: What does OTA Integration service include?
items.a:
• analysis of the existing PMS and channel manager structure,
  • determination and preliminary preparation of the OTAs to be used,
  • making the room & price plan structure suitable for integration,
  • PMS–channel manager–OTA mapping (room, price, market, package),
  • flow verification with test reservations,
  • creating procedures for risks and error management,
  • reporting and optimization suggestions.

items.q: What is rate parity, why is it critical?
items.a:
Rate parity; It is the principle of offering the same price (or within certain difference rules) for the same room and date on the channels you control. When rate parity is broken:
  • Disagreements with OTAs and business partners,
  • loss of “trust” on the guest side,
  • penalization or loss of visibility on some channels may occur.

items.q: Does OTA integration only cover major OTAs like Booking–Expedia?
items.a: No. Many channel managers; In addition to major OTAs, it supports integration with niche OTAs, local agencies, metasearch and even web booking engines. The important thing is to choose channels that are meaningful to you and build the integration architecture accordingly.

items.q: How to start the OTA integration process?
items.a:
1. Analysis of your PMS and channel manager structure,
  2. clarifying which OTAs to work with,
  3. simplifying/standardizing your room & price plan structure,
  4. Making the necessary configurations on the PMS & channel manager side,
  5. Opening property and connection settings on the OTA side,
  6. mapping and test reservations,
  7. go-live and first period monitoring.

items.q: How to do OTA room/price mapping with Channel Manager?
items.a:
• Each room type in the PMS is mapped to the room type in the channel manager.
  • Each rate plan in the PMS (standard, non-refundable, HB, AI, etc.) is mapped to the rate plans in the OTA.
  • If market/country based distinctions are in use; These are also included in the mapping.
After mapping, a check must be made with test reservations (real or dummy).

items.q: Why are test reservations important in OTA integration?
What should be taken into consideration after OTA integration is activated?
items.a:
• Checking PMS-channel manager-OTA logs frequently in the first days,
  • making sure that prices, inventory and closings appear correctly on all channels,
  • checking whether the description and photo contents are consistent,
  • regularly monitoring error and warning notifications (channel manager/PMS dashboards).

items.q: How long does it take for OTA integration?
items.a: If your PMS & channel manager infrastructure is ready and your room/price structure is not too complex, the integration and testing process for a single OTA can usually be completed within a few days. For chains with many OTAs and complex room/price/market structures, the process may take weeks.

section5.title: Performance & Reporting: What Does OTA Integration Gain?

items.q: How does OTA integration increase revenue?
items.a:
• simultaneous price and inventory updates in all channels → rapid reflection of campaign and price decisions,
  • reduction in false closings → decrease in the number of vacant rooms,
  • channel-based performance reports → more focus on efficient channels.
The right PMS–OTA setup can improve channel efficiency by 20–30% in many hotels.

items.q: How is OTA performance reflected in PMS & channel manager reports?
items.a:
With the right integration; Via PMS:
  • OTA based nights and revenue,
  • market and country based performance,
  • commission/direct revenue comparisons
can be reported. These data are basic inputs for sales and revenue management.

items.q: How does OTA integration reduce the risk of overbooking?
items.a:
• work of all channels connected to the same PMS inventory,
  • elimination of double manual entries,
  • real-time or frequent synchronization,
  • central management of rules such as stop-sell and minimum night
It seriously reduces the risk of overbooking.

items.q: If OTA integration is faulty, how will it affect performance?
items.a:
• wrong price submission → loss of revenue or guest dissatisfaction,
  • wrong room mapping → different room type instead of the room the guest expects,
  • closed dates appearing open → overbooking,
  • missing reservation data → error in reporting and decision processes.

items.q: Which reports should I check regularly after OTA integration?
items.a:
• channel-based revenue and occupancy,
  • market/country-based distribution,
  • cancellation and no-show rates,
  • commission load and net income,
  • mapping and error logs.

section6.title: Wrong Price/Room, Overbooking, Closed Dates, Missing Data

items.q: What causes incorrect price/room transfer and how to prevent it?
items.a:
Causes:
  • incorrect mapping,
  • later manual changes,
  • PMS/price plan structure not suitable for OTA.
Solution:
  • Mapping carefully,
  • making price changes only from PMS or channel manager,
  • Seeing deviations early with test reservations and regular checks.

items.q: How does the double booking (overbooking) problem arise?
items.a:
• Keeping capacities outside PMS (Excel, notepad),
  • some OTAs being excluded from integration,
  • channel manager synchronization problems,
  • stop-sell and closing rules being made manually, not from the system.

items.q: How can I technically prevent overbooking?
items.a:
• managing all salable inventory via PMS & channel manager,
  • avoiding manual stock tracking,
  • including all OTAs within the scope of integration,
  • defining minimum buffer (e.g. manual approval requirement for the last room),
  • regularly checking mapping and synchronization logs.

items.q: How to prevent sales from opening on closed dates?
items.a:
• making closure and stop-sell decisions only from the PMS or channel manager,
  • not making different manual settings from OTA panels,
  • activating the closure rules by testing them,
  • applying extra controlled planning for special periods (holidays, high season).

items.q: What problems does incomplete reservation data cause?
items.a:
• Invisible/missing reservation in PMS → check-in chaos,
  • channel-based inaccuracy in income reports,
  • missing past records of the guest,
  • incorrect forecast and planning.
Therefore, integration logs and channel manager-PMS reservation lists should be compared regularly.

section7.title: Productive Search & Sector Focused OTA Integration (Antalya, Belek, Kemer, Side, Bodrum, Alanya)

items.q: Why is OTA integration critical in Antalya and surrounding destinations?
items.a:
• high number of rooms,
  • working with many OTAs and agencies,
  • peak season and dynamic pricing.
This combination makes manual OTA management impossible; Integration has become a mandatory infrastructure in these regions.

items.q: How should OTA integration be structured in resort destinations such as Belek, Kemer and Side?
items.a:
• country/market based price plans (DE, RU, UK, TR etc.),
  • long stay & package products,
  • precise management of early booking and campaign periods,
  • central management of minimum nights and closures.

items.q: What is important in price/performance regions such as Bodrum and Alanya?
items.a:
• to be able to display the hotel's price-value balance accurately on OTAs,
  • to offer different room types without causing confusion,
  • to manage the inventory correctly during busy cancellation/no-show periods.

items.q: How should OTA integration be positioned for city hotels across Türkiye?
items.a:
• quick response to short stay and last minute reservations,
  • control of MICE and corporate segment and OTA balance,
  • dynamic management of weekday/weekend demand differences.

items.q: How should OTA integration tie in with the hotel digital marketing strategy?
items.a:
• balanced distribution of campaign prices across OTA + web + direct channels,
  • metasearch and remarketing campaigns working without stock & price errors,
  • direct booking campaigns not conflicting with OTA prices.

section8.title: Mini OTA Integration FAQ

items.q: Is integration required for every OTA?
items.a: Technically no; However, for all OTAs with significant volume, integration provides serious time and error savings.

items.q: Is it enough to work OTA only with the channel manager, is PMS integration necessary?
items.a: It is possible in the short term; But if there is no PMS integration, reservations are still entered manually, increasing errors and workload. PMS integration is recommended in the long term.

items.q: Is it right to manage all prices only from the OTA panel?
items.a: No; Prices should be managed from PMS or channel manager and reflected on all channels. Local changes made from the OTA panel may cause parity corruption.

items.q: Is it enough to establish and release the OTA connection once?
items.a: No; Integration should be reviewed regularly due to mapping changes, new price plans and OTA terms.

items.q: Is it right to look for integration errors only on the OTA side?
items.a: Not; Every link of the PMS, channel manager and OTA chain must be checked.

items.q: Is it necessary to book tests for every change in the integration?
items.a: Yes, especially when there is a room/price/mapping change; A small test reservation can catch a big bug early.

items.q: Do I have to keep prices 100% the same on every channel?
items.a: It depends on your rate parity policies and OTA agreements; But even if there is a difference, it must be conscious and rule-based.

items.q: Is it mandatory to work with a single supplier in OTA integration?
items.a: No; However, establishing a simple, single-centered structure as much as possible on the PMS and channel manager side reduces complexity.

items.q: Is an IT team required for OTA integration?
items.a: Not necessarily; Most PMS and channel manager integrations can be managed via the panel. However, expert supervision is recommended.

items.q: Can I get the OTA Integration service only as audit + roadmap?
items.a: Yes; You can receive a consultancy package that analyzes your current integration structure, shows mapping and risks, and includes the correct installation steps.

items.q: What exactly is channel management?
items.a:
Channel management; It is the process of managing the balance of:
  • price,
  • inventory,
  • campaign and visibility,
  • commission and cost
in your hotel's OTA, website, call center, agency and corporate sales channels under a single strategy and architecture. The aim is not "let the room be sold no matter where it is sold"; The right room should be sold in the right channel, at the right price and at the right cost.

items.q: Why is channel management so important?
items.a:
Because:
  • OTAs are strong,
  • a significant portion of guests travel between web/OTA/call center,
  • marketing budgets are limited,
  • wrong channel balance affects both revenue and brand perception.
Correct channel management; It allows you to establish a healthy triangle of occupancy, income and commission.

items.q: Is channel management just OTA management?
items.a:
No. OTAs are an important part, but channel management is the whole balance of:
  • OTA (Booking, Expedia etc.),
  • hotel website (direct booking),
  • call center & reservation line,
  • agencies and wholesalers,
  • MICE/corporate sales.

items.q: Do I have to use channel manager?
items.a:
Technically no; However:
  • if you are working with more than one OTA,
  • if you are trying to enter price/inventory manually,
  • if errors and overbooking have increased
channel manager is an almost mandatory component for channel management.

items.q: Does channel management only make sense for large hotels?
items.a: No. As your number of channels + number of rooms + revenue targets grow, channel management becomes important, even if you are a boutique hotel. Even small hotels benefit significantly from strategic channel management, especially if OTA volume is high in tourist areas.

items.q: Who is the Channel Management FAQ suitable for?
items.a:
• For all hotel and tourism brands that have OTA-web-call center mix,
  • increased commission burden,
  • experienced direct booking problems that go to OTA instead of web,
  • have price/inventory confusion and parity problems.

items.q: What is channel management and what does it do?
items.a: It allows you to gather your hotel's OTA, web and call center sales under a single strategy and optimize occupancy and revenue with the right channel mix and pricing.

items.q: How should I establish the OTA–web–call center balance for my hotel?
items.a: First, clarify your goal (occupancy–income–direct share); You should establish separate but compatible roles and goals for OTA, web, and call center.

items.q: What problems does channel manager solve?
items.a: It allows you to manage prices and inventory from a single panel, update them simultaneously in all OTAs, and technologically reduce the risk of overbooking.

items.q: How can I offset high OTA commission?
items.a: When using OTAs for occupancy and visibility; You can balance it by increasing the direct share with campaigns, loyalty and price advantages on the web and call center side.

items.q: What does incorrect channel balance cost?
items.a: Problems such as high commissions, reservations going to OTA instead of the web, occupancy-income imbalance and price/campaign confusion.

items.q: Who is the Channel Management service suitable for?
items.a: It is suitable for hotels that use OTA and direct sales channels together and want to optimize their income & commission balance, especially in tourism destinations such as Antalya, Belek, Kemer, Side, Bodrum and Alanya.

section3.title: Scope of Service: Channel Setup, Price & Inventory Strategies

items.q: What does the channel management service include?
items.a:
• analysis of current channel mix (OTA, web, call center, agency, etc.),
  • mapping of PMS–OTA–web–call center flow,
  • channel manager configuration recommendations,
  • price & inventory strategy (BAR, packages, campaigns),
  • allotment and stop-sale setups,
  • creation of measurement and reporting structure.

items.q: How should the OTA–web–call center balance be established?
items.a:
General principle:
  • OTA → visibility and new guest acquisition,
  • web → direct and lower commission booking,
  • call center → winning undecided guests, upsell/cross-sell, multilingual support.
The role of each channel should be clearly defined and targets should be set accordingly.

items.q: How does channel management tie into pricing strategies?
items.a:
• Commission and campaign strategy for OTAs,
  • direct booking incentive for the web (flexible cancellation, extra benefits, packages),
  • upsell/cross-sell scripts for the call center,
  • market and season-based dynamic pricing
should be managed under the same roof.

items.q: What does using channel manager bring to channel management?
items.a:
• price/inventory management of all OTAs from a single panel,
  • mapping and rate plan management,
  • central management of closure/stop-sell and minimum night rules,
  • reduced risk of error and overbooking,
  • possibility of reporting and log tracking.

items.q: How do allotment and stop-sale work in channel management?
items.a:
• Allotment:The number of rooms or quota reserved for reservations for a specific channel/partner.
  • Stop-sale:Closing sales on specific dates or room types for a specific channel or all channels.
When used correctly; They provide balance and price control across channels.

section4.title: Process & Operation: Channel Setup, Allotment, Stop-Sale

items.q: How to start the channel management process?
items.a:
1. Current channel list (OTA, web, call center, agency, etc.) is extracted.
  2. Occupancy, revenue and commission contribution of each channel is analyzed.
  3. PMS–channel manager–OTA and web flows are mapped.
  4. targets (direct share, total revenue, specific channel shares) are defined.
  5. price and inventory strategy are updated accordingly.

items.q: How should the OTA–web–call center balance be planned?
items.a:
• It can be planned with tactics such as giving visibility to OTAs and maintaining the web/direct price balance in high season,
  • highlighting direct and call center campaigns in low season,
  • keeping some room types only for web/call center,
  • reducing the share of high-commission OTAs in a controlled manner in the long term
.

items.q: What are the common mistakes in allotment management?
items.a:
• giving more quota than necessary to a particular OTA or agency,
  • not monitoring quota usage regularly,
  • not adjusting the allotment/individual stock balance when occupancy increases,
  • trying to manage allotment only with paper/Excel outside of PMS.

items.q: How should stop-sale management be done?
items.a:
• It is necessary to make stop-sale decisions through PMS or channel manager,
  • Do not make manual "different" closures on OTA panels,
  • decide in advance which channel will be closed during high demand or special periods (holidays, festivals, etc.),
  • These decisions should be planned together with the revenue management team.

items.q: How should the channel management strategy be integrated with the call center and PMS side?
items.a:
• call center script and price information,
  • Room/price planning in PMS,
  • channel manager and OTA settings
should be part of the same strategy.

section5.title: Performance & Reporting: Channel Efficiency and Revenue Impact

items.q: How does channel management affect revenue and occupancy?
items.a:
• highlights the right room types on the right channels,
  • reduces dependence on high-commission channels,
  • increases direct booking share,
  • reduces false closings and price errors.
All of these directly affect total revenue and profitability.

items.q: What metrics should I use to track channel performance?
items.a:
• channel based night and revenue,
  • commission rate and net income,
  • cancellation/no-show rates,
  • market/country based channel performance,
  • direct vs OTA share,
  • web conversion rate,
  • call center conversion rate.

items.q: How to read channel manager performance?
items.a:
• mapping error and warning logs,
  • price/inventory synchronization success,
  • OTA-based update error rates,
  • frequency of integration-related overbooking and wrong price cases.

items.q: How is price & inventory strategy reflected in reports?
items.a:
• analyzes should be made such as which channel and price plan performed better in which period,
  • which campaigns produced higher occupancy and revenue in which channel,
  • which room types sold better in which channels
.

items.q: How often should channel management reports be reviewed?
items.a:
• operational: weekly,
  • strategic (price and channel mix): monthly/quarterly.
For seasonal hotels, pre/mid/post-season analysis is critical to the big picture.

section6.title: Wrong Channel Balance, High Commission, Direct Escape, Price Confusion

items.q: What does incorrect channel balance cost?
items.a:
• high commission cost,
  • over-dependence on some OTAs and agencies,
  • web and call center remaining idle,
  • periods when we “had to close channels”.

items.q: How can high OTA commission be offset?
items.a:
• extra benefit for direct (flexible cancellation, room preference, small gestures),
  • positioning packages and campaigns primarily on the web/call center,
  • optimizing the OTA mix according to share and performance analysis,
  • consciously reducing the share of some OTAs in the long term.

items.q: How to reduce direct bookings going to OTA instead of the web?
items.a:
• clear and attractive direct booking offer on your website,
  • Message and remarketing that will attract the guest who sees you on OTA to the web or call center,
  • good establishment of web price/parity balance,
  • better cancellation and payment conditions for direct channels.

items.q: What are the consequences of uncontrolled price chaos?
items.a:
• guest sees different prices on different channels → loss of trust,
  • Disagreement with OTA and business partners,
  • pricing without yield (unnecessary discounts or excessively high prices).

items.q: What will wrong channel balance and incorrect installation affect in the long run?
items.a:
• revenue and profitability,
  • guest and OTA relations,
  • operational load and team fatigue,
  • price & brand positioning of the hotel.

section7.title: Productive Search & Sector Focused Channel Management (Antalya, Belek, Kemer, Side, Bodrum, Alanya)

items.q: Why is channel management so critical in Antalya and surrounding destinations?
items.a:
• domestic + foreign multiple markets,
  • high number of rooms and seasonal pressure,
  • working with many OTAs and agencies.
In these dynamics, wrong channel balance leads to rapid losses and unnecessary commission costs.

items.q: Which channel priorities come to the fore in resort areas such as Belek, Kemer and Side?
items.a:
• OTA + direct campaigns for early booking,
  • strategies to increase direct share in high season,
  • golf, wellness, family etc. Adjusting channel weights according to concepts.

items.q: What should the channel strategy be in price/performance destinations such as Bodrum and Alanya?
items.a:
• OTA listings that accurately describe the price-value balance,
  • web/call center campaigns that highlight long stay opportunities,
  • segment-based channel preferences (family with children, young couple, etc.).

items.q: How should channel management be shaped for City hotels?
items.a:
• corporate/agency channels for business travel and MICE,
  • OTA + web campaigns for short stay and weekend,
  • dynamic pricing and intraday price management.

items.q: How should channel management integrate with the hotel digital marketing strategy?
items.a:
• Campaign messages and prices should be compatible across all channels,
  • Direct campaigns should be designed so as not to conflict with OTA prices,
  • Google Ads, Meta and Metasearch campaigns should be planned together with the channel strategy.

section8.title: Mini Channel Management FAQ

items.q: Do I have to be at every OTA?
items.a: No; Analyzing inefficient channels and simplifying your portfolio often yields better results.

items.q: Does it make sense to work only with OTA and ignore the web/call center?
items.a: It provides occupancy in the short term, but in the long term you will experience high commission and low direct pay problems.

items.q: Does channel management = just “price” management?
items.a: No; Inventory, campaign, visibility, comment score and call center integration are also part of channel management.

items.q: Can channel management be done without a channel manager?
items.a: With very few channels and low volume, yes; But as the number of OTAs and volume increases, channel manager becomes almost mandatory.

items.q: Do I have to maintain Parity 100%?
items.a: It depends on your contract and strategy; However, unconscious parity degradation can lead to serious problems.

items.q: Is it right to sell the same room types across all channels?
items.a: Not always; You can create direct booking appeal by allocating some room types to direct channels only.

items.q: Is it better to use completely free inventory instead of allotment?
items.a: In some cases yes; but in certain agency/OTA relationships, allotment is still a strategic tool.

items.q: Is channel management only the job of the revenue manager?
items.a: No; sales, marketing, call center and operations teams need to work together.

items.q: Is it enough to set and release the channel management strategy once a year?
items.a: No; Channel strategy should be reconsidered as season, market and competition change.

items.q: Can I get the Channel Management service only as "audit + strategy"?
items.a: Yes; You can get a consultancy package that analyzes your current channel mix and efficiency, shows risks and opportunities, and offers a new strategy & action plan and carries out the implementation with your own team.

items.q: Does “online selling” just mean using OTA?

Not. OTAs are an important part of online sales, but strategy;
  • web booking engine,

together.

items.q: Why should OTA + web + metasearch + call center be considered together?

Because the guest;
  • sees you on OTA and looks at your website,
  • cannot make a decision on the web and writes to WhatsApp/call center,
  • When you compare prices on Google, you come across it in metasearch.
Online sales strategy; It brings this omnichannel behavior under a single revenue plan.

items.q: What should be the main goal in online sales: occupancy or profitability?
items.a: Both of them. However, it is more accurate to think in terms of occupancy in the short term and profitability in the medium and long term. Constantly "filling occupancy by undercutting prices" will weaken your brand and revenue structure in the long run.

items.q: Can the online sales strategy remain constant all year?

No. As season, market and economic conditions change;
  • price levels,
  • channel weights,
  • campaign periods
should be reconsidered. Especially in destinations such as Antalya, Belek, Kemer, Side, Bodrum, Alanya, a separate look is required for the before/middle/after season.

items.q: Where do I start to get more bookings from my hotel website?

section3.title: Service Scope: Web, OTA, Metasearch & Performance Ads

items.q: What does Online Sales Service include?
items.a:
• web booking engine and site conversion analysis,

  • metasearch (Google Hotel Ads etc.) setup,
  • Integration of Google/META ads and online sales flow,
  • PMS–channel manager–OTA–web booking engine evaluation of links,

items.q: Why is the web booking engine critical for online sales?
items.a:
• When the guest presses the reservation button on your website,
  • the screen he sees,
  • ease of selection,
  • perception of speed and security
determines whether he will complete the reservation or not. A weak booking engine may push “intended” guests to OTA.

items.q: Where is the OTA balance in online sales?
items.a:
OTAs:
  • showcase that makes you stand out in certain markets,
  • critical for occupancy and the start of the season,
but; Relying solely on OTA means high commission and poor direct structure. OTA balance is at the heart of the online sales strategy.

items.q: How do metasearch channels (Google Hotel Ads etc.) work?
items.a:
• As soon as the guest searches for your hotel,
  • it shows your web price side by side with OTA prices,
  • directs the clicking guest to your hotel web booking engine.
When installed correctly, it is a powerful tool for converting the hotel he sees on OTA into a direct reservation.

items.q: What is the relationship between performance ads (Google Ads, Meta Ads) and online sales?
items.a:
• Showing the correct message and price to the guest searching for "hotel name + price" on Google,
  • capturing the guest at the decision stage with remarketing and funnel campaigns on social media,
  • bringing this traffic to a well-optimized web & booking engine,
is the performance engine of the online sales strategy.

section4.title: Process & Operation: How to Establish an Online Sales Strategy?

items.q: How to start an online sales strategy?
items.a:
1. Current channel mix (OTA/web/call center/metasearch) analysis,
  2. measurement of web reservation rate and conversion rates,
  3. OTA commission and performance analysis,
  4. review of advertising (Google/META) and metasearch campaigns,
  5. determination of direct reservation targets,
  6. creation of new price & channel plan.

items.q: What can be the first 3 steps to increase web booking rate?
items.a:
1. UX & speed: Website design, mobile usability, page speed.
  2. Booking engine optimization: Number of steps, fields, trust and payment options.
  3. Direct value proposition: A clear “why here” advantage over OTA.

items.q: What should I do to reduce OTA addiction?
items.a:
• attractive benefits for web & call center (flexible cancellation, special request, small gestures),
  • strengthening direct booking with metasearch and brand search campaigns,
  • slowly reducing the share of low-performance OTAs,
  • establishing remarketing flows that will attract guests who find you in OTAs to the web/call center.

items.q: How to establish the right price strategy in online sales?
items.a:
• BAR (Best Available Rate) logic,
  • season, market, channel-based differences,
  • parity and advantage balance between OTA-web-call center,
  • channel-based planning of campaigns and packages,
  • revenue management data (pick-up, forecast, pace).
All should be considered together.

items.q: How should web-OTA-call center integration be on the technical side?
items.a:
• Price/inventory flow to OTAs via PMS and channel manager,
  • web booking engine integrated with PMS or channel manager,
  • call center reservations are opened under the same structure in PMS.
In this way, sales in all channels can be monitored from a single database (PMS).

section5.title: Performance & Reporting: How Well Does Online Sales Work?

items.q: What metrics should I use to track online sales performance?
items.a:
• web conversion rate (site to reservation),
  • channel based revenue and occupancy,
  • OTA vs direct share,
  • number of reservations sourced from metasearch,
  • campaign (Google/META) based ROAS and reservations,
  • average commission/profit margin.

items.q: How to increase web booking rate?
items.a:
• simplifying the site and booking engine if it is multi-step and slow,
  • describing the rooms and price clearly, understandably and visually powerfully,
  • highlighting the trust elements (comments, security, payment),
  • offering logical advantages that are “only for the web” (benefits, not discounts).

items.q: How to reduce OTA addiction?
items.a:
• setting a target for direct booking share,
  • focusing on attracting the subsequent reservations of guests coming from OTAs to direct,
  • establishing a strong value proposition and loyalty structure in direct,
  • planning marketing campaigns with a web/call center focus instead of OTA.

items.q: How do metasearch channels (Google Hotel Ads etc.) work?
items.a:
• price and availability are synchronized via PMS–channel manager–metasearch,
  • when the guest searches for the hotel on Google, the web price and OTA prices appear side by side,
  • there is an opportunity to increase direct booking by pulling the click to the web booking engine.
If not installed and followed correctly; It spends the budget but cannot produce results.

items.q: How often should reports be checked in online sales?
items.a:
• weekly: campaign and channel performance,
  • monthly: channel shares, commission load, web conversion rates,
  • seasonal: strategy revision and lesson learned analyses.

section6.title: Low Web Bookings, High OTA Commission, Campaign Inefficiency

items.q: What are the most common reasons for low web booking rate?
items.a:
• weak or insecure-looking booking engine,
  • slow and mobile-friendly website,
  • lack of a clear advantage for direct,
  • clearer and more attractive appearance in OTA,
  • confused price and room description.

items.q: Why is high OTA commission a critical problem?
items.a:
• With every OTA reservation, your hotel's profit margin decreases,
  • A hotel that grows only with OTA becomes more fragile in times of crisis,
  • brand control and customer relationship shifts to OTA.

items.q: How to understand inefficiencies in metasearch and campaign management?
items.a:
• low number of reservations compared to the budget spent,
  • Campaigns falling below ROAS targets,
  • especially clicks that do not convert into direct reservations,
  • incorrect or unclear targeting.

items.q: What happens in the long run if the online sales strategy is designed incorrectly?
items.a:
• being stuck in constant price cuts and campaigns,
  • decline in profitability,
  • weakening of brand perception,
  • direct channels remaining weak and OTA addiction becoming chronic.

items.q: How dangerous is the “let's just fill it out, we'll see about the profitability later” approach in online sales?
items.a:
Provides occupancy in the short term; but in the long run:
  • your price will be positioned below,
  • you will not attract the right audience but only the audience looking for the "cheapest",
  • your brand value and future pricing power will weaken.

  • OTA balance with MICE and corporate agreements,
  • campaigns for mobile and last minute reservations.

items.q: What should be taken into consideration when using metasearch in Türkiye in general?
items.a:
• correct PMS–channel manager–metasearch connection,
  • using the budget in the correct segments and dates,
  • clear tracking and conversion tracking,
  • Balance between OTA prices and web prices.

items.q: How should the online sales strategy integrate with hotel digital marketing?
items.a:
• SEO, SEM, social media, metasearch and OTA visibility;
  • must be parts of the same revenue and channel strategy,
  • campaign message and price should not conflict in different channels,
  • direct and OTA roles should be designed "together".

section8.title: Mini Online Selling FAQ

items.q: Is a web booking engine required for every hotel?
items.a: Yes; If you want to be a direct channel in online sales, a properly working booking engine is essential.

items.q: Is just working with OTA enough in the long run?
items.a: It provides occupancy in the short term, but in the long term it creates high commission and direct independence problems.

items.q: Do you need a big budget to enter Metasearch?
items.a: No; With the right targeting and controlled budget, it can be run efficiently, especially in brand name searches.

items.q: If my website is poor on mobile, how much will my online sales be affected?
items.a: Seriously. Many guests search and book the hotel from their mobile device; A mobile site with a slow or poor UX means direct loss.

items.q: Is it a problem to be strong on OTA and weak on the web?
items.a: Yes; This situation makes OTA dependency permanent and increases the commission burden.

items.q: Should I highlight price or value when selling online?
items.a: Price is important but not enough alone; It is healthier in the long run to explain the value offered (concept, experience, flexibility).

items.q: Can I grow my online sales with just Google Ads?
items.a: Google Ads is a powerful tool, but it alone is not enough; Site & booking engine optimization, OTA balance and metasearch are also important.

items.q: Is it enough to update the online sales strategy once a year?
items.a: No; It is necessary to re-look at least during pre-mid-post season and important market changes.

items.q: Should I go to every market with the same price when selling online?
items.a: No; It may be more efficient to use price and campaign strategies that differ according to market dynamics; but parity and agreements must be observed.

items.q: Can I get the Online Sales service only as "audit + strategy"?
items.a: Yes; You can obtain a strategy document that analyzes your current online sales structure, shows risks and opportunities, and includes the channel-price-campaign balance and carries out the implementation with your own team.

In this meeting, we clarify together:

intro.p3:

.

aiCapsule.title: Brief Summary
aiCapsule.text: Reservation management; It is the management of all reservations coming from web, OTA, call center/WhatsApp, agency and MICE channels on a single "real source" (preferably PMS) without overlapping, with complete guest and revenue information. In a healthy model, OTA reservations flow to PMS via channel manager, web booking engine works integrated with PMS or channel manager, and call center reservations are opened in PMS with standard fields (source/channel, segment, note format). Thus, the risk of overbooking is reduced, reservations that do not fall into the PMS are detected early, and pick-up/forecast data becomes reliable for revenue management. Critical control points; mapping and log tracking, daily/weekly comparison reports, single-center management of stop-sell/closing decisions and buffer inventory approach in certain periods. Guest data integrity (email, country, segment, preference) is the primary fuel for CRM, remarketing and loyalty beyond booking; Disorganized records produce invisible losses on both the operational and revenue sides. Especially in high-volume destinations such as Antalya–Belek–Kemer–Side–Bodrum–Alanya, standardizing processes with written SOPs, regular inspection of integrations and periodic control of reports transform reservation management from a "source of stress" into a system that preserves income and reputation.

voiceSummary.title: Brief Summary
voiceSummary.text: Reservation management; It is a process structure that collects web, OTA and call center reservations on a single screen in PMS, reduces overbooking and keeps guest data properly.

voiceQueries.title: Frequently Asked Sample Queries
voiceQueries.q1: What is reservation management?
voiceQueries.q2: How can I find reservations that are not included in PMS?
voiceQueries.q3: How to prevent overbooking?
