items.q: What exactly is reservation management?
items.a:
Reservation management; Requests coming to your hotel from all channels such as:
  • web reservations,
  • OTA reservations,
  • call center & WhatsApp reservations,
  • agency and MICE reservations
requests:
  • on the same PMS,
  • without conflict,
  • with complete guest and income information,
  • in a revenue-oriented manner. It refers to managing the flow
.

items.q: Why is reservation management critical for hotels?
items.a:
Because small mistakes made during the reservation process are returned as:
  • overbooking (double booking),
  • wrong room/price,
  • reservation not recorded in PMS,
  • missing guest data
. These mean:
  • guest dissatisfaction,
  • problem with OTA/agency,
  • revenue loss and operational chaos
.

items.q: Are reservation management and OTA/channel management the same thing?
items.a:
Complementary but different layers:
  • Channel management → how much inventory and at what price you will release on which channel,
  • Reservation management → how the reservations coming from these channels are recorded, controlled and tracked on the PMS.
Reservation management is incomplete without correct channel management; Channel management without proper booking management is risky.

items.q: Who is the Reservation Management FAQ suitable for?
items.a:
• For all hotel and tourism businesses that, despite using PMS, still make reservations in Excel/notebook,
  • cannot see web/OTA/call center reservations at a glance,
  • experience overbooking and false reservation errors,
  • cannot collect guest data properly
.

items.q: Is it “reservation management = entering reservations into PMS”?
items.a:
No. Registering in PMS is just the last step. Reservation management:
  • means being aware of what kind of demand comes in which channel,
  • designing the process revenue-oriented,
  • establishing the PMS-OTA-channel manager-call center connection correctly,
  • continuous improvement with control and reporting
.

items.q: Why is reservation management extra important in destinations such as Antalya–Belek–Kemer–Side–Bodrum–Alanya?
items.a:
Because:
  • number of rooms is high,
  • OTA and agency diversity is high,
  • seasonal pressure and price competition are intense.
In this combination, dispersed reservation management very quickly leads to problems that will affect future seasons.

items.q: What is reservation management and what does it do?
items.a: Reservation management; It is a process structure that collects web, OTA and call center reservations in a single flow on PMS, prevents overbooking and manages guest data properly.

items.q: How do I combine web, OTA and call center bookings in one system?
items.a: By connecting PMS-channel manager-OTA integration and web booking engine-call center flows to PMS; You should collect all reservation records on a single PMS.

items.q: How do I prevent overbooking?
items.a: By managing the inventory in all channels via PMS & channel manager, minimizing the use of manual channels/updates and defining stop-sell/closing rules through the system.

items.q: How do I solve the problem of reservations not being recorded in PMS?
items.a: Regularly compare OTA/channel manager logs, PMS reservation list and manually opened records; You must identify and fix integration errors and process gaps.

items.q: How should I structure the reservation flow in a revenue-oriented manner?
items.a: During the reservation process; You should plan room types, upsell/cross-sell opportunities, minimum night, package and price rules together with revenue management and apply the same logic in call center/web/OTA flows.

items.q: Who is the Reservation Management FAQ suitable for?
items.a: Especially for hotels in tourism destinations who use PMS, OTA, web and call center channels and say “everything is together, I cannot see a clear picture”.

section3.title: Service Scope: Channels, PMS, Data Integrity

items.q: What does the reservation management service include?
items.a:
• analysis of web, OTA, call center and agency reservation flows,
  • evaluation of PMS–channel manager–OTA integration structure,
  • flow design for deduplication of all reservations on PMS,
  • detection of overbooking risk points and solution suggestions,
  • standardization of guest data (name, e-mail, country, segment, etc.),
  • reporting and control mechanisms. constructing.

items.q: How to deduplicate OTA–web–call center reservations in PMS?
items.a:
• OTA reservations are written to PMS via the channel manager,
  • web booking engine is integrated into PMS or channel manager and transferred to PMS,
  • call center reservations are opened directly via PMS.
It is essential for deduplication that all reservations can be seen on the same PMS screen.

items.q: How does reservation management affect revenue management?
items.a:
• clear visibility of segment and channel-based reservations,
  • accuracy of forecast and pick-up analyses,
  • quick price/room decisions (e.g. which channel should we block, where should we load?)
entirely depends on the quality of reservation management. Broken booking processes make accurate revenue decisions impossible.

items.q: Where are the call center reservation flows in this structure?
items.a:
The call center is especially critical for:
  • winning the undecided guest,
  • upsell/cross-sell,
  • multilingual support
. However, call center reservations must be opened via PMS; It should never remain in the external system/Excel.

items.q: Why is guest data integrity so important?
items.a:
• Accurate and complete guest data is essential to recognize repeat guests,
  • to manage CRM and loyalty processes,
  • to produce country/market based performance reports,
  • to carry out campaigns and remarketing
. Messy reservation management; Creates an incomplete or inconsistent guest database.

section4.title: Process & Operation: Single Flow, Overbooking, Control Mechanisms

items.q: How to start the reservation management process?
items.a:
1. Make the current reservation flow map (web, OTA, call center, agency).
  2. Determine which reservations enter PMS automatically and which manually.
  3. Collect overbooking and reservation cases that do not fall into PMS.
  4. Check PMS–channel manager–OTA integrations.
  5. Design and test the new “single flow” process.

items.q: How are OTA–web–call center reservations standardized in PMS?
items.a:
• using the same room and price plan structure,
  • using the same segment and source codes,
  • keeping special requests and notes in the same format in PMS note fields,
  • following the cancellation/change flow on PMS for all channels.

items.q: How to prevent overbooking?
items.a:
• managing all salable inventory from PMS & channel manager,
  • Minimizing manual stock changes in OTA panels,
  • Not keeping Excel/ledger stock outside PMS,
  • taking stop-sell and closing decisions through the integrated system,
  • using "buffer" inventory in certain periods (extra attention for end rooms).

items.q: How to detect reservations that are not transferred to PMS?
items.a:
• Regularly comparing OTA & channel manager reservation reports with the reservation list in PMS,
  • receiving "control reports" at regular intervals (daily/weekly),
  • following integration logs,
  • defining a separate control process for manually entered reservations.

items.q: How should I structure the reservation flow in a revenue-oriented manner?
items.a:
• taking into account which room types are sold on which channel,
  • which channel you booked on which dates,
  • minimum night, package and campaign rules
; You should design a reservation flow that aims to generate maximum revenue depending on which channel the guest comes from.

section5.title: Performance & Reporting: Results of Reservation Processes

items.q: What metrics should I use to monitor reservation management performance?
items.a:
• channel-based reservation number and revenue,
  • OTA–web–call center shares,
  • number of overbooking cases,
  • number of reservations not transferred to PMS,
  • missing guest data rate,
  • cancellation and no-show rates.

items.q: How are OTA–web–call center reservations reported in PMS?
items.a:
In a correctly configured PMS;
  • If the Source/Channel fields are used correctly,
  • which channel each reservation came from,
  • which segment it is in,
  • on which dates it is concentrated
can be reported.

items.q: How do booking processes affect revenue management?
items.a:
If the data is corrupted, revenue decisions are also corrupted. Correct reservation management ensures accurate data such as
  • actual occupancy and pick-up,
  • channel and segment-based distribution,
  • market/country performance
; Thus, pricing & revenue decisions are on solid ground.

items.q: How does reservation management affect guest satisfaction?
items.a:
• accurate room/price information,
  • no overbooking,
  • special requests being visible in PMS notes,
  • the feeling of "waiting for you" at check-in
determines the guest's first impression. In a hotel that does not have strong reservation management, the guest experience begins to "crack" even before reaching the reception.

items.q: How often should reservation management reports be checked?
items.a:
• operational: daily/weekly (overbooking, reservations not included in PMS, mapping errors),
  • strategic: monthly/quarterly (channel shares, revenue distribution, market analyses).

section6.title: Messy Reservation Records, Conflicting Reservations, Missing Data

items.q: What does messy reservation records mean, what harm does it do?
items.a:
• If some reservations remain in PMS,
  • some in Excel,
  • some in e-mail folders,
  • some in the OTA panel;
it means that the real occupancy and revenue are not visible anywhere. This creates risks on both the operation and revenue side.

items.q: How do conflicting reservations occur?
items.a:
• manual stock tracking,
  • non-integration channel or agency,
  • non-PMS reservation records,
  • late or incomplete closing/stop-sell transactions.

items.q: What happens if I have to manage overbooking?
items.a:
• you may have to move the guest to another hotel,
  • guest satisfaction and OTA/partner relations may be damaged,
  • in-operational stress and costs increase.
Good reservation management allows you to make overbooking a "controlled strategic choice" rather than an "accident" (and often it is not necessary).

items.q: What problem does missing guest data (email, country, segment) cause?
items.a:
• loss of remarketing and remarketing opportunities,
  • inability to perform segment-based analysis,
  • lack of market and country-based performance reports,
  • making it difficult to establish loyalty and CRM processes.

items.q: Why are reservations that do not go through PMS critical?
items.a:
• missing guests in check-in lists,
  • errors in accounting and income reports,
  • risk of conflict in room planning,
  • shock of "no record" when the guest arrives at the hotel.
Therefore, routine checks are essential to "detect reservations that are not included in the PMS".

section7.title: Productive Search & Industry-Focused Reservation Management Questions

items.q: Why is reservation management critical for resort hotels in Turkey?
items.a:
• high number of rooms,
  • OTA + agency + direct mix,
  • peak season pressure,
make manual or dispersed reservation management impossible.

items.q: What should be focused on in reservation management in regions such as Antalya, Belek, Kemer, Side, Bodrum, Alanya?
items.a:
• Robustness of PMS–channel manager–OTA integration,
  • Duplicating OTA–web–call center reservations in PMS,
  • clear reporting of market/country based reservation flow,
  • overbooking control.

items.q: How does reservation management differ for City hotels?
items.a:
• short accommodation and last minute reservations,
  • corporate agreements,
  • MICE reservations,
require special arrangements. It is important to manage these flows under the same roof, without mixing with each other in the PMS.

items.q: How to deduplicate OTA–web–call center reservations in PMS?
items.a:
• by using the "source/channel" field correctly for each reservation,
  • by ensuring card/ID uniqueness instead of opening a new record for the same guest,
  • by adding reservation numbers and OTA references to PMS records.

items.q: With which departments should reservation management work together for Türkiye in general?
items.a:
• reservation & call center,
  • reception/front office,
  • sales & marketing,
  • revenue management,
  • accounting.
They should all talk through the same PMS and reservation process architecture.

section8.title: Mini Reservation Management FAQ

items.q: Should the reservation management process be in writing for every hotel?
items.a: Yes; Written reservation SOPs are very useful to reduce errors and uncertainty, especially during personnel changes.

items.q: Does just using PMS mean reservation management is good?
items.a: No; If PMS is used incorrectly or some channels fall outside PMS, reservation management is still poor.

items.q: Is reservation management necessary for small hotels as well?
items.a: Yes; Even if the number of rooms is small, reservation management with a mix of several OTAs and web/call centers is important.

items.q: Can reservation management be carried out by outsourcing teams?
items.a: Yes; With the right SOP, integration and reporting, a reservation management model can be established with both internal and external resource teams.

items.q: Does it still make sense to keep all bookings in Excel?
items.a: Not above a certain volume; The risks of errors, overbooking and data loss are very high.

items.q: Is it enough to just work with OTA reports?
items.a: No; It is necessary to look at combining PMS reports covering all channels with OTA reports.

items.q: Are call center scripts important when managing reservations?
items.a: Yes; Reservation flow, PMS integration and upsell/cross-sell steps on the call center side should be standardized with scripts.

items.q: Is it realistic to completely reset overbooking?
items.a: Technically, it is possible to get it close to zero; However, some hotels may choose to do strategic overbooking. The important thing is that this is conscious and controlled.

items.q: How should I prepare reservation data for CRM and loyalty systems?
items.a: By keeping guest information in PMS with standard fields (e-mail, country, segment, etc.); You must transfer or integrate it to external systems in a healthy way.

items.q: Can I get the Reservation Management service only as “audit + process design”?
items.a: Yes; It is possible to purchase a consultancy package that analyzes your current reservation flows, shows risks and opportunities, offers PMS-OTA-call center integration suggestions and SOP draft, and carries out the application with your own team.

section9.title: Collaboration and Action Questions for Reservations Management

items.a:
• the type of your hotel (resort, city, boutique, chain, etc.),
  • the PMS, channel managers and OTAs you use,
  • your web booking engine and call center structure,
  • the reservation problems you are currently experiencing (overbooking, reservations not recorded in PMS, missing guest data, messy records, etc.),
  • your targeted improvement areas (correct data, data integrity, revenue-oriented flow). etc.)
When you share a short brief with; A Reservation Management roadmap and proposal can be prepared, including current situation analysis, reservation process architecture, integration & SOP recommendations.

items.q: What does the “consult an expert” call clarify on the reservation management side?
items.a:
• We discuss together which channels you receive reservations from,
  • where the data is broken (reservations not included in PMS, Excel, e-mail, etc.),
  • overbooking and error points,
  • critical flows that affect revenue & guest experience
. Thus, reservation management is not just a job where records are entered into PMS; It becomes a strategic process that carries revenue, guest data and operations.

items.q: Who is the Looker Studio Reporting FAQ suitable for?

items.q: How to set up automatic email reports in Looker Studio?

intro.p1:
The era of hotels making pricing and channel decisions based solely on "share" is over. Especially in destinations such as Antalya–Belek–Kemer–Side–Bodrum–Alanya:
  • How full are the competitors?
  • On what date and at what price?
  • On which channel are they more visible?
  • Where does your price and occupancy level stand according to this table?
Making price and channel decisions without answering these questions means revenue management with your eyes closed.
intro.p2: This is where the Benchmark Analysis FAQ comes in: We clarify competitive set identification, market & price comparisons, occupancy and revenue benchmark reports, and positioning strategy step by step.

items.q: What exactly is benchmark analysis?
items.a:
Benchmark analysis; It is the process of comparing your hotel's performance indicators such as:
  • price,
  • occupancy,
  • income,
  • visibility
with the competitor set and regional average you have chosen. The aim is to ensure that you are positioned based onmarket and competitor data rather than "just looking at yourself".

items.q: What does benchmark analysis do for my hotel?
items.a:
• It allows you to see on which dates you are more expensive/cheaper than your competitors,
  • to understand the situation of your competitors while your occupancy increases,
  • to support price, channel and campaign decisions with data,
  • to make the right “positioning” in your target markets and segments.

items.q: What risks does pricing without benchmark data carry?
items.a:
• undercutting prices unnecessarily,
  • underestimating the demand level of the market,
  • positioning too far below/above competitors,
  • making campaign and channel decisions intuitively.
Result: you will either “stay cheap” and reduce the profit, or “stay expensive” and miss the demand.

items.q: What sources are used in benchmark analysis?
items.a:
• OTA price monitoring tools,
  • regional market data (ADR, occupancy, RevPAR benchmark reports),
  • metasearch and OTA visibility data,
  • your internal data (PMS & channel performance).
These are interpreted together to form a “big picture”.

items.q: Who is Benchmark Analysis FAQ suitable for?
items.a:
Especially:
  • operating in highly competitive destinations (Antalya–Belek–Kemer–Side–Bodrum–Alanya),
  • wanting to make more data-oriented pricing and campaign decisions,
  • “What are competitors doing?” For all hotels looking for a systematic answer to the question.

items.q: Is benchmark analysis only meaningful for the luxury segment?
items.a: No. Price/performance, budget, city, resort… whatever segment you are in; You have to see what your competitors, who play to the same audience as you, are doing. Regardless of the segment, market dynamics become meaningful with benchmarking.

items.q: What is benchmark analysis and what does it do?
items.a: It is the analysis process that allows you to compare the price, occupancy and revenue performance of your hotel with the competitive set and regional average of your choice.

items.q: How do I choose the right set of competitors for my hotel?
items.a: According to similar destination, segment, number of rooms, price range and target market criteria; You should choose hotels that compete for the same guests as you.

items.q: How do I follow competitor prices and campaigns?
items.a: With OTA and metasearch price monitoring tools; You should regularly report the date, room and channel-based price and campaign movements of the competitive set you have determined.

items.q: How do I read the occupancy and revenue benchmark?
items.a: By placing your own occupancy, ADR and RevPAR values ​​side by side with regional and competitor set averages; You analyze in which periods you are behind or ahead.

items.q: How do benchmark results affect my pricing strategy?
items.a: Benchmark shows with data in which period and segment you can raise or lower your price, and in which channel and market you should be more aggressive or cautious.

items.q: Who is Benchmark Analysis FAQ suitable for?
items.a: Price decisions are made not by inner feeling; It is suitable for all hotels that want to provide market and competitor data.

section3.title: Scope of Service: Competitor Set, Market & Price Comparisons

items.q: What does the benchmark analysis service include?
items.a:
• identification of the right competitive set,
  • price comparison reports on OTA/metasearch,
  • use of occupancy and revenue benchmark reports,
  • market and segment based positioning analysis,
  • production of price and campaign suggestions.

items.q: How to determine the right competitive set for the hotel?
items.a:
The following criteria are evaluated together:
  • destination (Antalya–Belek–Kemer–Side–Bodrum–Alanya etc.),
  • segment (luxury, family, adults only, budget, etc.),
  • number of rooms and facility scope,
  • price range,
  • target markets (country/segment),
  • similar OTA/web appearance and brand. perception.
Thus, your “real competitors” are determined; not just nearby hotels.

items.q: How are OTA price comparisons used in benchmarking?
items.a:
• Your and your competitor's OTA prices for certain dates are compared according to
  • room type and occupancy criteria,
  • your position in the market (cheap - balanced - premium) is determined,
  • If necessary, update and campaign suggestions are produced.

items.q: How to use occupancy and revenue benchmark reports?
items.a:
With regional reports and competitor set data:
  • occupancy, ADR, RevPAR trends are compared,
  • your hotel's "market share" and "price level" are understood,
  • decisions to request a higher price on certain dates or to flex the price for occupancy are supported.

items.q: How is benchmark data reflected in price and campaign decisions?
items.a:
• in periods of high demand & low competition → price and direct advantage are increased,
  • in periods of intense competition & low demand → campaign and channel strategies are revised,
  • segments in which you want to be positioned above/below your competitors → are marked with conscious pricing policies.

section4.title: Process & Operation: How Does Benchmark Analysis Work?

items.q: How to begin the benchmark analysis process?
items.a:
• Target setting: Is price, occupancy or market share priority?
  • Competitor set definition: With destination, segment, number of rooms, price and market criteria.
  • Identification of data sources: OTA/metasearch tools, market reports, internal PMS data.
  • Selection of benchmark periods: Season, shoulder, low season, special dates.
  • Reporting & commentary: Price and occupancy positioning. analysis and action plan.

items.q: How is OTA price and visibility data included in the benchmark?
items.a:
• Your and your competitors' OTA prices,
  • campaign and discount markings,
  • ranking/visibility positions (if possible)
are analyzed together. For example; If you are more expensive but you are ranked lower, this requires action on the “price/benefit perception” and content/visibility side.

items.q: For which periods should occupancy and income benchmarks be made?
items.a:
• high season,
  • shoulder periods (pre-season–end-season),
  • low season,
  • special events & periods (festivals, fairs, holidays, etc.).
Looking only at the “highest” period of the year hides the big picture.

items.q: How to use PMS data in benchmark analysis?
items.a:
When your own PMS data (occupancy, ADR, RevPAR) is compared with competitor and regional data:
  • “your price level” and
  • “how full you are”
are read together. For example; If you sell cheaper than your competitor and are less full; The problem is not just price – it is also necessary to look at the channel, visibility or brand perception side.

items.q: How often should benchmark analysis be done?
items.a:
• monthly for critical periods,
  • seasonally at the end-beginning of the season,
  • extra in case of strategy or market changes.
Weekly/real-time “mini benchmarks” are also useful, especially in busy areas.

items.q: What kind of reports does benchmark analysis produce?
items.a:
• competitor set price comparison reports (date/room/channel based),
  • occupancy and ADR comparisons,
  • RevPAR and market share analyses,
  • market and segment based benchmark reports,
  • OTA visibility and campaign benchmarks.

items.q: How to interpret OTA price comparisons?
items.a:
• If you are always in the cheapest position → unnecessary price loss and margin erosion,
  • If you are constantly in the most expensive position → risk of loss of occupancy,
  • If you are in the middle of the market but behind in occupancy → visibility, content and channel strategy need to be looked at.

items.q: How to use occupancy and revenue benchmark reports?
items.a:
• competitors are full, you are empty → the problem may not be in the price, but in the channel/visibility,
  • you are full, competitors are empty → you may consider raising the price a little,
  • both you and competitors are low full → market demand is weak; campaign and market diversification may be required.

items.q: How does benchmark analysis reflect on revenue?
items.a:
• reduces unnecessary “runs” in price,
  • provides ADR increase in high demand periods,
  • prioritizes channel and campaign investment correctly,
  • thus providing an increase in both occupancy and RevPAR.

items.q: How should I share benchmark results within the team?
items.a:
• Detailed tables and graphs for revenue/sales team,
  • plain summary and “what should we do?” for management. list,
  • relevant sections for operations and marketing (demand fluctuations, market priorities).
It is more effective to share summaries by role rather than giving everyone the same complex picture.

section6.title: Wrong Competitor Set, Missing Market Data, Pricing by Sentiment

items.q: What problems does choosing the wrong opponent set cause?
items.a:
• comparing with hotels in very different segments and price levels than your own,
  • making wrong price and campaign decisions,
  • unnecessarily aggressive or unnecessarily shy pricing,
  • the internal team not trusting the "benchmark".

items.q: What are the risks of working with incomplete market data?
items.a:
• saying "the market is good/bad" just by looking at your own occupancy and ADR,
  • lowering or raising the price without understanding whether there is demand or not,
  • missing the big picture by only looking at OTA prices.

items.q: What does it cost to make pricing decisions based solely on gut feeling?
items.a:
• unnecessary price cuts and loss of profits in some periods,
  • falling behind the market and loss of occupancy in other periods,
  • confusion of price/brand positioning over the years.

items.q: What happens if the benchmark analysis is constructed incorrectly?
items.a:
• incorrect set of competitors,
  • incorrect data sources,
  • misread reports,
ultimately lead the internal team to distrust the “benchmark work” and the entire investment is wasted.

items.q: Is it right to directly reflect benchmark data on prices?
items.a:
No. Benchmark data is an indicator and decision support tool; it should be considered together with your
  • brand positioning,
  • guest experience,
  • channel strategy
.

section7.title: Productive Search & Sector Focused Benchmark Analysis (Antalya, Belek, Kemer, Side, Bodrum, Alanya)

items.q: Why is benchmark analysis critical in destinations such as Antalya, Belek, Kemer, Side, Bodrum, Alanya?
items.a:
• numerous similar hotels,
  • peak season competition,
  • multi-market (DE, RU, UK, TR etc.) structure make benchmarking a mandatory management tool, not a luxury in these regions.

items.q: Which KPIs should be focused on in the benchmark for resort hotels?
items.a:
• seasonal ADR and occupancy,
  • country/market based night and revenue,
  • OTA channel shares,
  • RevPAR comparison with competing set.

items.q: How does the benchmark analysis differ for City hotels?
items.a:
• weekday/weekend distinction,
  • corporate and MICE segment performance,
  • short-stay and last minute behaviors,
should be especially monitored.

items.q: How should OTA price comparisons be read on a destination basis?
items.a:
• By placing similar segment hotels in the same destination side by side,
  • you should see which hotel acts aggressively or cautiously on which date,
  • you should update your own channel and price decisions accordingly.

items.q: How is benchmark data reflected in destination-based channel and campaign decisions?
items.a:
• In markets with strong demand, OTA and metasearch investment is increased,
  • In weak markets, campaign or channel diversification is considered,
  • direct vs OTA balance is adjusted according to market-based benchmark results.

section8.title: Mini Benchmark Analysis FAQ

items.q: Is benchmarking just looking at the competitor's price?
items.a: No; price, occupancy, revenue, market share and visibility should be evaluated together.

items.q: Can the same set of competitors be used for every hotel?
items.a: No; Because the segment, location and target market are different, the set of competitors must be customized for each hotel.

items.q: Do you need expensive tools to perform benchmark analysis?
items.a: Advanced tools are useful, but meaningful analysis can also be done in the beginning with simpler OTA/metasearch monitoring solutions and market reports.

items.q: Should I monitor benchmark data every day?
items.a: It is not necessary to look at it every day; More frequent monitoring during critical periods and weekly/monthly monitoring during normal periods is sufficient for most hotels.

items.q: Is benchmarking only the job of the revenue manager?
items.a: Even though its main ownership is in Revenue; It should be interpreted together with sales, marketing and management.

items.q: Is it enough to just position my price 'slightly lower than the competitors'?
items.a: No; Your concept, quality, brand perception and cost structure also determine the price level. Benchmark is for reference only.

items.q: Does it make sense to do the benchmark analysis once and put it aside?
items.a: No; As the market and competitors change, the benchmark should be updated periodically.

items.q: Do competitor prices on OTA always reflect reality?
items.a: Sometimes there may be channel based campaign, parity corruption or errors; Therefore, it is necessary to evaluate the data within the trend and general picture.

items.q: Can I be successful without benchmark data?
items.a: In the short term, yes; But as competition increases, the “price with feeling” approach puts you at a disadvantage.

items.q: Can I get the Benchmark Analysis service only as 'report + comment'?
items.a: Yes; You can get consultancy for regular benchmark reports and interpretation, and implement price and campaign actions with your own team.

generalQuestions.title: General Questions About Sales & Conversion Reporting

items.q: What exactly is a sales & conversion report?
items.a: Sales & conversion report; It is a reporting structure that shows the visitor → demand → reservation → revenue chain separately and in total for web, OTA and call center channels. The goal is not just “how many bookings did we get?” but “which channel generated how much traffic, demand, reservations and revenue?” is to answer the question clearly.

items.q: Why should I look at the conversion rate and not just the number of bookings?
items.a:
The number of reservations shows the result and the conversion rate shows the efficiency.
  • High traffic + low reservations = inefficient funnel,
  • Low traffic + high conversion = high potential structure.
It is difficult to make the right decision without reading both together.

items.q: What systems does sales & conversion reporting include?
items.a:
• GA4 / web analysis - visitor, session, funnel
  • PMS / reservation - room sales, ADR, income
  • OTA panels and reports - channel-based conversions
  • Call center / CRM - number of calls, offers, reservations
If necessary, this data is moved to panels such as Looker Studio and made readable.

items.q: Is just looking at OTA reports enough?
items.a: No. OTA reports only show the part coming from OTA. Web, call center and corporate sales do not appear in OTA reports at all. To see the total picture, it is necessary to include PMS, GA4 and call center data.

items.q: Is sales & conversion reporting only for marketing teams?
items.a:
Not.
  • Management → channel-based revenue and profitability
  • Revenue management → price & channel decisions
  • Marketing → campaign and web funnel performance
  • Call center & sales → call → offer → reservation chain
Each of them is fed by these reports.

items.q: Who is the Sales & Conversion Reporting FAQ suitable for?

• It is especially suitable for hotels and tourism businesses who say "There is traffic but no sales",
  • who see sales on OTAs and cannot read the web and call center adequately,
  • whose reports are fragmented between Excel and panel screens,

items.q: What is a sales conversion report and what does it do?

items.q: How to report hotel web, OTA and call center sales together?
items.a: By combining PMS, GA4, OTA and call center data in a single panel; channel-based sales and conversion rates are displayed on the same screen.

items.q: If there is traffic but no reservations, how to find the reason?
items.a: By examining the web funnel; You identify at which step users drop out (room selection, price screen, payment step, etc.) and from which channel the traffic is inefficient.

items.q: How do I measure the impact of the call center on sales?
items.a: By tracking the number of calls, number of offers, calls turned into reservations and the income of these reservations; You can calculate the real conversion and revenue contribution of the call center.

items.q: How do I know which channel is more profitable?
items.a: For each channel, you should report performance on both gross revenue and net profitability, comparing revenue – commission – marketing costs.

items.q: Who is the Sales & Conversion Reporting FAQ suitable for?
items.a: It is suitable for all hotels that want to see sales from web, OTA and call center in a single sales funnel.

items.q: How to report sales funnel on hotel website?
items.a:
Via GA4:
  • session → room search → room selection → price screen → payment → reservation
steps are followed. The drop-off rate is reported for each step; The steps where the greatest loss occurs are identified.

items.q: How should OTA performance appear in sales & conversion reports?
items.a:
• OTA-based reservation number and revenue,
  • channel commission cost,
  • cancellation/no-show rate,
  • Post-check-in revenue contribution of guests arriving via OTA
in short, "net contribution of the OTA channel" should appear.

items.q: How is the call center sales conversion rate calculated?
items.a:
• Total number of sales/reservation calls (or number of requests),
  • Number of calls with offers,
  • Number of calls converted to reservation and revenue.
Reservation conversion rate = Calls converted to reservation / call for sales purposes.

items.q: Is it possible to see offline and online sales together in reporting?
items.a: Yes. PMS and CRM data; By combining online (web/OTA) and offline (call center, agency, walk-in) sales in a single table, it can take a picture of the channels together.

section4.title: Process & Operation: How to Set Up a Sales Funnel?

items.q: How to start the sales & conversion reporting process?
items.a:
• The systems used (PMS, GA4, OTA, call center) are listed.
  • The basic funnel is defined: visitor → demand → reservation → income.
  • It is determined which data will be obtained from where for each channel.
  • KPI set and dashboard draft are prepared.
  • Reporting is tested and interpreted with the teams.

items.q: What steps should the sales funnel include?
items.a:
• Visitor / traffic (web, OTA listings, campaign clicks),
  • Demand (search, offer, call, cart/room review),
  • Reservation (completed sale),
  • Revenue (room revenue, additional revenues).
Rates are calculated for each step and channel.

items.q: How to combine GA4, PMS, OTA and call center data in one funnel?
items.a:
• GA4: session and web sales events,
  • PMS: actual reservations and revenue,
  • OTA: channel-based reservations,
  • call center: call and offer records.
They are shown in a single funnel by associating them through common time, channel and campaign fields.

items.q: How to solve offline report confusion?
items.a:
• Sales and proposal reports, which are kept by different departments in their own Excel, are moved to a central data structure (e.g. Sheets + Looker Studio),
  • entry standards (date, channel, source, etc.) are determined,
  • monitoring is done via the dashboard instead of producing manual reports.

items.q: What minimum systems are needed for sales & conversion reporting?
items.a:
• PMS (or similar reservation/revenue system),
  • GA4 (web analytics),
  • OTA reports,
  • basic sales data received from call center/CRM.
Looker Studio or similar panel tool is the layer that makes these readable.

section5.title: Performance & Reporting: “There is Traffic but No Sales” Problem

items.q: What is a sales & conversion report and what does it do?
items.a: Sales & conversion report; For each channel, “how many people came, how many people generated demand, how many people made reservations, how much revenue came in?” Answers your questions clearly. It shows where you are experiencing the “There is traffic but no sales” problem.

items.q: If there is traffic but no sales, how to find the reason?
items.a:
• On the web side: which funnel step has the biggest loss?
  • On the OTA side: are the visibility and price level compatible with the market?
  • On the call center side: what is the call → offer → booking conversion rate?
You can find the real reason by examining each step with data.

items.q: How is the booking conversion rate calculated?
items.a:
• Booking conversion rate (web) = Booking / Sales session
  • Booking conversion rate (OTA) = Booking / Click-out or view
  • Reservation conversion rate (call center) = Call returned to booking / sales call
These rates show the efficiency of the sales funnel.

items.q: How to understand which channel is more profitable?
items.a:
• Channel-based revenue,
  • channel-based commission and marketing costs,
  • operational load and return (cancellation/no-show) rates
are analyzed together. The important thing is to see the net profit contribution.

items.q: How does sales & conversion reporting connect to target KPIs?
items.a:
• web conversion rate,
  • direct pay,
  • call center conversion rate,
  • OTA share and ROI,
targets are determined and reports show the "green/red" table according to these targets.

section6.title: High Traffic – Low Bookings, Cart Abandonment, Call Not Converting

items.q: What are the typical reasons for the problem of high traffic but low bookings?
items.a:
• poor web UX/booking engine experience,
  • complex or unsafe payment step,
  • unclear price/concept information,
  • wrongly targeted campaigns (wrong audience, wrong market).

items.q: What does a high cart/room abandonment rate mean?
items.a:
The guest took care of the hotel and the room; but:
  • did not like the price/conditions,
  • decided to look at alternative hotels,
  • may have encountered technical or UX problems.
The reason should be analyzed step by step with funnel data.

items.q: How can I detect offers that do not turn into a reservation after a call?
items.a:
• it is necessary to create an offer record for each call,
  • to follow up via PMS whether there is a reservation after the offer,
  • to calculate the offer → reservation conversion rate,
  • to review low-performance segments (country, channel, room type) and scripts.

items.q: What causes offline report confusion?
items.a:
• number mismatch between departments,
  • “whose report is correct?” discussions,
  • late and conflicting reports,
  • delay in decision-making and loss of confidence.

items.q: What happens if sales & conversion reporting is constructed incorrectly?
items.a:
• funnel is defined incorrectly,
  • wrong KPIs are followed,
  • web/OTA/call center is blamed incorrectly,
  • reports lose confidence, the team comes to the point of "let's go back to Excel again"

section7.title: Productive Search & Sector-Focused Sales & Conversion Reporting (Antalya, Belek, Kemer, Side, Bodrum, Alanya)

items.q: Why is sales & conversion reporting important in destinations such as Antalya, Belek, Kemer, Side, Bodrum, Alanya?
items.a:
• short but busy season,
  • multi-channel sales structure (OTA, web, agency, call center),
  • fast price and campaign decisions.
If you do not know which one is really profitable in these regions, there is a high risk of spending the budget on the wrong channels and campaigns.

items.q: What should be focused on in sales & conversion reports for resort hotels?
items.a:
• family and country based segment transformations,
  • early booking etc. last-minute conversion differences,
  • OTA vs direct performance,
  • upsell/cross-sell contribution of call center.

items.q: How should sales & conversion reporting be positioned in City hotels?
items.a:
• corporate and individual booking funnels,
  • business travel and weekend segment performance,
  • direct sales vs OTA balance,
  • MICE queries and conversion rates.

items.q: What kind of decisions does sales & conversion reporting for Türkiye in general support?
items.a:
• how much to invest in which channel,
  • which market to go with which campaign,
  • which channel to reduce and which to expand,
  • whether direct share targets are realistic or not.

items.q: How does sales & conversion reporting connect to advertising and campaign strategy?
items.a:
• By seeing the traffic → funnel → booking → revenue chain from the campaign, you understand which campaigns bring only “traffic” and which bring “revenue”.
This allows you to shift the budget to the right campaigns.

section8.title: Mini Sale & Conversion FAQ

items.q: Is it enough to just look at the number of reservations without a Funnel report?
items.a: No; You need funnel to see why you are stuck at that reservation number.

items.q: My web conversion rate is low, is this just a price issue?
items.a: No; UX, speed, trust, content, targeting and technical issues can also be very influential.

items.q: What should I do if sales are high but profitability is low in OTA?
items.a: When trying to maintain conversion, you should consider rebalancing the direct pay and OTA mix.

items.q: Does it make sense to keep the call center report separate from the PMS report?
items.a: No; By combining PMS booking data and call data, you should see the real conversion and revenue contribution.

items.q: Should I use a single conversion rate for all channels?
items.a: No; The conversion dynamics of each channel are different, it is necessary to look at channel-based conversion rates.

items.q: Is just looking at ROAS enough for sales & conversion?
items.a: Not; In addition to ROAS, it is also necessary to analyze funnel steps and the number of reservations.

items.q: How should reservation cancellations be reflected in the conversion report?
items.a: “Net conversion” and “gross conversion” should be shown separately; Cancellation rates should be reported separately.

items.q: Does it make sense to A/B test a campaign without sales & conversion reporting?
items.a: No; It is not possible to interpret a test that you cannot measure.

items.q: Is it enough to just look at the OTA funnel?
items.a: Not; You cannot understand the whole sales picture without seeing the web and call center funnels.

items.q: Can I get the Sales & Conversion Reporting service only as "setup + training"?
items.a: Yes; You can receive dashboard/funnel installation and interpretation training for teams and carry out daily use and analysis with your own team.

section9.title: Collaboration and Actionable Questions for Sales & Conversion Reporting

items.q: How can I get a quote for the Sales & Conversion report with DGTLFACE?
items.a:

  • your current reporting format (Excel, existing panels, etc.),
  • the main problems you are experiencing (traffic but no sales, offline/online report confusion, etc.),
  • your goals (direct share, conversion rates, channel profitability); A Sales & Conversion Reporting roadmap and proposal can be prepared, including data source analysis, funnel design, KPI set and dashboard plan.

items.q: What does the “consult an expert” call clarify on the sales & conversion side?
items.a:
• Together we clarify where you really experience losses (traffic, funnel, booking, revenue),
  • which channels you should focus on more/less,

. Thus, Sales & Conversion reporting is not just “graphs and tables”; It becomes a practical management tool that feeds into channel and campaign decisions.

generalQuestions.title: General Questions About KVKK & Data Security

items.q: What is KVKK data security, what does it cover?
items.a:
KVKK data security; It is the set of technical and organizational measures taken to protect personal data (name, contact, reservation information, payment information, device data, etc.) processed by your hotel against unauthorized access,
  • not to be stored for unintended or excessive periods of time,
  • not to be shared without permission,
  • logging of access and changes,
    • .

items.q: Why is KVKK so critical in the hotel industry?
items.a:
Because hotels work with multi-layered guest data such as:
  • identity and contact information,
  • reservation and accommodation history,
  • preferences and special requests (in some cases, health or special quality data),
  • payment information,
. Incorrect management of these data is risky in terms of both KVKK sanction risk and guest trust and brand reputation.

items.q: What is the difference between “legal KVKK compliance” and “technical data security”?
items.a:
• On the legal side: information text, explicit consent, contracts, data inventory, VERBIS record, etc.
  • On the technical side: system architecture, access rights, logging, encryption, retention periods, backup and access records, etc.
This FAQ covers more technical & operational framework; Legal documents and comments should be discussed with your lawyer.

items.q: Which systems are critical for guest data?
items.a:
Generally:
  • PMS / channel manager / OTA connections,
  • call center & switchboard records,
  • website, cookie infrastructure and forms,
  • CRM, e-mail/SMS campaign systems,
  • security logs and access records.
How these systems transfer data to each other is the basis of KVKK & data security design.

items.q: Who is KVKK & Data Security FAQ suitable for?
items.a:
• for hotel and chain hotel structures,
  • resort & city & boutique hotels,
  • for all tourism brands that keep guest data in PMS, OTA, call center, web and CRM.
It is especially useful for managers and IT teams who want to collect the data flow from a technical perspective and prepare for the audit.

items.q: Is this FAQ legal advice?
items.a:
No. The content here:
  • is a general information and technical framework,
  • It should be detailed with your legal advisorfor your obligations within the scope of KVKK.

items.q: What exactly is KVKK data security?
items.a: KVKK data security; It is the protection of guest data by technical and organizational measures against unauthorized access, misuse and storage for longer than necessary.

items.q: How should I store guest data in my hotel in accordance with KVKK?
items.a: Data; In PMS and connected systems, you should store it with an architecture that has limited access, is logged, has defined retention periods and does not need to be copied unnecessarily.

items.q: How do I secure data flow between PMS, OTA and call center data?
items.a: In data flow; Secure connections (VPN/TLS), role-based access, encryption if possible, logging and recording of transfers to external systems are critical steps.

items.q: How should I keep cookie management and consent records?
items.a: For cookies used on your website; You must provide lighting and preference screens in accordance with KVKK, and keep a record of which permission was obtained and when by logging user choices.

items.q: What are technically asked during the KVKK audit?
items.a: In general; Your technical & organizational measures, including data inventory, retention periods, access authorizations, logging, backup, violation processes, cookie/permission management and training records, are questioned.

items.q: Who is KVKK & Data Security FAQ suitable for?
items.a: For all hotel and tourism brands that want to manage hotel guest data with a more secure, logged and KVKK compliant architecture.

section3.title: Service Scope: PMS, OTA, Call Center, Web & CRM

items.q: What technical topics does KVKK & data security consultancy cover?
items.a:
• Data map: extracting the data flow between PMS, OTA, call center, web, CRM,
  • Access & authorization matrix: who is accessing which system, at what level,
  • Logging framework: who accessed which data, when, what they did,
  • Storage & destruction policies: which data will be kept for how long,
  • Cookie & permission management: permission on the web and campaign side records,
  • Reporting & audit preparation: Technical background documentation for KVKK audit.

items.q: How should guest data be protected in the hotel PMS?
items.a:
• personal account and strong password policies for users,
  • role-based access (different levels such as reception, reservation, accounting, etc.),
  • IP or device-based access restrictions (where necessary),
  • limiting or masking access to critical areas (card information, etc.),
  • logging of all access and changes.

items.q: How should OTA and channel manager connections be handled in terms of data security?
items.a:
• operation of integrations via secure API or certified connections,
  • not sharing access tokens and passwords with unauthorized persons,
  • Managing OTA panel access on a person/role basis,
  • avoiding unnecessary export and e-mailing of reservation data.

items.q: What does KVKK & data security mean on the call center and CRM side?
items.a:
• storing call records in accordance with KVKK and not listening to them without authorization,
  • keeping guest complaints and requests only in the necessary systems without excessive copying,
  • associating data used for the campaign in CRM with permission records,
  • storing call and campaign logs in an access-controlled manner.

items.q: Why is logging so important within the scope of KVKK & data security?
items.a:
Logs answer the questions
  • Who accessed which data, when,
  • What changed or exported
. This is a critical record set for both internal audit and KVKK audit; It is also the basic way to understand what is at risk of data breach.

section4.title: Process & Operation: Data Map, Storage Periods, Cookies & Logging

items.q: How to create a KVKK compliant technical data map?
items.a:
• You list in which systems (PMS, OTA, call center, web, CRM) you keep guest data.
  • You determine which data is transferred between these systems, for what purpose and in what way.
  • Which data is entered from where, where it is stored and where it is deleted is processed.
This technical data map is the basic document for both KVKK and IT architecture.

items.q: How should access rights be structured from the KVKK perspective?
items.a:
• With the “need to know” principle: everyone should only access the data necessary to do their job,
  • department-based roles (front office, reservations, sales, IT, etc.),
  • extra privileges for managers but logged access,
  • timely closure of access of old users (who leave the job, change departments).

items.q: How should the data retention period and destruction process be designed?
items.a:
• For each type of data (reservation, invoice, log, campaign list, etc.), the storage period should be determined according to legal and operational requirements.
  • When this period expires, a technical process should be defined for the anonymization or destruction of the data.
  • It should be ensured that the destruction processes are logged and reported when necessary.
Here, you should definitely work with your legal advisor for the legal period and interpretation.

items.q: How to make cookie and permission management compatible with KVKK?
items.a:
• the types and purposes of cookies used on the website should be clearly stated,
  • the user must be asked to choose optional cookies,
  • user choices (date, IP, preference) must be logged,
  • these records must be available for audit when necessary.

items.q: What can be asked technically during the KVKK audit?
items.a:
Generally;
  • data inventory and data map,
  • access authorization matrix,
  • logging and security measures,
  • cookie and permission management records,
  • records of data storage and destruction processes,
  • technical documentation and sample records regarding the steps to be followed in case of data breach
are examined.

section5.title: Performance & Reporting: How Do We Track KVKK Compliance?

items.q: What is KVKK data security, what does it cover?
items.a:
With its short and practical definition, KVKK data security is to control the questions of
  • who accesses the data (authority),
  • what is happening in the data (logging),
  • how long the data is stored (storage period),
  • where the data goes (sharing),
at a technical level.

items.q: How should guest data be monitored in terms of reporting in the hotel PMS?
items.a:
• user login/logout and transaction logs,
  • who opened/changed which record,
  • which reports were received by which users,
  • data export (CSV/Excel) and e-mail sending logs
should be regularly monitored by IT and management.

items.q: Which technical KPIs can be followed for KVKK compliance?
items.a:
Technical indicators rather than legal KPIs:
  • number of active users vs number of defined users,
  • number of accounts forgotten to close,
  • rate of critical transactions not logged,
  • number of manual/inappropriate data exports,
  • time to detect data breach/suspicious cases.

items.q: Can KVKK & data security reporting be connected to panels such as Looker Studio?
items.a:
Yes. By reporting log and access records in the form of certain metrics, you can move indicators such as:
  • who is doing more transactions in which system,
  • which reports and exports are received the most,
  • from which IPs or devices there is unusual access
, etc., to visual dashboards.

items.q: How should I manage KVKK compliance as an “ongoing process”?
items.a:
• regular (e.g. every 6 months) technical and process audit,
  • data flow review as the new system/integration is put into effect,
  • access update in case of personnel changes,
  • simulated audit (mini audit) practices from time to time.

section6.title: Unauthorized Access, Incomplete Log, Uncertain Storage, Audit Risk

items.q: What risks does unauthorized user access pose?
items.a:
• visibility of guest data by wrong persons,
  • malicious use (listing, exporting),
  • data breach notification obligation,
  • risk of administrative fines and loss of reputation within the scope of KVKK.

items.q: In what situations is incomplete logging a problem?
items.a:
• since there is no "trace" of what happened, it becomes difficult to trace back the events,
  • you cannot answer the question of who did what during audits,
  • it becomes difficult to find the root cause in case of a data breach or error.

items.q: What do unclear data retention policies lead to?
items.a:
• more data is kept than necessary → risk and burden increases,
  • necessary data is kept for a shorter time than necessary → operational and legal problems arise,
  • in the audit, "which data is kept for how long?" The question cannot be answered clearly.

items.q: How risky is sharing guest data via WhatsApp, email and Excel?
items.a:
• data remains in dispersed environments instead of controlled systems (PMS, CRM),
  • it becomes impossible to implement deletion and retention policies,
  • it becomes difficult to keep track of who owns which file.
Therefore, in-system sharing should be preferred whenever possible.

items.q: What are the frequently encountered technical incompatibilities in KVKK audit?
items.a:
• inconsistent or incomplete access authorization matrix,
  • critical transactions not logged,
  • undefined retention period and destruction processes,
  • incomplete cookie/permission records,
  • lack of technical preparation for data breach scenarios.

section7.title: Productive Search & Sector Focused KVKK & Data Security (Antalya, Belek, Kemer, Side, Bodrum, Alanya)

items.q: What does KVKK data security mean for hotels in Turkey?
items.a: Hotels operating in Turkey; They are within the scope of KVKK as structures located in Turkey and/or processing data in Turkey. This means that all processes related to guest data (PMS, OTA, call center, web, CRM) must be carried out with technical and organizational measures in accordance with KVKK.

items.q: Why is the risk of data security high in destinations such as Antalya, Belek, Kemer, Side, Bodrum, Alanya?
items.a:
• high guest volume,
  • working with multiple agencies and OTAs,
  • seasonally increased use of temporary staff,
  • numerous systems and integrations.
All of this increases the number of data access and flow points; Therefore, it also increases the risk of KVKK.

items.q: Do KVKK technical risks change between resort hotels and city hotels?
items.a:
Although the basic risks are similar:
  • the number of guests and OTA/partners are more intense in resorts,
  • corporate and MICE data are more dominant in city hotels.
This leads to differences in data types and sharing points; KVKK & data security should be taken into consideration in design.

items.q: How should foreign guest data be considered within the scope of KVKK?
items.a: The data of foreign guests also falls within the scope of KVKK as long as it is processed and stored in Turkey. In addition, other legislation such as GDPR may come into play for some global chains; At this point, it is necessary to act together with your legal advisor for both local and global compliance.

items.q: How to harmonize brand standards with KVKK technical requirements in global chain hotels?
items.a:
• data flows between global systems and local PMS/CRM should be clarified,
  • which data is stored in which country and which legal order it is subject to should be analyzed,
  • both chain IT standards and KVKK technical measures should be handled together.

section8.title: Mini KVKK & Data Security FAQ

items.q: Is KVKK compliance only about preparing legal documents?
items.a: No; Elements such as technical architecture, access control, logging, retention period and training are at least as important as legal documents.

items.q: Is it in compliance with KVKK for all employees to have access to all data?
items.a: Usually no; Due to the “need to know” principle, everyone should only access data necessary for their job.

items.q: Is it sufficient to provide KVKK training to employees?
items.a: Necessary but not sufficient; Training should be supported by technical and process measures.

items.q: Is using cloud-based PMS a problem in terms of KVKK?
items.a: Regardless of cloud or on-prem; You need to be able to clearly answer the questions of where the data is kept, what security measures are there, how access and logging work.

items.q: If I use cookies and pixels, do I need a lighting and consent screen?
items.a: Generally yes for cookie/pixel types that provide traceability; You should work with your legal advisor for a detailed evaluation.

items.q: Is it more appropriate to KVKK to keep all logs forever?
items.a: No; Reasonable retention periods should be determined for logs, and destruction/anonymization processes should be put into effect at the end of these periods.

items.q: If there is a KVKK violation, should I report it?
items.a: In general terms, data breaches may need to be reported to the relevant authority within certain periods; You should consult your legal advisor for the specific situation.

items.q: Is carrying a guest list in Excel against KVKK?
items.a: It is risky; Because it is not possible to control who owns Excel files, where they are stored and when they will be deleted. In-system and logable structures should be preferred whenever possible.

items.q: Is a one-time project sufficient for KVKK & data security?
items.a: Not; This is an ongoing process as there are new systems, integrations, personnel changes and regulatory updates.

items.q: What are KVKK technical measures?
items.a: Generally; These include access control, encryption (if appropriate), logging, secure connections, storage and destruction processes, backup and security updates. For a detailed and binding list, you should consult your official guide and legal advisor.

section9.title: Collaboration and Actionable Questions for KVKK Data Security Consultancy

items.q: How can I get an offer for KVKK data security consultancy with DGTLFACE?
items.a:
• If you share a brief brief summarizing the PMS, OTA, channel manager, call center, web and CRM systems you use,
  • the KVKK documents and technical measures you currently have,
  • the risk areas you think you are experiencing (unauthorized access, Excel/WhatsApp usage, lack of logs, etc.)
If you share a brief briefing; A KVKK & Data Security roadmap and proposal can be prepared, including technical data flow analysis, risk map and recommended technical/process improvements.

items.q: What does the call to “consult with an expert” clarify on the KVKK & data security side?
items.a:
• Together, we clarify which of your systems should be prioritized,
  • where there is the highest KVKK technical risk (authorization, log, storage, sharing),
  • simple measures that can be taken in the short term, and
  • the reporting & logging structure to be established in the medium term
. Thus, KVKK & data security is not just “form and text”; It becomes a technically living structure that is ready for inspection.

voiceQueries.q5: Is resort and city hotel SEO strategy different?
